headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining the Sherwin-Williams Company's Review of Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Results and Expectations; and Bob Wells, Senior Vice President Corporate Communications. This conference call is being webcast simultaneously
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining the Sherwin-Williams Company's Review of Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Results and Expectations; and Bob Wells, Senior Vice President Corporate Communications. 
This conference call is being webcast simultaneously in listen-only mode by Issuer Direct via the Internet at www.sherwin.com. An archived replay of this webcast will be available at www.sherwin.com, beginning approximately 2 hours after the conference call concludes, and will be available until Wednesday, February 17 at 5:00 p.m. Eastern time.
This conference call will include forward-looking statements under U.S. federal securities laws, with respect to sales, earnings and other matters. Any forward-looking statement speaks only as of the day on which such statement is made, and the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A full declaration regarding forward-looking statements is provided in the company's earnings release transmitted earlier this morning. After the company's prepared remarks, we will open the session to questions. I will now turn the call over to Bob Wells.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jesse. Good morning, everyone. In the interest of time, we've provided some balance sheet items and other select financial information on our website, www.sherwin.com, under Investor Relations, January 28th Press Release. Our consolidated sales
componenttext:
Thanks, Jesse. Good morning, everyone. In the interest of time, we've provided some balance sheet items and other select financial information on our website, www.sherwin.com, under Investor Relations, January 28th Press Release. 
Our consolidated sales in the fourth quarter increased 1.4% to $2.6 billion, due entirely to higher paint sales volume to our Paint Stores and Consumer Group. 
For the full sales increased 1.9% to $11.34 billion. Unfavorable currency translation decreased consolidated net sales 3.6% in the quarter and 3.3% for the full year. Consolidated gross profit in the fourth quarter increased $104.3 million to $1.3 billion and gross margin expanded to 50.8% of sales from 47.4% of sales in the fourth quarter 2014. 
For the year, gross margin increased to 49% of sales from 46.4% of sales last year. The increase in gross margin in the quarter and full year was due primarily to volume-driven supply chain productivity and lower year-over-year raw material cost. 
Selling, general and administrative expense increased $6.1 million to $991.5 million in the fourth quarter, but decreased as a percent of sales to 38.1% from 38.3% in the same quarter last year. 
For the full year 2015, SG&A expense increased $90.6 million to $3.91 billion, an increase as a percent of sales to 34.5% from 34.3% in 2014. The incremental SG&A to support the new HGTV HOME program at Lowe's and new store openings and sales territory addition, accounted for a majority of the SG&A increase in the year. 
Other general expense decreased $12.6 million in the fourth quarter and $7.2 million for the year, due primarily to lower environmental expenses in both periods. 
Interest expense for the quarter increased $4.1 million to $19.5 million. For the year, interest expense was $61.8 million compared to $64.2 million in 2014. 
Profit before tax in the fourth quarter increased 57.4% to $297.2 million; and for the full year, increased 23.1% to $1.55 billion. 
Our effective income tax rate for the fourth quarter 2015 increased to 33.4% from 29.7% in the fourth quarter last year. 
For the year, our effective tax rate was 32% compared to 31.2% in 2014. 
Consolidated net income for the quarter increased $65.3 million to $198 million. For the year, net income increased $188 million to $1.05 billion. 
Net income as a percent of sales in the quarter increased to 7.6% from 5.2% last year. For the year, net income as a percent of sales increased to 9.3% from 7.8% in 2014. 
Diluted net income per common share in the fourth quarter 2015 increased to $2.12 from $1.37 per share in the fourth quarter of 2014. For the full year, diluted net income per common share increased 27.1% to $11.16 per share from $8.78 per share in 2014. 
Let me take a few minutes to break down our performance by segment. Sales for our Paint Stores Group in the fourth quarter 2015 increased 5.9% to $1.68 billion. Thanks to higher architectural paint sales volume across all customer segments. 
For the year, net sales increased 5.2% to $7.21 billion. This full year sales increase was also driven by higher architectural paint sales volume across all segments. 
Comparable store sales increased 5.1% in the quarter and 4.2% in the year. Regionally, in the fourth quarter, our Midwest division led all division, followed by Eastern division, Southeastern division and Southwestern division. 
Fourth quarter segment profit for Paint Stores Group increased 27.8% to $316.1 million, due primarily to higher year-over-year paint sales volumes. 
For the full year, Paint Stores Group profit increased 19.3% to $1.43 billion from $1.2 billion in 2014. The increase in segment profit for the year resulted from higher paint sales volume that were partially offset by higher SG&A expenses. Segment profit margin for the fourth quarter increased to 18.9% from 15.6% last year. 
Profit margin for the full year 2015 increased to 19.9% from 17.5% in 2014. 
Turning now to consumer group. Fourth quarter external net sales increased 13.6% to $314.6 million. 
For the year, consumer group sales increased 11.1% to $1.58 billion. Most of the increase in sales for the fourth quarter and full year was from the HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams Paint Program at Lowe's. 
Segment profit for the fourth quarter increased 67.9% to $50.9 million from $30.3 million in the fourth quarter 2014. For the year, segment profit increased 22.1% to $308.8 million from $252.9 million in 2014. 
Consumer groups segment profit as a percent of net sales in the fourth quarter increased to 16.2% from 11% last year. 
For the year, segment profit margin increased to 19.6% from 17.8% last year. Most of the improvement in both the fourth quarter and full year segment profit margin was from volume-driven operating efficiency. 
For our Global Finishes Group, fourth quarter net sales in U.S. dollars decreased 9.5% to $454.8 million. And full year sales decreased 7.9% to $1.92 billion, due primarily to unfavorable currency translation. 
Currency translation decreased sales in U.S. dollars by 7.1% in the quarter and 7.5% in the year. 
Stated in U.S. dollars, global finishes group profit in the fourth quarter, increased to $50.6 million from $39 million last year. The increase in segment profit in the quarter resulted from good expense control and lower year-over-year raw material costs that were partially offset by unfavorable currency translation, which reduced segment profit $4.8 million. 
For the year, segment profit increased 0.4% to $201.9 million from $201.1 million last year. This full year profit improvement resulted from good expense control and lower raw material costs that were mostly offset by unfavorable currency translation of $26.5 million. 
As a percent of net sales, Global Finishes Group's operating profit was 11.1% in the fourth quarter compared to 7.8% last year and 10.5% for the year compared to 9.7% in 2014. 
For our Latin America Coatings Group. Net sales decreased 23.5% to $158.7 million in the fourth quarter and decreased 18.2% to $631 million for the full year, due primarily to unfavorable currency translation and lower volume sales, partially offset by higher year-over-year selling prices. Currency translation decreased sales in U.S. dollars by 21.4% in the quarter and 19.3% in the year. 
Stated in U.S. dollars, Latin America Coatings Group's segment profit in the quarter decreased to $2.8 million from $13 million last year. For the year, segment profits decreased to $18.5 million from $40.5 million in 2014. The decline in segment profit in both quarter and year was primarily due to unfavorable currency translation and lower volume sales, partially offset by selling price increases. 
Unfavorable currency translation decreased segment profit $5.3 million in the quarter and $16 million in the full year. 
As a percent of net sales, segment operating profit was 1.8% in the fourth quarter, compared to 6.3% last year and 2.9% for the year compared to  5.2% in 2014. 
That concludes the review of our operating results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. So let me turn the call over to John Morikis who will make some general comments and highlight our expectations for 2016. John?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. As we announced last October, in January 1 of this year, I assumed the duties of Chief Executive Officer. Back in 1971, British rock band, The Who, recorded the now famous lyrics, meet the new
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. 
As we announced last October, in January 1 of this year, I assumed the duties of Chief Executive Officer. Back in 1971, British rock band, The Who, recorded the now famous lyrics, meet the new boss, same as the old boss. In our case, the same may not hold true literally in every respect, but it is certainly true when it comes to our mutual confidence in the company's strategy, our focus on growing market share through superior products and execution, our adherence to key performance metrics like return on net assets employed and net operating cash through sales and our shareholder-friendly capital allocation. These are the things that will define the value of Sherwin-Williams in the years ahead. And I believe, they are all moving in the right direction. 2015 was a year of ups and downs. 
Our full year revenue of $11.3 billion set a new record for the company. But fell a little short of our original expectations. One reason for this was stronger currency headwinds than originally anticipated. Another was the weaker-than-expected demand for industrial coatings in certain categories. Particularly, that was used to maintain oil and gas production in storage assets. And in the middle 2 quarters of 2015, we grew our long-standing practice of not giving weather reports on earnings calls as heavy rainfall across much of the country clearly affected paint demand. This lower-than-expected revenue performance, however, did not translate to lower-than-expected profit or cash flow. 
Our full year profit before tax net income, earnings per share and net operating cash all met or exceeded the expectations we set back in January 2015. Net income eclipsed to $1 billion in 2015 for the first time in our company's history. This strong profitability  and cash generation was largely due to the successful and accelerated integration of the Comex stores and the consolidation of Comex manufacturing assets, coupled with volume-driven sales -- supply chain productivity in North America, good SG&A control and raw material cost tailwinds. 
Looking ahead, we expect the year-over-year incremental margin benefit from the Comex integration to diminish as we go through 2016. Architectural paint sales through our paint stores picked up momentum in the fourth quarter, but was again, offset to some degree by negative volumes in protected and marine coatings. 
Sales to residential contractors continue to grow at double-digit paces. Sales volume to the new construction markets and DIY customers also increased compared to last year, but at a full pace than residential repaint. 
In total, Paint Stores Group grew fourth quarter revenues by just under 6%, with architectural paint volume growth outpacing revenues. 
For the fourth quarter, we opened 38 net new stores, bringing our full year store opening total to 83 new location. And our total store count at year-end to 4,086 stores in the U.S, Canada and the Caribbean. We remain confident that our next milestone of 5,000 locations in North America is realistic, and we intend to get closer to that goal by 90 to 100 stores this year. 
Consumer Group also turned into a solid performance for the year. The launch of the HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams Paint Program at Lowe's was one reason. But we also saw strong sales growth from another valued home center partner, Menards. As a result, Consumer Group's business grew by low single-digit percentage phase in the quarter. 
Market and economic conditions outside North America continue to be very challenging. Sales volumes in most Latin American countries fluctuated modestly compared to fourth quarter 2014. And with the exception of Brazil, our volumes and revenues declined significantly. The impact of currency devaluation, once again, was worse-than-anticipated in the quarter. 
Global Finishes Group also thought softening environment coatings demand and deteriorating currencies in both Europe and Latin America, but made progress in offsetting these effects through tight SG&A controls. 
In 2015, we generated record net operating cash of $1.45 billion. Thanks in part to the terrific working capital management by all of our operating segments. Despite of the incremental working capital required to support the HGTV HOME Program at Lowe's, our working capital ratio at year-end dropped to 8.6% of sales from 10.1% last year. 
Free cash flow, which is net operating cash, less CapEx and dividends, was $953.5 million compared to $655.7 million last year. We used this cash from operations to fund capital expenditures, increase our dividend and buyback shares for treasury. 
Our capital expenditures in 2015 totaled $234 million. Depreciation for the year was $170 million, and amortization was $28 million. 
In 2016, we anticipate capital expenditures of approximately $240 million, depreciation of $185 million to $200 million and amortization of about $30 million. 
The capital spending will run higher-than-normal in 2016 as we complete some facility renovation process. 
Through 2015, we returned more than $1.28 billion in cash to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. 
In the fourth quarter, we acquired 1 million shares of the company's stock for treasury, bringing our full year to 3.575 million shares at an average cost of $278.57 per share and a total investment of just over $1 billion. 
At year-end, we have remaining authorization to acquire 11.65 million shares. 
We paid $249.6 million in cash to shareholders through quarterly dividend. 2015 marked our 37th consecutive year of increased dividends per share, and we intend to continue. This year, at our February meeting of the Board of Directors, we will recommend approval of an annual dividend of $3.36 per share, an increase of more than 25% over 2015. 
Looking ahead to 2016. The demand for paint and coatings in most domestic markets looks encouraging. Both residential starts and existing home turnover was solid throughout 2015. And the Outlook for 2016 is equally encouraging. Although contrast for new nonresidential projects dips slightly in 2015, there was still a strong year in absolute terms, which bodes well for paint demand in this segment. 
Outside the U.S., it appears likely that sluggish market conditions and the currency devaluation, particularly in Europe and many Latin American countries will remain a challenge. 
Our raw material basket has many moving parts but in total, we believe we're likely to see lower year-over-year input costs in 2016. The continuing fall in the price of crude oil will no doubt have a positive impact on this petrochemical side on the raw materials basket. But these commodities will not necessarily move in many of our relationship with crude. The price of high-grade chloride TiO2 continues to slide over the back half of 2015 due to weak global demand and over capacity, but it's likely nearing the bottom. Based on these factors, we would expect average year-over-year raw material costs for the paint and coatings industry to be down in the mid-single-digit range in 2016. 
Our outlook for first quarter 2016 is for consolidated net sales to increase in the low single digits percentage range compared to last year's first quarter. With sales at that level, we estimate diluted net income per common share in the first quarter will be in the range of $1.50 to $1.55 per share compared to the $1.38 per share earned in the first quarter of 2015. 
For the full year 2016, we expect net sales will increase in the low single-digit percentage range compared to full year 2015. With annual sales at that level, we estimate diluted net income for common share for 2015 will be in the range of $12.20 to $12.40 compared to $11.16 in 2015. 
Again, I would like to thank you for sharing -- for being with us this morning, and now we'd be happy to open it up for questions.

componenttextpreview: John, this is Bob. We think that there could be some benefit in the petrochemical side of the basket, maybe as much as we saw in 2015. We think that -- we saw a pretty big move in TiO2 in '15, and we're likely to see that bigger move in '16. So mid-single
componenttext: John, this is Bob. We think that there could be some benefit in the petrochemical side of the basket, maybe as much as we saw in 2015. We think that -- we saw a pretty big move in TiO2 in '15, and we're likely to see that bigger move in '16. So mid-single digits, I think, is a reasonable Outlook for the industry and as we usually do, we'll update that as we go through the year.

componenttext: If you look at the -- this is Sean Hennessy. So I'll take the first -- the second part first. I think that the non-paint sales performed fairly well. I think that, consistently throughout the year, we had a nice gear in the non-paint sales, but they accelerated also. I think that Paint Stores Group had a very nice quarter. And as John said, we don't usually talk about weather. But maybe weather helped us a little bit. I think that when you look at the second and third quarter versus the fourth quarter, we did use weather in the second and third quarter. You'll see parts of that.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Bob. We have very few data sources to go to, to help us with estimates of industry volume. The American Coatings Association models industry volume over the course of the year, they currently stand at an estimate of 5.5% growth for 2015. We thin
componenttext: Yes, it's Bob. We have very few data sources to go to, to help us with estimates of industry volume. The American Coatings Association models industry volume over the course of the year, they currently stand at an estimate of 5.5% growth for 2015. We think they're a little high. We were thinking more in the 3% to 3.5% range. But as we collect more data, year-end data, we'll kind of fine tune that outlook. But I think it's likely the industry is going to end up in the 3% to 3.5% range.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just one last one before I turn it over. With the spring selling season quickly approaching, can you talk about some of the lessons learned at most in 2015? And if any, strategies anything are going to do in 2015?
componenttext: Great. And just one last one before I turn it over. With the spring selling season quickly approaching, can you talk about some of the lessons learned at most in 2015? And if any, strategies anything are going to do in 2015?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think there is a strategy shift at all. I think lessons learned include the importance of being very responsive obviously, to our customers. Really working well with the associates in the aisles and helping them to be successful and now it's growi
componenttext: I don't think there is a strategy shift at all. I think lessons learned include the importance of being very responsive obviously, to our customers. Really working well with the associates in the aisles and helping them to be successful and now it's growing our product. I think we've got a very good strategy there. I think we've got a very good relationship there. And I think we're working very hard to be the best customer there as we do with all of our customers..

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is, from the line of Don Carson with Susquehanna Financial.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question for Sean. Just in gross margin here. Just when we think it can't get any better, it does, particularly in the fourth quarter. So I'm wondering how much of that was volume-driven? Was there any true up against your standard cost because turned out
componenttext: Question for Sean. Just in gross margin here. Just when we think it can't get any better, it does, particularly in the fourth quarter. So I'm wondering how much of that was volume-driven? Was there any true up against your standard cost because turned out to be lower than you originally thought when you made the estimate on standard costing? And what's kind of your outlook for next year, I mean, if you end the year in a 50.8% gross margin? That signal is a pretty strong performance as we get into the paint season this year.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Dan, if you look at that 300 to 400 basis points, possibly half of that was due to the paint volume increases through our North America supply chain. That's really the #1 thing that drove it. That also includes the integration of that Comex busines
componenttext: Right. Dan, if you look at that 300 to 400 basis points, possibly half of that was due to the paint volume increases through our North America supply chain. That's really the #1 thing that drove it. That also includes the integration of that Comex business. That has been a nice piece of that. Don't forget to remember the mix because of the foreign currency exchange. As U.S. becomes bigger and bigger piece of that -- of our total sales, the Paint Stores Group does have the highest gross margin. So that helped on the other piece. Now having said that, LIFO is always trying to catch what you think is  going to happen with the raws and the way the raws came in, there was a slight help from the LIFO. LIFO did help us, especially in the Consumer Group but also a little bit in the Stores Group. If you take a look about the long-term, in the long term, I think we try to give you guidance what we think is a long-term. We think that probably our long-term, when you look at the make-up of the company and where we are going, it's in the mid-47s to the mid-49s. I think -- again, when that foreigners currency changes around, instead of being at 80% U.S. in North American sales, you're going to see start seeing that come down and back pedaling to the 70%. That will have the reverse impact in the gross margins. So when we feel like we're running at a normal area, we think we're going to end up 47.5% to 49.5% gross margins.

But John, you might want to comment on the guidance within the sales side. I think we expect...

componenttext: As I mentioned, we're working closely with all levels of Lowe's, and we're feeling good about the momentum, as I mentioned. So I think it's a matter of execution know. And as I said, we're going to focus on being the best partner we can for them and every customer that we have.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, you have just kind of [ph] 4,100 stores to date, and you said, 5,000 is the target. Is there a saturation point for you in terms of numbers of stores? And what do you think you might get there?
componenttext: And John, you have just kind of [ph] 4,100 stores to date, and you said, 5,000 is the target. Is there a saturation point for you in terms of numbers of stores? And what do you think you might get there?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me be clear. 5,000 is not our target. It's a milestone. And I often say that I refer to it because it's between 4 and our next number is 6. And so we're going to stop at 5 on the way. We're -- we don't see a saturation point. We've continued to add st
componenttext: Let me be clear. 5,000 is not our target. It's a milestone. And I often say that I refer to it because it's between 4 and our next number is 6. And so we're going to stop at 5 on the way. We're -- we don't see a saturation point. We've continued to add stores. Each of our district managers maintained a real estate strategy, and our plan is to continue to invest in their stores. And there's not one of them that has raise their hand and say they really see no additional -- additional market to think and add to. So it's our expedition that we're going to continue to invest in those markets and continue to penetrate the opportunities in those markets, and we're excited about that.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, John, is there any particular area where you want to add stores?
componenttext: And then, John, is there any particular area where you want to add stores?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're obviously looking at the West Coast. We shared with the community here that we look at households propane store, and we see a terrific opportunity in the West area of the country. And again, we remained very confident in this model. It's  this model
componenttext: We're obviously looking at the West Coast. We shared with the community here that we look at households propane store, and we see a terrific opportunity in the West area of the country. And again, we remained very confident in this model. It's  this model and our ability to grow market share and to, in fact, grow our operating leverage as we grow that incremental volume that gives us that confidence.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Question. There's a number of ways just to triangulate it. But if you look at the Q4, you delivered, and then the Q1 that you've guided to, just take the midpoint, and then extrapolate that through '16, there's a disconnect between how good those quarters were and kind of where the midpoint is for '16. So is there something in the back 3 quarters where there's a little bit of a step down that we should take into account? Or is that just a good case of conservatism?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think when you look at it the way you just guided us to, I think the first quarter, I just want to remind you, in Consumer Group, because of the HGTV expansion, if you remember the growth, the SG&A expenses, we had a jump in the first quarter when we po
componenttext: I think when you look at it the way you just guided us to, I think the first quarter, I just want to remind you, in Consumer Group, because of the HGTV expansion, if you remember the growth, the SG&A expenses, we had a jump in the first quarter when we pointed out last year that, that was going to be -- we had 100% SG&A, 0 sales. So I think that this year, we're going to have relatively close to the same amount of SG&A but some sales going against it. I think that helped us. So I think if you look over 2 years, I think the first quarter would look more normal to you and would probably more like the other 3 quarters we have in the guidance.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And then one of the issues in '15, was -- it seems like your customers were running up against their bandwidth as far as just the number of painters they can employ. Is your sense that they could ever expand their paint force? And therefore, t
componenttext: Okay, good. And then one of the issues in '15, was -- it seems like your customers were running up against their bandwidth as far as just the number of painters they can employ. Is your sense that they could ever expand their paint force? And therefore, the opportunity for more sales is bigger this year in the U.S?

componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's improved to some degree. It's hard to put your fingers exactly on that. But I'd say that in the market, I think it's gotten a little better.
componenttext: Well, I think that's improved to some degree. It's hard to put your fingers exactly on that. But I'd say that in the market, I think it's gotten a little better.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm kind of curious with your was for spending money down in South America opportunistically, given what's going on down there?  Or may be there is a little field estimate, what are your thoughts on these [indiscernible]
componenttext: I'm kind of curious with your was for spending money down in South America opportunistically, given what's going on down there?  Or may be there is a little field estimate, what are your thoughts on these [indiscernible]

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that there's a little difference everywhere. I think that 2 years ago, we were really nervous about putting money down in Argentina. And you think about the exchange rate now at 13x. If you look at Chile now, they've changed their government out.
componenttext: I think that there's a little difference everywhere. I think that 2 years ago, we were really nervous about putting money down in Argentina. And you think about the exchange rate now at 13x. If you look at Chile now, they've changed their government out. And I think -- so we feel away feel okay investing in Chile. We're probably -- long-term, we still feel good about Brazil. But we're watching both of those governments and see what happens with some of the policies down there. We -- if the right opportunity would appear, we would actually buy it. I think that if we are still looking at a long-term. But I think on the marginal investments, we've been very careful on what we're going to spend down there. And when I say marginal, I'm not talking about distribution or manufacturing or marketing. I think more on the advent side, systems side, those kinds of sides. How much working capital will allow it to grow and so forth. And we're watching it, and we feel good about it. We're still cash positive in each and every country. And that really helps us stay in the course. But we think, eventually, it might be a while. We were going through where we went through in the late '80s and early '90s when we actually had to do inflationary accounting in South America, which I haven't looked at some of the rules. It's been so long. So we take a look at this size and we're watching these things. But we're very careful in the margin.

componenttext: We don't break it out by regions. But I could say, directionally, as you would expect the oil and gas market there has experienced the pressure that one would expect. We are growing in the market. Our acquisitions of a brand that came along with Comex, General Paint, is we're in the process of integrating that end, and we're really excited about the momentum that we're gaining up there. So on the architectural side, we're continuing to grow. In the Protected and Marine side, we continue to see some pressure.

componenttext: I've got a few quick ones. Starting with the fourth quarter, you beat the consensus estimate by about $0.18. headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes. If you take a look at the guidance that we gave at the beginning of 2015, about a year ago, we gave you $0.20 and that was a $0.90 to $0.11. But I think that we feel confident that we're able to whether it happens at just a different things, and we think that we're going to be able to get that kind of improvement.

componenttext: Yes, we do. Just think about how the Brazilian reals, even the Canadian dollar that we are talking about before. We definitely have a foreign currency. componenttext: I will tell you that when we look at our guidance, I think the fourth quarter is pretty interesting. Total, we were at 1.4% of sales gain, store throughput was 5.9%. So 4x what we thought that we are going to be at. So I think that currency, other things, I think that we don't break out our guidance by segment. But I think that to give you some indication, that tells you where we think the growth is going to be.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: But we do see, to your point, Protective & Marine, we do expect that, that pressure is going to continue for the foreseeable future.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as a follow-up, on the raw side, obviously, some decline incremental in 3Q and 4Q. If I go through the math, I guess, we expect that to continue to see a benefit in '15 to '16. Is there any reason why we shouldn't expect a nice benefit
componenttext: Okay. And then just as a follow-up, on the raw side, obviously, some decline incremental in 3Q and 4Q. If I go through the math, I guess, we expect that to continue to see a benefit in '15 to '16. Is there any reason why we shouldn't expect a nice benefit on the raw side? And maybe you can just elaborate on the oil-based versus TiO2.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun. This is Bob. We do expect to continue to see benefit from raw materials. And we commented that on the oil side, it does take longer for a drop in propylene and ethylene to work its way through the acrylic chain and actually dip to market. So th
componenttext: Yes, Arun. This is Bob. We do expect to continue to see benefit from raw materials. And we commented that on the oil side, it does take longer for a drop in propylene and ethylene to work its way through the acrylic chain and actually dip to market. So there is probably more tailwind on that side of the basket in the year to come than there is on the TiO2 side. TiO2 took a pretty sharp drop in the back half of last year. We'll see that, obviously, the benefit of that in the first half of this year. But TiO2 is approaching kind of it's historic starting place of $100 a pound on the spot market. So we don't necessarily see a lot of further runway for TiO2 to decline.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I  think that we've been pretty consistent with our cash utilization. I think that we feel pretty good about the cash generation of the company. I think we've been consistently generating cash and cash over the last 15 or so years, and I'm going back to w
componenttext: I  think that we've been pretty consistent with our cash utilization. I think that we feel pretty good about the cash generation of the company. I think we've been consistently generating cash and cash over the last 15 or so years, and I'm going back to when we took -- when we were put into these jobs. I think you're going to see us to continue to invest in the business and CapEx and new stores and so forth. I think that we're going to pay out dividends. You heard the dividend going over $3.30. And then, we're going to look at acquisitions and we're going to look at buying back stock. And I would tell you, I'd be surprised if we were holding cash at the end of next year.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then, I wanted to dig in a few brief questions. In terms of Global Finishes, So to what do you attribute like the sudden step up in profitability? Obviously, GM is going to help up a little bit. But what kind of what major improvement would you put in the cost side? And how sustainable that on next several quarters?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Because when you look at the Global Finishes Group in the fourth quarter, it was up 29%. It was -- the operating profit was really driven by SG&A expense control and favorable raw material costs, which more than offset the negative currency because
componenttext: Right. Because when you look at the Global Finishes Group in the fourth quarter, it was up 29%. It was -- the operating profit was really driven by SG&A expense control and favorable raw material costs, which more than offset the negative currency because it had to go against currency also. And I would tell you, we feel pretty good about this -- the SG&A savings that we have. And I'll tell you, years ago, when this Global Finishes Group was operating at 3% to 3.5%, after we've left the and income acquisitions. We said eventually that we felt we could run at 12%. So we think we're at a pretty good spot. We think in the future, one that improvement has come from those efficiencies we're going to get. I think in the future, is going to be driven by market share gains and sales gains.

And this year, you're guiding 10%. So the fact that it continue to feel good about the architectural paint market and raw materials tailwinds. So I guess there's an offset from Comex not being as accretive. But what else is in the project that we should consider that should contribute to lower earnings growth this year?

componenttext: I think that the FX headwinds, I would say, be a little more -- I'd like to say that our estimate is a little stronger than it  was going into last year. componenttextpreview: We are continuing to invest in the store transitions over to Sherwin's. So to Sean's point, largely in the supply chain side, the give us a terrific job in a fairly moved some of that up from what we have expected to see in 2016 -- 2015. And we were succe
componenttext: We are continuing to invest in the store transitions over to Sherwin's. So to Sean's point, largely in the supply chain side, the give us a terrific job in a fairly moved some of that up from what we have expected to see in 2016 -- 2015. And we were successful also on the store side, but there's still some work to do on the store side and that's what we're working on here as we roll into 2016.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, very helpful. And just one last one for you, Sean. The capital conversion to sales that you guys have kind of talked in that may continue community about it, right around 13% this year. Is that -- is there something unusual? Or that's kind of the n
componenttext: Great, very helpful. And just one last one for you, Sean. The capital conversion to sales that you guys have kind of talked in that may continue community about it, right around 13% this year. Is that -- is there something unusual? Or that's kind of the new run rate of the company going forward?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think with -- we were helped with -- if you look at that working capital, again, we define working capital as receivables plus inventory minus payables. It was driven all the way down to  8.6%. And I would tell you that our long-term goal is to red
componenttext: Yes. I think with -- we were helped with -- if you look at that working capital, again, we define working capital as receivables plus inventory minus payables. It was driven all the way down to  8.6%. And I would tell you that our long-term goal is to reduce that working capital as a percent of sales so that we could go from 10% to 11% at a long-term cash conversion from sales. And I would tell you that our working capital in that 8.6%. Our inventory is in great shape and our receivables are in very great shape. But I think our payables were favorably impacted by timing of some payments year-over-year. So I think that our payables, accounts payable, will be lower next year, which will raise the working capital or more near-term target of about 10% of sales. So I think the 13% as nice. And I think it was just because of the timing of the payments, I think you're going to see us going back in that 10%, 11% of sales in the future.

componenttext: Well, it was the architectural, Greg. componenttext: The nonresidential side did slow down in 2015 to 2014. And -- but what we feel though as an absolute number, it was still a good performance. Our relationship in this business, as we look at the large commercial contractors and how we're positioned there, we feel really good -- when the market, we'll grow well beyond the market trends will grow. You got a very good position here. We work hard on every aspect of product specifications, color and we expect to get, again, quite a bit of that share as we grow into 2016.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other issue to keep in mind in the non-res new site is that there's a long lag between starts and paints in that market. So starts were strong in 2014 and just down slightly in '15. So that bodes pretty well for painting on new nonresidential construc
componenttext: The other issue to keep in mind in the non-res new site is that there's a long lag between starts and paints in that market. So starts were strong in 2014 and just down slightly in '15. So that bodes pretty well for painting on new nonresidential construction in '16.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at residential repaint, we've been experiencing double-digit gains here for quite some time. We've got good momentum there. Good position in the commercial side and we expect, as Bob mentioned, that, that pipeline is going to work in our di
componenttext: So if you look at residential repaint, we've been experiencing double-digit gains here for quite some time. We've got good momentum there. Good position in the commercial side and we expect, as Bob mentioned, that, that pipeline is going to work in our direction.

componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Nils Wallin from CLSA.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I believe you said that paint volume in the Stores Group was greater than revenues -- revenue growth, that is. And so given your estimation of 3% or so of overall growth for the paint gallons, it suggests that you're probably taking share. Would you -- ho
componenttext: I believe you said that paint volume in the Stores Group was greater than revenues -- revenue growth, that is. And so given your estimation of 3% or so of overall growth for the paint gallons, it suggests that you're probably taking share. Would you -- how would you characterize those share gains? Are you actually seeing competitors close down? Or you're just -- or is it somehow that their growth is -- they're not opening stores as fast as you are? And then finally, are you actually seeing any distributors kind of leave the business? Independent distributors.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there are stores that close. And it really varies by market. It's a very fragmented market. We compete with local competitors. So each market is a bit different. And we often say inside our 4 walls that we don't discriminate by which -- or by where
componenttext: Well, there are stores that close. And it really varies by market. It's a very fragmented market. We compete with local competitors. So each market is a bit different. And we often say inside our 4 walls that we don't discriminate by which -- or by where we'll go our share. And so some of them will be larger competitors and some of them might be smaller. But our teams locally are focused on their customers that offer opportunity. And it may be, in any channel that they see those opportunities, that they're really focused on growing and we're winning. We're winning. We feel pretty good about the pace of which we're winning.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing I'd point out is what  we've commented on  over the last couple of years is we've done very well against national accounts since the recession as they consolidate supplier base. We are the only paint supplier that has a truly national foot
componenttext: The other thing I'd point out is what  we've commented on  over the last couple of years is we've done very well against national accounts since the recession as they consolidate supplier base. We are the only paint supplier that has a truly national footprint of contractor-friendly outlets. So that helped us a lot in that arena.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I'll tell you why. What happens with most of the raw materials. So 80-some percent of the raw materials we're purchasing down there are purchased in U.S. dollars. So when the raws go down mid-single-digit, I'll say, 5, and the currency fluctuates -- l
componenttext: No. I'll tell you why. What happens with most of the raw materials. So 80-some percent of the raw materials we're purchasing down there are purchased in U.S. dollars. So when the raws go down mid-single-digit, I'll say, 5, and the currency fluctuates -- loses 25% to 30%, such as in Brazil, your raws in a local basis are going to go up. So that's really is the big driver and here saying grow from one supplier to another.

componenttext: Much like we did with every past acquisition that we've done with every past acquisition. We've looked at the customer base. And the customer dictates to us the pace to which we move. So brand is the ultimate brand that we end up with. Some of these products end up a subbrand inside our Sherwin-Williams stores. We were able to leverage the advertising and the communications we had to promote the Sherwin-Williams brand once they become a Sherwin-Williams bannered stone. And so we move in that direction, but we move at a pace that we're able to get through the tunnel and sure that when we get to the other side that we have our customers with us.

But I think when you look at some of these areas, there's a reason why the currency continues to devalue. And I don't see Brazil being positive this year.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rosemarie. We often common to the pricing cycles in TiO2 typically begin with pricing below $1 a pound. Oftentimes peak about $2 a pound and then settle back on the back end of the cycle below $1 a pound again. We are hovering just above $1 a pound A
componenttext: Yes, Rosemarie. We often common to the pricing cycles in TiO2 typically begin with pricing below $1 a pound. Oftentimes peak about $2 a pound and then settle back on the back end of the cycle below $1 a pound again. We are hovering just above $1 a pound And we realize that there's been price increase announcements in the market. Ultimately, the balance of supply and demand in the market will determine whether those increases are successful, and we'll see. But if it feels like we are approaching the bottom on the downside of this cycle.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start in your question on the product It's an exciting new technology for us. It's a first EPA paint that kills 99% of the infection causing bacteria that has been exposed for 2 hours. And there's nothing like it in the market. Nothing. And s
componenttext: Well, let me start in your question on the product It's an exciting new technology for us. It's a first EPA paint that kills 99% of the infection causing bacteria that has been exposed for 2 hours. And there's nothing like it in the market. Nothing. And so we're excited about it. It actually lands and it begins to sell in our stores beginning February 1. So you're right. It is a little bit early. We just finished up our sales meetings with our teams, where we send them extensive trainings with our team on the product. And we're really looking forward to it. We did launch it last year and the feedback from the medical community has just been outstanding. And not just -- it's just terrific. We're really excited about it. So we're looking forward to a good year with that product.

componenttext: I'll just tell you right now, Dmitry. You're right. We don't break this out. We don't see dramatic difference between the fourth quarter and the other quarters in the year. componenttext: Yes. Because if you take away that fourth quarter, gross margin really came down to 2 things: gross margin and SG&A. And gross margin definitely had a larger impact in that SG&A. I think that when you think about the expenses that were admin expenses, those guys of expenses, we basically had a nice run rate for all the different systems and admin expenses for Comex.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. One final question just on the store -- new store growth. You keep guiding to sort of 100 stores a year or so. You came close in 2014 at about 95. You only did 83 this year. Sort of what's holding you back to getting you to that 100? Is it just fi
componenttext: Got it. One final question just on the store -- new store growth. You keep guiding to sort of 100 stores a year or so. You came close in 2014 at about 95. You only did 83 this year. Sort of what's holding you back to getting you to that 100? Is it just finding the right locations? Or is there some constraints on personnel? Or how should we think about your not exceeding 100 stores? If you do 100 stores as a yearly average?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it really does come down to a level of comfort that we have with the expansion and making sure that we have the human talents to be able to deliver on our promise. And so as we have these stores, incrementally important,  if you will, to have the ri
componenttext: Well, it really does come down to a level of comfort that we have with the expansion and making sure that we have the human talents to be able to deliver on our promise. And so as we have these stores, incrementally important,  if you will, to have the right people at the right level to be able to deliver on every brand comments that we make. And we just feel that 85 to 100 range is the right range. And you're going to see that fluctuate. Sometimes the system is in the timing of when they're going to hit. You might have a heavier first quarter, heavier fourth quarter. But that's a range that we just feel comfortable with.

componenttext: A real quick one. Are you taking though 1% or 2% of TiO2 out of the formulations per annum? Or are you sort of hit a technical limit with reduction?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that there was a lot of discussion about the formulations a couple of years ago and the reaction, the rapid rise backside. What we showed then that a lot of our formulas are for the paying contractor. And we know that 1% to 2% was put out the
componenttext: Yes. I think that there was a lot of discussion about the formulations a couple of years ago and the reaction, the rapid rise backside. What we showed then that a lot of our formulas are for the paying contractor. And we know that 1% to 2% was put out there by some of the competitors we had. And we said that we're pretty careful not to change the formulas of these workhorses and the product.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd like to make sure we're very clear on that. Our product to our customers, we describe it this way. Close enough for our customers. We have had the opportunity to formulate the robustness that might modify the amount of TiO2, but the quality of ou
componenttext: Yes. I'd like to make sure we're very clear on that. Our product to our customers, we describe it this way. Close enough for our customers. We have had the opportunity to formulate the robustness that might modify the amount of TiO2, but the quality of our product is something that we will never ever put at risk. I mean the customers that come to buy our products are expecting a consistent product. TiO2 is an important part of that, and the formulations  that we've been able to help maximize productivity by formulation is not as simply removing TiO2 and having product is going to perform differently.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We typically see the pressure on large bid projects, and that's typically been the same for as long as I've been in the industry for 31 years. While the average pricing might sit down slightly, the margins are not. So we work very hard to ensure that
componenttext: No. We typically see the pressure on large bid projects, and that's typically been the same for as long as I've been in the industry for 31 years. While the average pricing might sit down slightly, the margins are not. So we work very hard to ensure that we remain competitive on those large projects. It's a relatively small percentage of our total sales that -- they are good projects. They are -- oftentimes, they are important projects to us. And so we work to keep those projects sure win.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, cool. Okay. Second. I want to follow up on the raw materials. Your first question is that your projection are down mid-single digits seems conservative. And I know you talked about the TiO2. But propylene is down 50% -- more in a year or so. Can you
componenttext: Okay, cool. Okay. Second. I want to follow up on the raw materials. Your first question is that your projection are down mid-single digits seems conservative. And I know you talked about the TiO2. But propylene is down 50% -- more in a year or so. Can you talk about the basket of your inputs and maybe give us an idea of why it's only down to mid-single digits? If you understand [indiscernible]

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Richard, actually, a mid-single-digit decline is a pretty significant decline across the entire basket. We spent a lot of time talking about TiO2 and the latex and the resin side of the basket, which granted, is the lion's share of our raw material basket
componenttext: Richard, actually, a mid-single-digit decline is a pretty significant decline across the entire basket. We spent a lot of time talking about TiO2 and the latex and the resin side of the basket, which granted, is the lion's share of our raw material basket by value. But there are also categories of packaging and specialty chemicals that may be moving the opposite direction and offset the deflation in TiO2 and resins and latex to some degree. The other thing I'd caution you on is assuming that resin and latex pricing is tracking in line with propylene over crude oil, a lot of times, it's because specialty formulas, they're oftentimes owned and controlled by our supplier. That gives them some measure of pricing power in the short-term. The resin that you use in a particular paint formula has a very significant impact on the performance of the end product, and they're not interchangeable parts. So if the supplier wants to hold onto some of the benefit of lower cost propylene for a period of time, in the long run, we believe we'll get the benefit, but the benefit tends to come to the markets slower than in the commodity category like TiO2.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining the Sherwin-Williams Company's Review of Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Results and Expectations for 2016. With us on today's call are John Morikis, President and CEO; Sean Hennessy, CFO; Al Mistysyn, Vice President,
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining the Sherwin-Williams Company's Review of Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Results and Expectations for 2016. With us on today's call are John Morikis, President and CEO; Sean Hennessy, CFO; Al Mistysyn, Vice President, Corporate Controller; and Bob Wells, Senior Vice President, Corporate Communications. 
This conference call is being webcast simultaneously in listen-only mode by Issuer Direct via the Internet at www.sherwin.com. An archived replay of this webcast will be available at www.sherwin.com, beginning approximately 2 hours after this conference call concludes, and will be available until Wednesday, February 17 at 5:00 p.m. Eastern time.
This conference call will include forward-looking statements as defined under U.S. federal securities laws, with respect to sales, earnings and other matters. Any forward-looking statement speaks only as of the day on which such statement is made, and the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A full declaration regarding forward-looking statements is provided in the company's earnings release transmitted earlier this morning. After the company's prepared remarks, we will open the session to questions. I will now turn the call over to Bob Wells.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jesse. Good morning, everyone. In the interest of time, we've provided some balance sheet items and other select financial information on our website, www.sherwin.com, under Investor Relations, January 28 press release. Our consolidated sales in
componenttext:
Thanks, Jesse. Good morning, everyone. In the interest of time, we've provided some balance sheet items and other select financial information on our website, www.sherwin.com, under Investor Relations, January 28 press release. 
Our consolidated sales in the fourth quarter increased 1.4% to $2.6 billion, due entirely to higher paint sales volume through our Paint Stores and Consumer Group.
For the full year, sales increased 1.9% to $11.34 billion. Unfavorable currency translation decreased consolidated net sales 3.6% in the quarter and 3.3% for the full year. Consolidated gross profit in the fourth quarter increased $104.3 million to $1.3 billion and gross margin expanded to 50.8% of sales from 47.4% of sales in the fourth quarter 2014. 
For the year, gross margin increased to 49% of sales from 46.4% of sales last year. The increase in gross margin in the quarter and full year was due primarily to volume-driven supply chain productivity and lower year-over-year raw material cost. 
Selling, general and administrative expense increased $6.1 million to $991.5 million in the fourth quarter, but decreased as a percent of sales to 38.1% from 38.3% in the same quarter last year. 
For the full year 2015, SG&A expense increased $90.6 million to $3.91 billion, an increase as a percent of sales to 34.5% from 34.3% in 2014. Incremental SG&A to support the new HGTV HOME program at Lowe's and new store openings and sales territory addition accounted for the majority of the SG&A increase in the year. 
Other general expense decreased $12.6 million in the fourth quarter and $7.2 million for the year, due primarily to lower environmental expenses in both periods. 
Interest expense for the quarter increased $4.1 million to $19.5 million. For the year, interest expense was $61.8 million compared to $64.2 million in 2014. 
Profit before tax in the fourth quarter increased 57.4% to $297.2 million; and for the full year, increased 23.1% to $1.55 billion. 
Our effective income tax rate for the fourth quarter 2015 increased to 33.4% from 29.7% in the fourth quarter last year. For the year, our effective tax rate was 32% compared to 31.2% in 2014. 
Consolidated net income for the quarter increased $65.3 million to $198 million. For the year, net income increased $188 million to $1.05 billion. 
Net income as a percent of sales in the quarter increased to 7.6% from 5.2% last year. For the year, net income as a percent of sales increased to 9.3% from 7.8% in 2014. 
Diluted net income per common share in the fourth quarter 2015 increased to $2.12 from $1.37 per share in the fourth quarter of 2014. For the full year, diluted net income per common share increased 27.1% to $11.16 per share from $8.78 per share in 2014. 
Let me take a few minutes to break down our performance by segment. Sales for our Paint Stores Group in the fourth quarter 2015 increased 5.9% to $1.68 billion, thanks to higher architectural paint sales volume across all customer segments. 
For the year, net sales increased 5.2% to $7.21 billion. This full year sales increase was also driven by higher architectural paint sales volume across all customer segments. 
Comparable store sales increased 5.1% in the quarter and 4.2% in the year. Regionally, in the fourth quarter, our Midwest division led all divisions, followed by Eastern division, Southeastern division and Southwestern division. 
Fourth quarter segment profit for Paint Stores Group increased 27.8% to $316.1 million, due primarily to higher year-over-year paint sales volumes. 
For the full year, Paint Stores Group profit increased 19.3% to $1.43 billion from $1.2 billion in 2014. The increase in segment profit for the year resulted from higher paint sales volume that were partially offset by higher SG&A expenses. Segment profit margin for the fourth quarter increased to 18.9% from 15.6% last year. Profit margin for the full year 2015 increased to 19.9% from 17.5% in 2014. 
Turning now to Consumer Group. Fourth quarter external net sales increased 13.6% to $314.6 million. For the year, Consumer Group sales increased 11.1% to $1.58 billion. Most of the increase in sales for the fourth quarter and full year was from the HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams Paint Program at Lowe's. 
Segment profit for the fourth quarter increased 67.9% to $50.9 million from $30.3 million in the fourth quarter 2014. For the year, segment profit increased 22.1% to $308.8 million from $252.9 million in 2014. 
Consumer Group's segment profit as a percent of net sales in the fourth quarter increased to 16.2% from 11% last year. For the year, segment profit margin increased to 19.6% from 17.8% last year. Most of the improvement in both fourth quarter and full year segment profit margin was from volume-driven operating efficiency. 
For our Global Finishes Group, fourth quarter net sales in U.S. dollars decreased 9.5% to $454.8 million. And full year sales decreased 7.9% to $1.92 billion, due primarily to unfavorable currency translation. Currency translation decreased sales in U.S. dollars by 7.1% in the quarter and 7.5% in the year. 
Stated in U.S. dollars, Global Finishes Group segment profit in the fourth quarter increased to $50.6 million from $39 million last year. The increase in segment profit in the quarter resulted from good expense control and lower year-over-year raw material costs that were partially offset by unfavorable currency translation, which reduced segment profit $4.8 million. 
For the year, segment profit increased 0.4% to $201.9 million from $201.1 million last year. This full year profit improvement resulted from good expense control and lower raw material costs that were mostly offset by unfavorable currency translation of $26.5 million. 
As a percent of net sales, Global Finishes Group's operating profit was 11.1% in the fourth quarter compared to 7.8% last year and 10.5% for the year compared to 9.7% in 2014. 
For our Latin America Coatings Group. Net sales decreased 23.5% to $158.7 million in the fourth quarter and decreased 18.2% to $631 million for the full year, due primarily to unfavorable currency translation and lower volume sales, partially offset by higher year-over-year selling prices. Currency translation decreased sales in U.S. dollars by 21.4% in the quarter and 19.3% in the year. 
Stated in U.S. dollars, Latin America Coatings Group's segment profit in the quarter decreased to $2.8 million from $13 million last year. For the year, segment profit decreased to $18.5 million from $40.5 million in 2014. The decline in segment profit in both quarter and year was primarily due to unfavorable currency translation and lower volume sales, partially offset by selling price increases. 
Unfavorable currency translation decreased segment profit $5.3 million in the quarter and $16 million in the full year. 
As a percent of net sales, segment operating profit was 1.8% in the fourth quarter, compared to 6.3% last year and 2.9% for the year compared to  5.2% in 2014. 
That concludes review of our operating results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. So let me turn the call over to John Morikis, who will make some general comments and highlight our expectations for 2016. John?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. As we announced last October, on January 1 of this year, I assumed the duties of Chief Executive Officer. Back in 1971, British rock band, The Who, recorded the now famous lyric, meet the new b
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. 
As we announced last October, on January 1 of this year, I assumed the duties of Chief Executive Officer. Back in 1971, British rock band, The Who, recorded the now famous lyric, meet the new boss, same as the old boss. In our case, the same may not hold true literally in every respect, but it is certainly true when it comes to our mutual confidence in the company's strategy, our focus on growing market share through superior products and execution, our adherence to key performance metrics like return on net assets employed and net operating cash to sales and our shareholder-friendly capital allocation. These are the things that will define the value of Sherwin-Williams in the years ahead. And I believe, they are all moving in the right direction. 
2015 was a year of ups and downs. Our full year revenue of $11.3 billion set a new record for the company, but fell well short of our original expectations. One reason for this was stronger currency headwinds than originally anticipated. Another was the weaker-than-expected demand for industrial coatings in certain categories, particularly those used to maintain oil and gas production and storage assets. And in the middle 2 quarters of 2015, we broke our long-standing practice of not giving weather reports on earnings calls as heavy rainfall across much of the country clearly affected paint demand. This lower-than-expected revenue performance, however, did not translate to lower-than-expected profit or cash flow. 
Our full year profit before tax, net income, earnings per share and net operating cash all met or exceeded the expectations we set back in January 2015. Net income eclipsed $1 billion in 2015 for the first time in our company's history. This strong profitability  and cash generation was largely due to the successful and accelerated integration of the Comex stores and consolidation of Comex manufacturing assets, coupled with volume-driven sales -- supply chain productivity in North America, good SG&A expense control and raw material cost tailwinds. 
Looking ahead, we expect the year-over-year incremental margin benefit from the Comex integration to diminish as we go through 2016. Architectural paint sales through our paint stores picked up momentum in the fourth quarter, but was again offset to some degree by negative volumes in protective and marine coatings. 
Sales to residential repaint contractors continue to grow at double-digit pace. Sales volumes to the new construction markets and DIY customers also increased compared to last year, but at a slower pace than residential repaint. 
In total, Paint Stores Group grew fourth quarter revenues by just under 6%, with architectural paint volume growth outpacing revenues. 
In the fourth quarter, we opened 38 net new stores, bringing our full year store opening total to 83 new location. And our total store count at year-end to 4,086 stores in the U.S., Canada and the Caribbean. We remain confident that our next milestone of 5,000 locations in North America is realistic, and we intend to get closer to that goal by 90 to 100 stores this year. 
Consumer Group also turned in a solid performance for the year. The launch of the HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams Paint Program at Lowe's was one reason. But we also saw strong sales growth from another valued home center partner, Menards. As a result, Consumer Group's business grew by low single-digit percentage phase in the fourth quarter. 
Market and economic conditions outside North America continue to be very challenging. Sales volumes in most Latin American countries fluctuated modestly compared to fourth quarter 2014. And with the exception of Brazil where volumes and revenues declined significantly. The impact of currency devaluation, once again, was worse-than-anticipated in the quarter. 
Global Finishes Group also felt a brunt of softening environment coatings demand and deteriorating currencies in both Europe and Latin America, but made progress in offsetting these effects through tight SG&A control.
In 2015, we generated record net operating cash of $1.45 billion, thanks in part to the terrific working capital management by all of our operating segments. Inspite of the incremental working capital required to support the HGTV HOME Program at Lowe's, our working capital ratio at year-end dropped to 8.6% of sales from 10.1% last year. 
Free cash flow, which is net operating cash less CapEx and dividends, was $963.5 million compared to $665.7 million last year. We used this cash from operations to fund capital expenditures, increase our dividend and buyback shares for treasury. 
Our capital expenditures in 2015 totaled $234 million. Depreciation for the year was $170 million, and amortization was $28 million. 
In 2016, we anticipate capital expenditures of approximately $240 million, depreciation of $185 million to $200 million and amortization of about $30 million. 
Capital spending will run higher-than-normal in 2016, as we complete some facility renovation projects. 
In 2015, we returned more than $1.28 billion in cash to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. 
In the fourth quarter, we acquired 1 million shares of the company's stock for treasury, bringing our full year to 3.575 million shares at an average cost of $278.57 per share and a total investment of just over $1 billion. At year-end, we have remaining authorization to acquire 11.65 million shares. 
We paid $249.6 million in cash to shareholders through quarterly dividend. 2015 marked our 37th consecutive year of increased dividends per share, a string we intend to continue. This year, at our February meeting of the Board of Directors, we'll recommend approval of an annual dividend of $3.36 per share, an increase of more than 25% over 2015. 
Looking ahead to 2016. The demand for paint and coatings in most domestic markets looks encouraging. Growth in residential starts and existing home turnover was solid throughout 2015. And the Outlook for 2016 is equally encouraging. Although contracts for new nonresidential projects dipped slightly in 2015, it was still a strong year in absolute terms, which bodes well for paint demand in this segment. 
Outside the U.S., it appears likely that sluggish market conditions and currency devaluation, particularly in Europe and many Latin American countries, will remain a challenge. 
Our raw material basket has many moving parts but in total, we believe, we're likely to see lower year-over-year input cost in 2016. The continuing fall in the price of crude oil will no doubt have a positive impact on the petrochemical side on the raw materials basket. But these commodities will not necessarily move in linear relationship with crude. The price of high-grade chloride TiO2 continued to slide over the back half of 2015 due to weak global demand and overcapacity, but is likely nearing a bottom. Based on these factors, we would expect average year-over-year raw material costs for the paint and coatings industry to be down in the mid-single-digit range in 2016. 
Our outlook for first quarter 2016 is for consolidated net sales to increase in the low-single-digit percentage range compared to last year's first quarter. With sales at that level, we estimate diluted net income per common share in the first quarter will be in the range of $1.50 to $1.65 per share compared to the $1.38 per share earned in the first quarter of 2015. 
For the full year 2016, we expect net sales will increase in the low-single-digit percentage range compared to full year 2015. With annual sales at that level, we estimate diluted net income for our common share for 2015 (sic) [ 2016 ] will be in the range of $12.20 to $12.40 compared to $11.16 in 2015. 
Again, I would like to thank you for sharing -- for being with us this morning, and now we'd like to -- be happy to open up for questions.

componenttext: If you look at the -- this is Sean Hennessy. And so I'll take the first -- the second part first. I think that the non-paint sales performed fairly well. headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Great. And just one last one before I turn it over. With the spring selling season quickly approaching, can you talk about some of the lessons learned at Lowe's in 2015? And if any strategy shift or anything different you guys are going to do in 2015?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think there is a strategy shift at all. I think lessons learned include the importance of being very responsive, obviously, to our customers. Really working well with the associates in the aisles and helping them to be successful and knowledgeable
componenttext: I don't think there is a strategy shift at all. I think lessons learned include the importance of being very responsive, obviously, to our customers. Really working well with the associates in the aisles and helping them to be successful and knowledgeable in our product. So I think we've got a very good strategy there. I think we've got a very good relationship there. And I think we're working very hard to be the best customer there as we do with all of our customers.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Question for Sean just on gross margin. Just when we think it can't get any better, it does, particularly in the fourth quarter. So I'm wondering how much of that was volume-driven? Was there any true up against your standard cost because raws turned
componenttext: Yes. Question for Sean just on gross margin. Just when we think it can't get any better, it does, particularly in the fourth quarter. So I'm wondering how much of that was volume-driven? Was there any true up against your standard cost because raws turned out to be lower than you originally thought when you made the estimate on standard costing? And what's kind of your outlook for next year? I mean, if you end the year at a 50.8% gross margin, that's going to signal a pretty strong performance as we get into the paint season this year.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, if you take a look at that 340 basis points, approximately half of that was due to the paint volume increases through our North America supply chain. That's really the #1 thing that drove it. That also includes the integration of that Comex busi
componenttext: Yes, Dan, if you take a look at that 340 basis points, approximately half of that was due to the paint volume increases through our North America supply chain. That's really the #1 thing that drove it. That also includes the integration of that Comex business. That has been a nice piece of that. And also got to remember the mix because of the foreign currency exchange. As U.S. becomes bigger and bigger piece of that -- of our total sales, Paint Stores Group does have the highest gross margin. So that helped on the other piece. Now having said that, LIFO is always trying to catch what you think is  going to happen with the raws and the way the raws came in, there was a slight help from the LIFO. LIFO did help us, especially in the Consumer Group but also a little bit in the Stores Group. If you take a look about the long term, in the long term, I think we try to give you guidance what we think of the long term. We think that probably our long term, when you look at the make-up of the company and where we are going, it's in the mid-47s to the mid-49s. I think that -- again, when that foreign currency changes around, and instead of being at 80% U.S. and North American sales, you're going to start seeing that come down and back down into the 70%, that will have the reverse impact on the gross margins. So when we feel like we're running at a normal area, we think we're going to be in the 47.5% to 49.5% gross margins.

componenttext: And John, you have just under 4,100 stores today, and you said 5,000 is the target. Is that a saturation point for you in terms of number of stores? And when do you think you might get there?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me be clear. 5,000 is not our target. It's a milestone. And I often say that it's -- I refer to it because it's between 4 and our next number is 6. And so we're going to stop at 5 on the way. We don't see a saturation point. We've continued to add sto
componenttext: Let me be clear. 5,000 is not our target. It's a milestone. And I often say that it's -- I refer to it because it's between 4 and our next number is 6. And so we're going to stop at 5 on the way. We don't see a saturation point. We've continued to add stores. Each of our district managers maintain a real estate strategy and plan to continue to invest in their stores. And there's not one of them that have raised their hand and say that they really see no addition -- additional markets that they can add to. So it's our expectation that we're going to continue to invest in those markets and continue to penetrate the opportunities in those markets, and we're excited about that.
