componenttext: We're, obviously, looking at the West Coast. We shared with the community here that we look at households per paint store, and we see a terrific opportunity in the West area of the country. And again, we remain very confident in this model. It's  this model and our ability to grow market share and to, in fact, grow our operating leverage as we grow that incremental volume that gives us that confidence.

componenttext: Question. There's a number of ways just to triangulate it. So is there something in the back 3 quarters where there's a little bit of a step down that we should take into account? Or is that just a good case of conservatism?

componenttext: No, I think when you look at it the way you just guided us to, I think the first quarter -- I just want to remind you, in Consumer Group, because of the HGTV expenses, if you remember, the gross -- the SG&A expenses, we had a jump in the first quarter we pointed out last year that that was going to be -- we had 100% SG&A, 0 sales. So I think that this year, we're going to have relatively close to the same amount of SG&A but some sales going against it. So I think that helped us. So I think if you look over 2 years, I think the first quarter would look more normal to you and would probably look more like the other 3 quarters we have in the guidance.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm kind of curious what your appetite was for spending money down in South America opportunistically, given what's going on down there?  Or maybe there is a little greater fear about forging ahead more aggressively, what are your thoughts on [indiscernib
componenttext: I'm kind of curious what your appetite was for spending money down in South America opportunistically, given what's going on down there?  Or maybe there is a little greater fear about forging ahead more aggressively, what are your thoughts on [indiscernible]?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that there's a little difference everywhere. I think that 2 years ago, we were really nervous about putting money down in Argentina. And you think about the exchange rate now at 13x. You look at Chile now, they've changed their government out. And
componenttext: I think that there's a little difference everywhere. I think that 2 years ago, we were really nervous about putting money down in Argentina. And you think about the exchange rate now at 13x. You look at Chile now, they've changed their government out. And I think -- so we feel okay investing in Chile. We're probably -- long term, we still feel good about Brazil. But we're watching both of those governments and seeing what happens with some of the policies down there. We -- if the right opportunity would appear, we would actually buy it. I think that we still are looking at the long term. But I think on the marginal investments, we've been very careful on what we're going to spend down there. And when I say marginal, I'm not talking about distribution or manufacturing or marketing. I think more on the admin side, systems side, those kinds of sides. How much working capital will allow it to grow and so forth. So we're watching it. We feel good about that. We're still cash positive in each and every country. And that really helps us stay the course. But we think, eventually, it might be a while. It was interesting, we were going through what we went through in the late '80s and early '90s when we actually had to do inflationary accounting in South America, which I haven't looked at some of the rules. They've been so long. So we take a look at this spot and we're watching these things. But we're being careful in the margin.

componenttext: Okay, we don't break it out by region. But I could say, directionally, as you would expect the oil and gas market there has experienced the pressure that one would expect. Our acquisition of the brand that came along with Comex, General Paint, is -- we're in the process of integrating that in, and we're really excited about the momentum that we're gaining up there. So on the architectural side, we're continuing to grow. The protective and marine side, we continue to see some pressure.

componenttext: Yes. If you just take a look at the guidance we gave at the beginning of 2015, about a year ago, we gave you $0.20, $10.90 to $11.10. I think we've changed this span many, many times. But I think that we feel confident that we're able to with -- whether it happens, adjust the different things, and we think that we're going to be able to get that kind of improvement.

componenttext: Yes, we do. Just think about how the Brazilian reai, even the Canadian dollar we were talking about before. We definitely have a foreign currency. But I think that to give you some indication, that tells you where we think the growth is going to be.

componenttext: But we do see, to your point, as you have protective and marine, we do expect that, that pressure is going to continue for the foreseeable future.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as a follow-up. On the raw side, obviously, some decline incremental in 3Q and 4Q. If I go through the math, I guess, you expect that to continue to be a benefit in 2016. Is there any reason why we shouldn't expect a nice benefit on th
componenttext: Okay. And then just as a follow-up. On the raw side, obviously, some decline incremental in 3Q and 4Q. If I go through the math, I guess, you expect that to continue to be a benefit in 2016. Is there any reason why we shouldn't expect a nice benefit on the raw side? And maybe, you can just elaborate on the oil-based versus TiO2.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun, this is Bob. We do expect to continue to see benefit from raw materials. And we've commented that on the oil side, it does take longer for a drop in propylene and ethylene to work its way through the acrylic chain and actually get to market. So
componenttext: Yes, Arun, this is Bob. We do expect to continue to see benefit from raw materials. And we've commented that on the oil side, it does take longer for a drop in propylene and ethylene to work its way through the acrylic chain and actually get to market. So there is probably more tailwind on that side of the basket in the year to come than there is on the TiO2 side. TiO2 took a pretty sharp drop in the back half of last year. We'll see that -- obviously, the benefit of that in the first half of this year. But TiO2 is approaching kind of its historic starting place of $100 a pound on the spot market. So we don't necessarily see a lot of further runway for TiO2 to decline.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one more, if I may, just on the share buyback side. What are you guys expecting to do in '16?
componenttext: And then just one more, if I may, just on the share buyback side. What are you guys expecting to do in '16?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I  think that we've been pretty consistent with our cash utilization. I think that we feel pretty good about the cash generation at the company. I think we've been consistently generating cash and strong cash over the last 15 or so years. And I'm goi
componenttext: Yes. I  think that we've been pretty consistent with our cash utilization. I think that we feel pretty good about the cash generation at the company. I think we've been consistently generating cash and strong cash over the last 15 or so years. And I'm going back to when we took -- we were put into these jobs. I think you're going to see us continue to invest in the business and CapEx and new stores and so forth. I think that we're going to pay out dividends. You heard the dividend going over $3.30. And then, we're going to look at acquisitions and we're going to look at buying back stock. And I would tell you, I'd be surprised if we were holding cash at the end of next year.

componenttext: Sure. Just give me one second here. Paint Stores Group was up $97.8 million in the quarter; Consumer Group, $27.5 million; Global Finishes Group was down $4.8 million; and Latin America was down $15.1 million.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then, just wanted to dig in a few brief questions. In terms of Global Finishes, so what do you attribute like the sudden step up in profitability? Obviously, GM is going to help a little bit. But what kind of what major improvements did y
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then, just wanted to dig in a few brief questions. In terms of Global Finishes, so what do you attribute like the sudden step up in profitability? Obviously, GM is going to help a little bit. But what kind of what major improvements did you put in the cost side? And how sustainable is that the next several quarters?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Because when you look at the Global Finishes Group in the fourth quarter, it was up 29%. It was -- the operating profit was really driven by SG&A expense control and favorable raw material costs, which more than offset the negative currency because
componenttext: Right. Because when you look at the Global Finishes Group in the fourth quarter, it was up 29%. It was -- the operating profit was really driven by SG&A expense control and favorable raw material costs, which more than offset the negative currency because they had to go against currency also. And I would tell you, we feel pretty good about this -- the SG&A savings that we have. And I'll tell you, years ago, when this Global Finishes Group was operating at 3%, 3.5%, after we bought the Becker, Sayerlack and the Inchem acquisitions, we said that eventually that we felt we could run it at 12%. And so we think we're at a pretty good spot. We think in the future, a lot of that improvement has come from those efficiencies that we were going to get. And I think that the future is going to be driven by market share gains and sales gains.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The team there has done a really nice job of streamlining the non-customer-facing functions. And we give that team a lot of credit for continuing to focus on that.
componenttext: Yes. The team there has done a really nice job of streamlining the non-customer-facing functions. And we give that team a lot of credit for continuing to focus on that.

componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just one quick one. You called out Menards as one potential reason for strength in the consumer segment. Was there something going on there in terms of a new program launch or a new [indiscernible] like, what kind of drove that strength?

componenttext: Well, we had a very good relationship with a very good customer there. And so we're continuing to focus our efforts there. As I mentioned earlier, we want to be the best supplier to each of our customers. And so we've really just tried to listen to a very good customer, be responsive and help them grow. And that's our game plan.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to better understand the planning assumptions for 2016. You guys posted 27% earnings growth last year. And over the past 4 years, it's been about 20% to 25% on average. And this year, you're guiding 10%. Just like the fact that you'd continu
componenttext: I just wanted to better understand the planning assumptions for 2016. You guys posted 27% earnings growth last year. And over the past 4 years, it's been about 20% to 25% on average. And this year, you're guiding 10%. Just like the fact that you'd continue to feel good about the architectural paint market and raw materials tailwinds. So I guess there's an offset from Comex not being as accretive. But what else is in the budget that we should consider that should contribute to lower earnings growth this year?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that the FX headwinds were, I would say, be at a little more -- I don't like to say -- our estimate is a little stronger than it  was going into last year. I think that Comex was a really strong one. And I think you heard Bob's comments about raw
componenttext: I think that the FX headwinds were, I would say, be at a little more -- I don't like to say -- our estimate is a little stronger than it  was going into last year. I think that Comex was a really strong one. And I think you heard Bob's comments about raw materials. Even though they're going to be a nice tailwind, I don't see the tailwind being as strong in 2016 as it was in 2015.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And are you guys done on Comex? I thought the, previously Comex, you had a multiyear runway. So kind of what inning are you in with that integration?
componenttext: And are you guys done on Comex? I thought the, previously Comex, you had a multiyear runway. So kind of what inning are you in with that integration?

componenttextpreview: I would say we're in inning 8, I think that -- the bottom of the eighth, and the home seems winning big. So I think we're going to see -- yes, we were able to accelerate it.
componenttext: I would say we're in inning 8, I think that -- the bottom of the eighth, and the home seems winning big. So I think we're going to see -- yes, we were able to accelerate it.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do said [ph] that we are continuing to invest in the store transitions over to Sherwin's. So to Sean's point, largely on the supply chain side, I think that team did a terrific job, and we've fairly moved some of that up from what we have expected to s
componenttext: We do said [ph] that we are continuing to invest in the store transitions over to Sherwin's. So to Sean's point, largely on the supply chain side, I think that team did a terrific job, and we've fairly moved some of that up from what we have expected to see in 2016 into 2015. And we were successful also on the store side. But there's still some work to do on the store side, and that's what we are working on here as we roll into 2016.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, very helpful. And just one last one for you, Sean. The capital conversion to sales that you guys have kind of talked to and that may continue community [ph] about it right around 13% this year. Is that -- is there something unusual? Or that's kind
componenttext: Great, very helpful. And just one last one for you, Sean. The capital conversion to sales that you guys have kind of talked to and that may continue community [ph] about it right around 13% this year. Is that -- is there something unusual? Or that's kind of the new run rate of the company going forward?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think with -- we were helped with -- if you look at that working capital -- again, we define working capital as receivables plus inventory minus payables. It was driven all the way down to  8.6%. And I would tell you that our long-term goals have b
componenttext: Yes, I think with -- we were helped with -- if you look at that working capital -- again, we define working capital as receivables plus inventory minus payables. It was driven all the way down to  8.6%. And I would tell you that our long-term goals have been to reduce that working capital as a percent of sales sold that we could go from 10% to 11% and the long-term cash conversion from sales. And I would tell you that our working capital in that 8.6%, our inventory is in great shape and our receivables were in great shape. But I think our payables were favorably impacted by timing of some payments year-over-year. So I think that our payables, accounts payable, will be lower next year, which will raise the working capital back up into the our more near-term target of about 10% of sales. So I think the 13% is nice, and I think it was -- just because of the timing of the payments, I think you're going to see us going back in that 10%, 11% of sales in the future.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then really what I wanted to ask how the business. componenttext: Well, it was largely the architectural, Greg. And if you look at what we're seeing there, it's clearly, an improvement, third quarter over fourth quarter, and we continue to be excited and encouraged by the comments that we're hearing from many of our customers. Our homebuilders that saw a more mild weather, which enable them to catch up on some of the lost workdays that were previously an issue. first just a momentum there that we're working hard to make sure that we capture more than our share.

componenttext: The nonresidential side did slow down in 2015 to 2014. But we -- what we feel though is an absolute number. It was still a good performance. Our relationship in this business, as we look at the large commercial contractors and how we're positioned there, we feel really good that with the market, we'll grow well beyond what the market trends will grow. You got a very good position here. We work hard on every aspect from product specifications, color and we expect to get, again, quite a bit of that share as we grow into 2016.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other issue to keep in mind on the non-res new side is that there is a long lag between starts and paints in that market. So starts were strong in 2014 and just down slightly in '15, so that bodes pretty well for painting on new nonresidential constru
componenttext: The other issue to keep in mind on the non-res new side is that there is a long lag between starts and paints in that market. So starts were strong in 2014 and just down slightly in '15, so that bodes pretty well for painting on new nonresidential construction in '16.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at our residential repaint, we've been experiencing double-digit gains here for quite some time. We've got good momentum there, good position in the commercial side. And we expect, as Bob mentioned, that, that pipeline is going to work in o
componenttext: So if you look at our residential repaint, we've been experiencing double-digit gains here for quite some time. We've got good momentum there, good position in the commercial side. And we expect, as Bob mentioned, that, that pipeline is going to work in our direction.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Nils Wallin from CLSA.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I believe you said that paint volume in the Stores Group was greater than the revenues -- and revenue growth that is. And so given your estimation of 3%-or-so overall growth of the paint gallons, it suggests that you're probably taking share. Would you --
componenttext: I believe you said that paint volume in the Stores Group was greater than the revenues -- and revenue growth that is. And so given your estimation of 3%-or-so overall growth of the paint gallons, it suggests that you're probably taking share. Would you -- how would you characterize those share gains? Are you actually seeing competitors close down? Or you just -- or is it somehow that their growth is -- they're not opening stores as fast as you are? And then finally, are you actually seeing any distributors kind of leave the business, independent distributors?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there are stores that close, and it really varies by market. It's a very fragmented market. We compete with local competitors. So each market is a bit different. And we often say inside our 4 walls that we don't discriminate by which where -- or by
componenttext: Well, there are stores that close, and it really varies by market. It's a very fragmented market. We compete with local competitors. So each market is a bit different. And we often say inside our 4 walls that we don't discriminate by which where -- or by where we'll grow our share. And so some of them will be larger competitors and some of them might be smaller. But our teams locally are focused on their customers that offer opportunity. And it may be in any channel that they see those opportunities, but they're really focused on growing, and we're winning. We're winning. We feel pretty good about the pace at which we're winning.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing I'd point out, we've commented on  over the last couple of years is we've done very well in the national accounts since the recession. As they've consolidate supplier base, we are the only paint supplier that has a truly national footprint
componenttext: The other thing I'd point out, we've commented on  over the last couple of years is we've done very well in the national accounts since the recession. As they've consolidate supplier base, we are the only paint supplier that has a truly national footprint of contractor-friendly outlets. So that helped us a lot in that arena.

componenttext: Got it. And then where are you in terms of your capacity to supply the market? Do you anticipate you'll need to expand capacity in the next 2 or 3 years or it's maybe 5 years out?

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that when we take a look at the capacity, I think our manufacturing footprint has been expanded each and every year from efficiency. If we take a look at our capacity utilization, we're in nice shape. We went through a nice growth here. We di
componenttext: Yes, I think that when we take a look at the capacity, I think our manufacturing footprint has been expanded each and every year from efficiency. If we take a look at our capacity utilization, we're in nice shape. We went through a nice growth here. We did an integration of Comex. We might see down the road 5 years where we might have to do some type of major expansion at a plant. But in the short term here, we don't have a game plan to open a new plant.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Now the teams are doing a really nice job, as Sean mentioned, and some of those investments might be on a filling line or something like that. But we've got a team that's got a mindset of continuous improvement, and they're working hard to capture additional capacity.

componenttext: Got it, and then just one final one. I know that you cited all year some of the raw material headwinds in your Latin American coatings group. Is there any opportunity to change sourcings that you don't have an issue [ph] going forward?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, and I'll tell you why. What happens with most of the raw materials, so 80-some percent of the raw materials we're purchasing down there are purchased in U.S. dollars. So when the raws go down mid-single-digit, I'll say, 5; and the currency fluctuates
componenttext: No, and I'll tell you why. What happens with most of the raw materials, so 80-some percent of the raw materials we're purchasing down there are purchased in U.S. dollars. So when the raws go down mid-single-digit, I'll say, 5; and the currency fluctuates -- loses 25% to 30% such as in Brazil. Your raws in a local basis are going to -- are going to go up. So that's really is the big driver, and that [indiscernible] here saying so you go from one supplier to another.

componenttext: Well, much like we did with every past acquisition, that we've done with every past acquisition, we look at the customer base and the customer dictates to us the pace in which we move. The Sherwin-Williams brand is the ultimate brand that we end up with. Some of these products end up a sub-brand inside our Sherwin-Williams stores. We are able to leverage the advertising and the communications that we had that promote the Sherwin-Williams brand, once they become a Sherwin-Williams-bannered store. And so we move in that direction, but we move at a pace that we're able to get through the tunnel and sure that when we get to the other side that we have our customers with us.

componenttext: No, I think you hit on them. I think that the basic business is, again, we're watching it. We have not -- I will not forecast that Brazil is going to be a robust economy next year. I don't think Argentina will be. I think we'll see what happens in Chile. Mexico seems we're doing fine. But I think, when you look at some of these areas, there's a reason why the currency continues to devalue. And I don't see Brazil being positive this year.

componenttext: Okay. And on the TiO2, the producers have been announcing several price increases. They all seem to be getting their act together. Are you guys kicking it or you are -- it is part of your comments about the fact that now it is the bottom, the bottom meaning a low floor or a beginning of price increases on the TiO2?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rosemarie. We often comment that these pricing cycles in TiO2 typically begin with pricing below $1 a pound, oftentimes peak above $2 a pound and then settle back on the back end of the cycle below $1 a pound again. We are hovering just above $1 a po
componenttext: Yes, Rosemarie. We often comment that these pricing cycles in TiO2 typically begin with pricing below $1 a pound, oftentimes peak above $2 a pound and then settle back on the back end of the cycle below $1 a pound again. We are hovering just above $1 a pound. And we realize that there's been price increase announcements in the market. Ultimately, the balance of supply and demand in the market will determine whether those increases are successful, and we'll see. But it feels like we are approaching the bottom on the downside of this cycle.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: I think it's too early. It really depends on demand growth. Demand growth outside in North America has been very weak.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start in your question on our product paint shield. It's an exciting new technology for us. It's a first EPA-registered paint that kills 99% of these five specific infection-causing bacteria that has been exposed for 2 hours. And there's noth
componenttext: Well, let me start in your question on our product paint shield. It's an exciting new technology for us. It's a first EPA-registered paint that kills 99% of these five specific infection-causing bacteria that has been exposed for 2 hours. And there's nothing like it in the market, nothing. And so we're excited about it. It actually lands and begins to sell in our stores, beginning February 1. So you're right. It is a little bit early. We've just finished up our sales meetings with our team, where we've send them extensive with our team on the product, and we're really looking forward to it. We did launch it last year, and the feedback from the medical community has just been outstanding, not just -- it's just terrific. We're really excited about it. So we're looking forward to a good year with that product.

componenttext: So -- and I know you don't guide on a segment basis, but when you go through that, it sounds like if one normal weather and one normal labor that -- I guess -- and again, your guidance wouldn't seem to imply that we're not going to '08s or '09s in the Stores Group. componenttext: Just a couple of clarifications on the fourth quarter just to make sure I understand the direction that the business is going. It sounded like in Latin America, you saw a little bit faster volume declines. I mean, you complained about volume declines being down offset by higher pricing for few quarters, but it looks like it was sort of way down in the fourth quarter. Is that sort of the pace that we should expect to see there in 2016, in other words, kind of a mid-single-digit decline in organic growth of volume plus price?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll just tell you right now, Dmitry, and you're right, we don't break this out. We don't see that dramatic of a difference between the fourth quarter and the other quarters in the year. By country, it's now different things go back and forth. I woul
componenttext: Yes. I'll just tell you right now, Dmitry, and you're right, we don't break this out. We don't see that dramatic of a difference between the fourth quarter and the other quarters in the year. By country, it's now different things go back and forth. I would say it was the dramatic change in the Brazilian reais and some of these things that hit us harder than what we thought they were going to be in the fourth quarter. And when you sit there and take a look at that, we just -- we got to get some price back to the comments about where we are. So I think things are -- when you sit down and look at that gallon number and the sales number. I think it had more to do with FX than it did in the business.

componenttext: Yes, because if you take away that fourth quarter, gross margin would really came down to 2 things: gross margin and SG&A, and gross margin definitely had a larger impact in that SG&A. componenttext: Got it. One final question just on the store -- new store growth. You keep guiding to sort of 100 stores a year or so. You came close in 2014 at about 95. You only did 83 this year. Sort of what's holding you back from getting to that 100? Is it just finding the right locations? Or is there some constraints on personnel? Or sort of how we should think about -- yours not exceeding 100 stores? If you do 100 stores as a yearly average?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it really does come down to a level of comfort that we have with the expansion and making sure that we have the human talent to be able to deliver on our promise. And so as we have these stores, it's incrementally important,  if you will, to have th
componenttext: Well, it really does come down to a level of comfort that we have with the expansion and making sure that we have the human talent to be able to deliver on our promise. And so as we have these stores, it's incrementally important,  if you will, to have the right people at the right level to be able to deliver on every brand promise that we's make. And we just feel that, that 85 to 100 range is the right range. And you're going to see that fluctuate sometimes to ship and the timing of when they're going to hit. You might have a heavier first quarter or heavier fourth quarter, but that's the range that we do feel comfortable with.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A real quick one. Are you still taking 1% of 2% of TiO2 out of the formulations per annum? Or have you sort of hit a technical limit with reductions?
componenttext: A real quick one. Are you still taking 1% of 2% of TiO2 out of the formulations per annum? Or have you sort of hit a technical limit with reductions?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that there was a lot of discussion about the formulations a couple of years ago and the reactions, the rapid rise, and thanks to be backside [ph]. But we said then that a lot of our formulas are for the paying contractor. And we know that 1%
componenttext: Yes, I think that there was a lot of discussion about the formulations a couple of years ago and the reactions, the rapid rise, and thanks to be backside [ph]. But we said then that a lot of our formulas are for the paying contractor. And we know that 1% to 2% was put out by some of the competitors we had. And we said that we're pretty careful not to change the formulas of these workhorses and the products.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd like to make sure we're very clear on that. Our product to our customers, we describe it this way that closer and closer enough for our customers. So we have had the opportunity to formulate the robustness that might modify the amount of TiO2, bu
componenttext: Yes. I'd like to make sure we're very clear on that. Our product to our customers, we describe it this way that closer and closer enough for our customers. So we have had the opportunity to formulate the robustness that might modify the amount of TiO2, but the quality of our product is something that we will never ever put at risk. I mean, the customers that come to buy our products are expecting a consistent product. TiO2 is an important part of that. And the formulations  that we've been able to help maximize the productivity by formulation is not at the cost of just simply removing TiO2 and having product that's going to perform differently.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the decline of raw materials at single digits last year, presumably you're competitors also benefited from that. Have you sort of feeling any competitive pressures from your customers to pass along some of those savings?
componenttext: With the decline of raw materials at single digits last year, presumably you're competitors also benefited from that. Have you sort of feeling any competitive pressures from your customers to pass along some of those savings?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we typically see the pressure on large-bid projects, and that's typically been the same for as long as -- I've been in the industry for 31 years, and while the average pricing might sit down slightly, the margins are not. And so we work very hard to e
componenttext: No, we typically see the pressure on large-bid projects, and that's typically been the same for as long as -- I've been in the industry for 31 years, and while the average pricing might sit down slightly, the margins are not. And so we work very hard to ensure that we remain competitive on those large projects. It's a relatively small percentage of our total sales, but they are good projects. They are -- oftentimes, they are important projects to us. And so we work to keep those projects sure win.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, cool. Okay. Second, I want to follow up on the raw material, and your first question is that: Your projection are down mid-single digits seems conservative. And I know you talked about the TiO2. But propylene is down 50% more in a year or so. Can yo
componenttext: Okay, cool. Okay. Second, I want to follow up on the raw material, and your first question is that: Your projection are down mid-single digits seems conservative. And I know you talked about the TiO2. But propylene is down 50% more in a year or so. Can you talk about the basket of your inputs and maybe give us an idea of why it's only down to mid-single digits? Did you understand?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Richard, actually, a mid-single-digit decline is a pretty significant decline across the entire basket. We spent a lot of time talking about TiO2 and the latex and the resin side of the basket, which granted is the lion's share of our raw material ba
componenttext: Yes. Richard, actually, a mid-single-digit decline is a pretty significant decline across the entire basket. We spent a lot of time talking about TiO2 and the latex and the resin side of the basket, which granted is the lion's share of our raw material basket by value, but there are also categories of packaging in specialty chemicals that may be moving the opposite direction and offset the deflation in TiO2 and resins and latex to some degree. The other thing I'd caution you on is, assuming that resin and latex pricing is tracking in line with propylene over crude oil, a lot of times, because these are specialty formulas, they're oftentimes owned and controlled by our supplier, that gives them some measure of pricing power in the short term. The resin that you use in a particular paint formula has a very significant impact on the performance of the end product, and they're not interchangeable parts. So if the supplier wants to hold on to some of the benefit of lower-cost propylene for a period of time, in the long run, we believe we'll get the benefit, but the benefit tends to come to the market slower than in a commodity category like TiO2.

componenttext: Thanks, again, Jesse. I'll conclude the call this morning by asking you to save the date of Thursday, May 26, on your calendars. That's the day we'll host our Annual Financial Community presentation at our headquarters in Cleveland. The program will consist of our customary morning presentations by management, with a Q&A session, followed by reception and launch, and there will also be special program options offered in the afternoon to help commemorate our 150-year history. Again, that date is Thursday, May 26, and we'll be sending out invitation and related information and a link to our registration website in late March. So please watch your email. As usual, I'll be available over the balance of the day and the coming days to answer any remaining questions. Thanks for joining us today, and thank you for your continued interest in Sherwin-Williams.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining the Sherwin-Williams Company's Review of Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Results and Expectations for 2016. With us on today's call are John Morikis, President and CEO; Sean Hennessy, CFO; Al Mistysyn, Vice President,
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining the Sherwin-Williams Company's Review of Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Results and Expectations for 2016. With us on today's call are John Morikis, President and CEO; Sean Hennessy, CFO; Al Mistysyn, Vice President, Corporate Controller; and Bob Wells, Senior Vice President, Corporate Communications. 
This conference call is being webcast simultaneously in listen-only mode by Issuer Direct via the Internet at www.sherwin.com. An archived replay of this webcast will be available at www.sherwin.com, beginning approximately 2 hours after this conference call concludes, and will be available until Wednesday, February 17 at 5:00 p.m. Eastern time.
This conference call will include certain forward-looking statements as defined under U.S. federal securities laws with respect to sales, earnings and other matters. Any forward-looking statement speaks only as of the day on which such statement is made, and the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A full declaration regarding forward-looking statements is provided in the company's earnings release transmitted earlier this morning. After the company's prepared remarks, we will open the session to questions. I will now turn the call over to Bob Wells.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jesse. Good morning, everyone. In the interest of time, we've provided some balance sheet items and other select financial information on our website, www.sherwin.com, under Investor Relations, January 28 press release. Our consolidated sales in
componenttext:
Thanks, Jesse. Good morning, everyone. In the interest of time, we've provided some balance sheet items and other select financial information on our website, www.sherwin.com, under Investor Relations, January 28 press release. 
Our consolidated sales in the fourth quarter increased 1.4% to $2.6 billion, due entirely to higher paint sales volume through our Paint Stores and Consumer Groups.
For the full year, sales increased 1.9% to $11.34 billion. Unfavorable currency translation decreased consolidated net sales 3.6% in the quarter and 3.3% for the full year. Consolidated gross profit in the fourth quarter increased $104.3 million to $1.3 billion and gross margin expanded to 50.8% of sales from 47.4% of sales in the fourth quarter 2014. 
For the year, gross margin increased to 49% of sales from 46.4% of sales last year. The increase in gross margin in the quarter and full year was due primarily to volume-driven supply chain productivity and lower year-over-year raw material costs. 
Selling, general and administrative expense increased $6.1 million to $991.5 million in the fourth quarter, but decreased as a percent of sales to 38.1% from 38.3% in the same quarter last year. 
For the full year 2015, SG&A expense increased $90.6 million to $3.91 billion, an increase as a percent of sales to 34.5% from 34.3% in 2014. Incremental SG&A to support the new HGTV HOME program at Lowe's and new store openings and sales territory additions accounted for the majority of the SG&A increase in the year. 
Other general expense decreased $12.6 million in the fourth quarter and $7.2 million for the year, due primarily to lower environmental expenses in both periods. 
Interest expense for the quarter increased $4.1 million to $19.5 million. For the year, interest expense was $61.8 million compared to $64.2 million in 2014. 
Profit before tax in the fourth quarter increased 57.4% to $297.2 million; and for the full year, increased 23.1% to $1.55 billion. 
Our effective income tax rate for the fourth quarter 2015 increased to 33.4% from 29.7% in the fourth quarter last year. For the year, our effective tax rate was 32% compared to 31.2% in 2014. 
Consolidated net income for the quarter increased $65.3 million to $198 million. For the year, net income increased $188 million to $1.05 billion. 
Net income as a percent of sales in the quarter increased to 7.6% from 5.2% last year. For the year, net income as a percent of sales increased to 9.3% from 7.8% in 2014. 
Diluted net income per common share in the fourth quarter 2015 increased to $2.12 from $1.37 per share in the fourth quarter of 2014. For the full year, diluted net income per common share increased 27.1% to $11.16 per share from $8.78 per share in 2014. 
Let me take a few minutes to break down our performance by segment. Sales for our Paint Stores Group in the fourth quarter 2015 increased 5.9% to $1.68 billion, thanks to higher architectural paint sales volumes across all customer segments. 
For the year, net sales increased 5.2% to $7.21 billion. This full year sales increase was also driven by higher architectural paint sales volumes across all customer segments. 
Comparable store sales increased 5.1% in the quarter and 4.2% in the year. Regionally, in the fourth quarter, our Midwest division led all divisions, followed by Eastern division, Southeastern division and Southwestern division. 
Fourth quarter segment profit for Paint Stores Group increased 27.8% to $316.1 million, due primarily to higher year-over-year paint sales volumes. 
For the full year, Paint Stores Group profit increased 19.3% to $1.43 billion from $1.2 billion in 2014. The increase in segment profit for the year resulted from higher paint sales volumes that were partially offset by higher SG&A expenses. Segment profit margin for the fourth quarter increased to 18.9% from 15.6% last year. Profit margin for the full year 2015 increased to 19.9% from 17.5% in 2014. 
Turning now to Consumer Group. Fourth quarter external net sales increased 13.6% to $314.6 million. For the year, Consumer Group sales increased 11.1% to $1.58 billion. Most of the increase in sales for the fourth quarter and full year was from the HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams paint program at Lowe's. 
Segment profit for the fourth quarter increased 67.9% to $50.9 million from $30.3 million in the fourth quarter 2014. For the year, segment profit increased 22.1% to $308.8 million from $252.9 million in 2014. 
Consumer Group's segment profit as a percent of net sales in the fourth quarter increased to 16.2% from 11% last year. For the year, segment profit margin increased to 19.6% from 17.8% last year. Most of the improvement in both fourth quarter and full year segment profit margin was from volume-driven operating efficiencies. 
For our Global Finishes Group, fourth quarter net sales in U.S. dollars decreased 9.5% to $454.8 million. And full year sales decreased 7.9% to $1.92 billion, due primarily to unfavorable currency translation. Currency translation decreased sales in U.S. dollars by 7.1% in the quarter and 7.5% in the year. 
Stated in U.S. dollars, Global Finishes Group segment profit in the fourth quarter increased to $50.6 million from $39 million last year. The increase in segment profit in the quarter resulted from good expense control and lower year-over-year raw material costs that were partially offset by unfavorable currency translation, which reduced segment profit $4.8 million. 
For the year, segment profit increased 0.4% to $201.9 million from $201.1 million last year. This full year profit improvement resulted from good expense control and lower raw material costs that were mostly offset by unfavorable currency translation of $26.5 million. 
As a percent of net sales, Global Finishes Group's operating profit was 11.1% in the fourth quarter compared to 7.8% last year and 10.5% for the year compared to 9.7% in 2014. 
For our Latin America Coatings Group. Net sales decreased 23.5% to $158.7 million in the fourth quarter and decreased 18.2% to $631 million for the full year, due primarily to unfavorable currency translation and lower volume sales, partially offset by higher year-over-year selling prices. Currency translation decreased sales in U.S. dollars by 21.4% in the quarter and 19.3% in the year. 
Stated in U.S. dollars, Latin America Coatings Group's segment profit in the quarter decreased to $2.8 million from $13 million last year. For the year, segment profit decreased to $18.5 million from $40.5 million in 2014. The decline in segment profit in both quarter and year was primarily due to unfavorable currency translation and lower volume sales, partially offset by selling price increases. 
Unfavorable currency translation decreased segment profit $5.3 million in the quarter and $16 million in the full year. 
As a percent of net sales, segment operating profit was 1.8% in the fourth quarter compared to 6.3% last year, and 2.9% for the year compared to 5.2% in 2014. 
That concludes review of our operating results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. So let me turn the call over to John Morikis, who will make some general comments and highlight our expectations for 2016. John?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. As we announced last October, on January 1 of this year, I assumed the duties of Chief Executive Officer. Back in 1971, British rock band, The Who, recorded the now famous lyric, "Meet the new
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. 
As we announced last October, on January 1 of this year, I assumed the duties of Chief Executive Officer. Back in 1971, British rock band, The Who, recorded the now famous lyric, "Meet the new boss, same as the old boss." In our case, the saying may not hold true literally in every respect, but it is certainly true when it comes to our mutual confidence in the company's strategy, our focus on growing market share through superior products and execution, our adherence to key performance metrics like return on net assets employed and net operating cash to sales and our shareholder-friendly capital allocation. These are the things that will define the value of Sherwin-Williams in the years ahead. And I believe, they are all moving in the right direction. 
2015 was a year of ups and downs. Our full year revenue of $11.3 billion set a new record for the company, but fell well short of our original expectations. One reason for this was stronger currency headwinds than originally anticipated. Another was the weaker-than-expected demand for industrial coatings in certain categories, particularly those used to maintain oil and gas production and storage assets. And in the middle 2 quarters of 2015, we broke our long-standing practice of not giving weather reports on earnings calls as heavy rainfall across much of the country clearly affected paint demand. This lower-than-expected revenue performance, however, did not translate to lower-than-expected profit or cash flow. 
Our full year profit before tax, net income, earnings per share and net operating cash all met or exceeded the expectations we set back in January 2015. Net income eclipsed $1 billion in 2015 for the first time in our company's history. This strong profitability and cash generation was largely due to the successful and accelerated integration of the Comex stores and consolidation of Comex manufacturing assets, coupled with volume-driven sales -- supply chain productivity in North America, good SG&A expense control and raw material cost tailwinds. 
Looking ahead, we expect the year-over-year incremental margin benefit from the Comex integration to diminish as we go through 2016. Architectural paint sales through our paint stores picked up momentum in the fourth quarter, but was again offset to some degree by negative volumes in protective and marine coatings. 
Sales to residential repaint contractors continue to grow at double-digit paces. Sales volumes to the new construction markets and DIY customers also increased compared to last year, but at a slower pace than residential repaint. 
In total, Paint Stores Group grew fourth quarter revenues by just under 6%, with architectural paint volume growth outpacing revenues. 
In the fourth quarter, we opened 38 net new stores, bringing our full year store opening total to 83 new locations and our total store count at year-end to 4,086 stores in the U.S., Canada and the Caribbean. We remain confident that our next milestone of 5,000 locations in North America is realistic, and we intend to get closer to that goal by 90 to 100 stores this year. 
Consumer Group also turned in a solid performance for the year. The launch of the HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams paint program at Lowe's was one reason. But we also saw strong sales growth from another valued home center partner, Menards. As a result, Consumer Group's business grew by a low single-digit percentage pace in the fourth quarter. 
Market and economic conditions outside North America continue to be very challenging. Sales volumes in most Latin American countries fluctuated modestly compared to fourth quarter 2014 and with the exception of Brazil, where volumes and revenues declined significantly. The impact of currency devaluation, once again, was worse-than-anticipated in the quarter. 
Global Finishes Group also felt the brunt of softening environment coatings demand and deteriorating currencies in both Europe and Latin America, but made progress in offsetting these effects through tight SG&A control.
In 2015, we generated record net operating cash of $1.45 billion, thanks in part to the terrific working capital management by all of our operating segments. In spite of the incremental working capital required to support the HGTV HOME Program at Lowe's, our working capital ratio at year-end dropped to 8.6% of sales from 10.1% last year. 
Free cash flow, which is net operating cash less CapEx and dividends, was $963.5 million compared to $665.7 million last year. We used this cash from operations to fund capital expenditures, increase our dividend and buy back shares for treasury. 
Our capital expenditures in 2015 totaled $234 million. Depreciation for the year was $170 million, and amortization was $28 million. 
In 2016, we anticipate capital expenditures of approximately $240 million, depreciation of $185 million to $200 million and amortization of about $30 million. 
Capital spending will run higher than normal in 2016, as we complete some facility renovation projects. 
In 2015, we returned more than $1.28 billion in cash to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. 
In the fourth quarter, we acquired 1 million shares of the company's stock for treasury, bringing our full year to 3.575 million shares at an average cost of $278.57 per share and a total investment of just over $1 billion. At year-end, we have remaining authorization to acquire 11.65 million shares. 
We paid $249.6 million in cash to shareholders through quarterly dividends. 2015 marked our 37th consecutive year of increased dividends per share, a string we intend to continue. This year, at our February meeting of the Board of Directors, we'll recommend approval of an annual dividend of $3.36 per share, an increase of more than 25% over 2015. 
Looking ahead to 2016. The demand for paint and coatings in most domestic markets looks encouraging. Growth in residential starts and existing home turnover was solid throughout 2015. And the outlook for 2016 is equally encouraging. Although contracts for new nonresidential projects dipped slightly in 2015, it was still a strong year in absolute terms, which bodes well for paint demand in the segment. 
Outside the U.S., it appears likely that sluggish market conditions and currency devaluation, particularly in Europe and many Latin American countries, will remain a challenge. 
Our raw material basket has many moving parts but, in total, we believe we're likely to see lower year-over-year input cost in 2016. The continuing fall in the price of crude oil will no doubt have a positive impact on the petrochemical side of the raw materials basket. But these commodities will not necessarily move in linear relationship with crude. The price of high-grade chloride TiO2 continued to slide over the back half of 2015 due to weak global demand and overcapacity, but is likely nearing a bottom. Based on these factors, we would expect average year-over-year raw material costs for the paint and coatings industry to be down in the mid-single-digit range in 2016. 
Our outlook for first quarter 2016 is for consolidated net sales to increase in the low-single-digit percentage range compared to last year's first quarter. With sales at that level, we estimate diluted net income per common share in the first quarter will be in the range of $1.50 to $1.65 per share compared to the $1.38 per share earned in the first quarter of 2015. 
For the full year 2016, we expect net sales will increase in the low-single-digit percentage range compared to full year 2015. With annual sales at that level, we estimate diluted net income for our common share for 2015 (sic) [ 2016 ] will be in the range of $12.20 to $12.40 compared to $11.16 in 2015. 
Again, I would like to thank you for sharing -- for being with us this morning, and now we'd like to -- be happy to open up for questions.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I think one of the big hits on that Who album was, Won't Get Fooled Again. On that note, what is your thinking about raw materials given the volatility in oil? Is your guidance assuming, relatively conservatively, not much benefit here? Is it going
componenttext: John, I think one of the big hits on that Who album was, Won't Get Fooled Again. On that note, what is your thinking about raw materials given the volatility in oil? Is your guidance assuming, relatively conservatively, not much benefit here? Is it going to take some time for oil to work its way down the supply chain?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Bob. We think that there could be some benefit in the petrochemicals side of the basket, maybe as much as we saw in 2015. We think that -- we saw a pretty big move in TiO2 in '15, and we're unlikely to see that big a move in '16. So mid-sing
componenttext: John, this is Bob. We think that there could be some benefit in the petrochemicals side of the basket, maybe as much as we saw in 2015. We think that -- we saw a pretty big move in TiO2 in '15, and we're unlikely to see that big a move in '16. So mid-single digits, I think, is a reasonable outlook for the industry. And well, as we usually do, we'll update that as we go through the year.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then it's 83 store openings per year for the Paint Store segment. The right rate, you're kind of a steady state there?
componenttext: And then it's 83 store openings per year for the Paint Store segment. The right rate, you're kind of a steady state there?

componenttext: Yes. I think that's about average for us. We'll adjust that as we go. But yes, I think that's about where we want to run.

componenttext: This is actually Mehul Dalia sitting in for Ghansham. First off, 4Q same-store sales was a nice acceleration versus 2Q and 3Q. So I just wanted to know what changed? And how did the nonarchitectural piece outperform on a relative basis compared to the previous 2 quarters?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you look at the -- this is Sean Hennessy. And so I'll take the first -- the second part first. I think that the non-paint sales performed fairly well. I think that consistently throughout the year, we had a nice year in the non-paint sales, but they ac
componenttext: If you look at the -- this is Sean Hennessy. And so I'll take the first -- the second part first. I think that the non-paint sales performed fairly well. I think that consistently throughout the year, we had a nice year in the non-paint sales, but they accelerated also. I think that Paint Stores Group had a very nice quarter. And as John said, we don't usually talk about weather, but maybe weather helped us a little bit. But I think that's what -- when you look at the second and third quarter versus the fourth quarter, we did use weather in the second and third quarter. I think you see parts of that.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Also what would you estimate the industry grew in the U.S. from a paint job perspective in 2015 and what are your expectations for 2016?
componenttext: Got it. Also what would you estimate the industry grew in the U.S. from a paint job perspective in 2015 and what are your expectations for 2016?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mehul, it's Bob. We have very few data sources to go to, to help us with estimates of industry volume. The American Coatings Association models industry volume over the course of the year. They currently stand at an estimate of 5.5% growth for 2015.
componenttext: Yes, Mehul, it's Bob. We have very few data sources to go to, to help us with estimates of industry volume. The American Coatings Association models industry volume over the course of the year. They currently stand at an estimate of 5.5% growth for 2015. We think they're a little high. We are thinking more in the 3% to 3.5% range. But as we collect more data, year-end data, we'll kind of fine tune that outlook. But I think it's likely the industry is going to end up in the 3% to 3.5% range.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your expectation for 2016 is similar, 3% to 3.5%?
componenttext: And your expectation for 2016 is similar, 3% to 3.5%?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It could be a little stronger than that. It depends on the weather patterns relative to last year. But that's not a bad range.
componenttext: It could be a little stronger than that. It depends on the weather patterns relative to last year. But that's not a bad range.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just one last one before I turn it over. With the spring selling season quickly approaching, can you talk about some of the lessons learned at Lowe's in 2015? And if any strategy shift or anything different you guys are going to do in 2016?
componenttext: Great. And just one last one before I turn it over. With the spring selling season quickly approaching, can you talk about some of the lessons learned at Lowe's in 2015? And if any strategy shift or anything different you guys are going to do in 2016?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think there is a strategy shift at all. I think lessons learned include the importance of being very responsive, obviously, to our customers. Really working well with the associates in the aisles and helping them to be successful and knowledgeable
componenttext: I don't think there is a strategy shift at all. I think lessons learned include the importance of being very responsive, obviously, to our customers. Really working well with the associates in the aisles and helping them to be successful and knowledgeable in our product. So I think we've got a very good strategy there. I think we've got a very good relationship there. And I think we're working very hard to be the best customer there as we do with all of our customers.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Don Carson with Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Don Carson with Susquehanna Financial.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Question for Sean just on gross margin. Just when we think it can't get any better, it does, particularly in the fourth quarter. So I'm wondering how much of that was volume-driven? Was there any sort of true-up against your standard cost because raw
componenttext: Yes. Question for Sean just on gross margin. Just when we think it can't get any better, it does, particularly in the fourth quarter. So I'm wondering how much of that was volume-driven? Was there any sort of true-up against your standard cost because raws turned out to be lower than you originally thought when you made the estimate on standard costing? And what's kind of your outlook for next year? I mean, if you end the year on a 50.8% gross margin, that's going to signal a pretty strong performance as we get into the paint season this year.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Don, if you take a look at that 340 basis points, approximately half of that was due to the paint volume increases through our North America supply chain. That's really the #1 thing that drove it. That also includes the integration of that Comex busi
componenttext: Yes, Don, if you take a look at that 340 basis points, approximately half of that was due to the paint volume increases through our North America supply chain. That's really the #1 thing that drove it. That also includes the integration of that Comex business. That has been a nice piece of that. And also got to remember the mix because of the foreign currency exchange. As U.S. becomes bigger and bigger piece of that -- of our total sales, Paint Stores Group does have the highest gross margin. So that helped on the other piece. Now having said that, LIFO is always trying to catch what you think is  going to happen with the raws and the way the raws came in. There was a slight help from the LIFO. LIFO did help us, especially in the Consumer Group, but also a little bit in the Stores Group. If you take a look about the long term, in the long term, I think we try to give you guidance what we think of the long term. We think that probably our long term, when you look at the make-up of the company and where we are going, it's in the mid-47s to the mid-49s. I think that -- again, when that foreign currency changes around, and instead of being at 80% U.S. and North American sales, you're going to start seeing that come down and back down into the 70s, that will have the reverse impact on the gross margins. So when we feel like we're running at a normal area, we think we're going to be in the 47.5% to 49.5% gross margins.

componenttext: Well, as I mentioned, I think we're working closely with all levels of Lowe's, and we're feeling good about the momentum, as I mentioned. So I think it's a matter of execution now. headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, you have just under 4,100 stores today, and you said 5,000 is the target. Is that a saturation point for you in terms of number of stores? And when do you think you might get there?
componenttext: And John, you have just under 4,100 stores today, and you said 5,000 is the target. Is that a saturation point for you in terms of number of stores? And when do you think you might get there?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me be clear. 5,000 is not our target. It's a milestone. And I often say that it's -- I refer to it because it's between 4 and our next number is 6. And so we're going to stop at 5 on the way. We don't see a saturation point. We've continued to add sto
componenttext: Let me be clear. 5,000 is not our target. It's a milestone. And I often say that it's -- I refer to it because it's between 4 and our next number is 6. And so we're going to stop at 5 on the way. We don't see a saturation point. We've continued to add stores. Each of our district managers maintain a real estate strategy and a plan to continue to invest in their stores. And there's not one of them that have raised their hand and say that they really see no addition -- additional markets that they can add to. So it's our expectation that we're going to continue to invest in those markets and continue to penetrate the opportunities in those markets, and we're excited about that.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: And is there a particular area where you want to add stores?

componenttext: We're, obviously, looking at the West Coast. We shared with the community here that we look at households per paint store, and we see a terrific opportunity in the West area of the country. And again, we remain very confident in this model. It's  this model and our ability to grow market share and to, in fact, grow our operating leverage as we grow that incremental volume that gives us that confidence.

componenttext: Question. There's a number of ways just to triangulate it. But if you look at the Q4 you delivered and then the Q1 that you've guided to, just take the midpoint, and then extrapolate that through '16, there's a disconnect between how good those quarters were and kind of where the midpoint is for '16. So is there something in the back 3 quarters where there's a little bit of a step down that we should take into account? Or is that just a good case of conservatism?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think when you look at it the way you just guided us to, I think the first quarter -- I just want to remind you, in Consumer Group, because of the HGTV expenses, if you remember, the gross -- the SG&A expenses, we had a jump in the first quarter we
componenttext: No, I think when you look at it the way you just guided us to, I think the first quarter -- I just want to remind you, in Consumer Group, because of the HGTV expenses, if you remember, the gross -- the SG&A expenses, we had a jump in the first quarter we pointed out last year that, that was going to be -- we had 100% SG&A, 0 sales. So I think that this year, we're going to have relatively close to the same amount of SG&A but some sales going against it. So I think that helped us. So I think if you look over 2 years, I think the first quarter would look more normal to you and would probably look more like the other 3 quarters we have in the guidance.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Great. And then one of the issues in '15, was -- it seems like your customers were running up against their bandwidth as far as just the number of painters they could employ. Is your sense that they've been able to expand their paint force and therefore, the opportunity for more sales is bigger this year in the U.S?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's improved to some degree. It's hard to put your fingers exactly on that. But I'd say that in the market, I think it's gotten a little bit better.
componenttext: Well, I think that's improved to some degree. It's hard to put your fingers exactly on that. But I'd say that in the market, I think it's gotten a little bit better.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm kind of curious what your appetite was for spending money down in South America opportunistically, given what's going on down there?  Or maybe there is a little greater fear about forging ahead more aggressively, what are your thoughts on [indiscernib
componenttext: I'm kind of curious what your appetite was for spending money down in South America opportunistically, given what's going on down there?  Or maybe there is a little greater fear about forging ahead more aggressively, what are your thoughts on [indiscernible]?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that there's a little difference everywhere. I think that 2 years ago, we were really nervous about putting money down in Argentina. And you think about the exchange rate now at 13x. You look at Chile now, they've changed their government out. And
componenttext: I think that there's a little difference everywhere. I think that 2 years ago, we were really nervous about putting money down in Argentina. And you think about the exchange rate now at 13x. You look at Chile now, they've changed their government out. And I think -- so we feel okay investing in Chile. We're probably -- long term, we still feel good about Brazil. But we're watching both of those governments and seeing what happens with some of the policies down there. We -- if the right opportunity would appear, we would actually buy it. I think that we still are looking at the long term. But I think on the marginal investments, we've been very careful on what we're going to spend down there. And when I say marginal, I'm not talking about distribution or manufacturing or marketing. I think more on the admin side, systems side, those kinds of sides. How much working capital will allow it to grow and so forth. So we're watching it. We feel good about that. We're still cash positive in each and every country. And that really helps us stay the course. But we think, eventually, it might be a while. It was interesting, we were going through what we went through in the late '80s and early '90s when we actually had to do inflationary accounting in South America, which I haven't looked at some of the rules. It's been so long. So we take a look at this spot and we're watching these things. But we're being careful on the margins.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay, we don't break it out by region. But I could say, directionally, as you would expect, the oil and gas market there has experienced the pressure that one would expect. We are growing in the market. Our acquisition of the brand that came along with Comex, General Paint, is -- we're in the process of integrating that in, and we're really excited about the momentum that we're gaining up there. So on the architectural side, we're continuing to grow. The protective and marine side, we continue to see some pressure.

componenttext: I've got a few quick ones. Starting with the fourth quarter, you beat the consensus estimate by about $0.18. componenttext: Yes. If you just take a look at the guidance we gave at the beginning of 2015, about a year ago, we gave you $0.20, $10.90 to $11.10. I think we've changed this span many, many times. Back in '09, we gave you a guidance range of $1. I think that there's been a lot of moving parts. But I think that we feel confident that we're able to with -- whether it happens, adjust the different things, and we think that we're going to be able to get that kind of improvement.

componenttext: Yes. I think that when we take a look at the full year, it was about 32.1%. I think that it's going to be approximately right around that number to maybe outside say, if it comes in at 31.5% to 32.5%, I wouldn't be surprised.

componenttext: Yes, we do. Just think about how the Brazilian reai, even the Canadian dollar we were talking about before. We definitely have a foreign currency. Looks like you're guiding to low single digits for the full company. Do you expect more of the same, i.e. weakness in protective and marine and outperformance in architectural?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will tell you that when we look at our guidance, I think the fourth quarter is pretty interesting. Total, we were at 1.4% of sales gain; Stores Group was 5.9%. So 4x what we thought that we were going to be at. So I think that currency, other things, I
componenttext: I will tell you that when we look at our guidance, I think the fourth quarter is pretty interesting. Total, we were at 1.4% of sales gain; Stores Group was 5.9%. So 4x what we thought that we were going to be at. So I think that currency, other things, I think that we don't break out our guidance by segment. But I think that to give you some indication, that tells you where we think the growth is going to be.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: But we do see, to your point, as you have protective and marine, we do expect that, that pressure is going to continue for the foreseeable future.
componenttext: But we do see, to your point, as you have protective and marine, we do expect that, that pressure is going to continue for the foreseeable future.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as a follow-up. On the raw side, obviously, some decline incremental in 3Q and 4Q. If I go through the math, I guess, you expect that to continue to be a benefit in 2016. Is there any reason why we shouldn't expect a nice benefit on th
componenttext: Okay. And then just as a follow-up. On the raw side, obviously, some decline incremental in 3Q and 4Q. If I go through the math, I guess, you expect that to continue to be a benefit in 2016. Is there any reason why we shouldn't expect a nice benefit on the raw side? And maybe, you can just elaborate on the oil-based versus TiO2.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun, this is Bob. We do expect to continue to see benefit from raw materials. And we've commented that on the oil side, it does take longer for a drop in propylene and ethylene to work its way through the acrylic chain and actually get to market. So
componenttext: Yes, Arun, this is Bob. We do expect to continue to see benefit from raw materials. And we've commented that on the oil side, it does take longer for a drop in propylene and ethylene to work its way through the acrylic chain and actually get to market. So there is probably more tailwind on that side of the basket in the year to come than there is on the TiO2 side. TiO2 took a pretty sharp drop in the back half of last year. We'll see that -- obviously, the benefit of that in the first half of this year. But TiO2 is approaching kind of its historic starting place of under $1 a pound on the spot market. So we don't necessarily see a lot of further runway for TiO2 to decline.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one more, if I may, just on the share buyback side. What are you guys expecting to do in '16?
componenttext: And then just one more, if I may, just on the share buyback side. What are you guys expecting to do in '16?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that we've been pretty consistent with our cash utilization. I think that we feel pretty good about the cash generation at the company. I think we've been consistently generating cash and strong cash over the last 15 or so years. And I'm goin
componenttext: Yes. I think that we've been pretty consistent with our cash utilization. I think that we feel pretty good about the cash generation at the company. I think we've been consistently generating cash and strong cash over the last 15 or so years. And I'm going back to when we took -- we were put into these jobs. I think you're going to see us continue to invest in the business and CapEx and new stores and so forth. I think that we're going to pay out dividends. You heard the dividend going over $3.30. And then, we're going to look at acquisitions and we're going to look at buying back stock. And I would tell you, I'd be surprised if we were holding cash at the end of next year.
