componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to longer-term, answer question is trying to understand, of course, gross margin policy up nice in the quarter and gross margins have been coming up quite a bit. Obviously, raw material cost is something to do with that. But do you guys l
componenttext: So I just wanted to longer-term, answer question is trying to understand, of course, gross margin policy up nice in the quarter and gross margins have been coming up quite a bit. Obviously, raw material cost is something to do with that. But do you guys looking kind of normalize gross margins. What are your thoughts about that? Can we still see things come up here? And I just wanted to get your thoughts on that.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that a way we run our business, we believe that in the long-term, we're going to continue to raise their ROS. I think that the gross margin, we've had great expansion. We've had basically because of 3 things. I mean, really nice gallon growth
componenttext: Yes, I think that a way we run our business, we believe that in the long-term, we're going to continue to raise their ROS. I think that the gross margin, we've had great expansion. We've had basically because of 3 things. I mean, really nice gallon growth, especially in storage group. And integration of that is complete now from the Comex North America and raw materials have been a tailwind. But those things have occurred. I think that in all cases, we're always with a long-term. I like your term, really looking in the long term. And again, this year, we're taking a balanced approach to where we're going. We're investing. There's times when the gross margin lead our ROS improvements. And there's times that SG&A and back to that gallon growth that we've had in that stores group is because of innovation. I think that we continue to do a lot of innovation and innovation has helped us in the all the different segments. So when you look at where we are going, this year, our mid-point of our range is $12.60. Last year, it was $11.13, a 13% increase. And during -- if you take a look at a challenging global environment, no share buybacks. Our original guidance at approximately $0.25 for the buybacks in there. So we're generating net operating cash at record levels and we're continuing to make prudent investments in the business. So you're going to see SG&A probably this year, it's going to be in the improvement in the are less it has to be in gross margin. And we had the tailwind. We fairly say there was going to the tailwind. We had the innovation and we have stores that are going away. But we're pretty confident that those investments principally intensive the future. And that's how we do this balanced approach for the long term that you asked.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate all the color. And just maybe switching gears just a little bit to capacity levels that you guys were seeing right now. And what are these -- where are they? And what would they look like if you successfully close the Valspar acquisition?
componenttext: Appreciate all the color. And just maybe switching gears just a little bit to capacity levels that you guys were seeing right now. And what are these -- where are they? And what would they look like if you successfully close the Valspar acquisition?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We always have said that we were 88% to 92%, that's the sweet spot for us. And 2008 and 2009, when the market to go down 25%, 30% in that 1 year, we managed it. We did not take all the capacity out to get down to that level. And that's where the earlier q
componenttext: We always have said that we were 88% to 92%, that's the sweet spot for us. And 2008 and 2009, when the market to go down 25%, 30% in that 1 year, we managed it. We did not take all the capacity out to get down to that level. And that's where the earlier question about the 8 20, we were shooting for that 7 50, 7 70. So that capacity, we lived with the capacity in the low 70%. We're now much closer to that 88% to 92% and that's why our margins are doing very well. Since then, that North America acquisition of, I think those gallons going into our footprint. But we've how want a couple of assets that they have, but when you look at the Valspar, the think that they have some great assets to give us our capacity. We think that gives us another leg in the store that to give us the ability to have of that capacity utilization go down in the short term. But that gives us the ability to grow without great deal of CapEx.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Just a dig in a little bit more on Consumer Group. You mentioned a couple of programs you were running at retail, but didn't get the traction that you are looking for. And you obviously had some increased spending against that. So what is, just sort of broadly or specifically, what's the course correction that you're looking to do? headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Well, I think what's important here is that there is some investments here and we see it as a clear opportunity. We do go into this with our eyes wide open. We know that there are investments made that may not come back in the first quarter that we make those investments, maybe not the second. But if you look at our market share in this segment, there's terrific opportunities. We believe a disciplined approach and aggressive approach here can help us to grow our market share and manage our margins for our shareholders. So we are moving in this direction with a very disciplined look. We are making the investments, and we think that there are opportunities out there for us to grow.

componenttext: Yes. And as far as the timing, as you mentioned, we're patient. We think it's -- but we don't see it snapping back in the next quarter or so.

componenttext: A question first just on your overall, the architectural market. Last year, it was obviously, I know you don't like to talk about weather, but it was weather in your press and growth was 2% to 3%. Are you seeing the snap back you expected this year? Or is that being moderated again by weather, Bob, what's kind of your outlook for the U.S. architectural market growth this year?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Don, I mean, for starters, we don't think there was much of weather effect on the numbers this year. We think that build rates are holding up very well, but they're not on fire. Residential construction is up about 10% year-over-year in square footag
componenttext: Yes, Don, I mean, for starters, we don't think there was much of weather effect on the numbers this year. We think that build rates are holding up very well, but they're not on fire. Residential construction is up about 10% year-over-year in square footage terms. In the commercial market, starts are down, but completions are up pretty significantly year-over-year. So we are seeing solid demand growth in the new construction markets. In their repaint markets, while in the pro residential repaint business has been really solid, we -- what's hard to determine at this stage because we just don't have the data is how the DIY channel held up in the second quarter. So I hesitate to say that this just not enough data to coal market growth in the second quarter yet. But I think that's the truth. The contractor market seems to have grow nicely but it's hard to tell on the other piece.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And John, a question maybe you can update us on the Valspar synergy outlook to the extent you've been able to talk to your counterparts over there and have meetings about combining the 2 company. What's your updated outlook for percentage potential
componenttext: Okay. And John, a question maybe you can update us on the Valspar synergy outlook to the extent you've been able to talk to your counterparts over there and have meetings about combining the 2 company. What's your updated outlook for percentage potential or what's your updated confidence level in the ratio target you set out?

componenttext: Right, I don't think we're going to move the original target. And -- but I think as time goes on, we continue to feel very confident that we're going to hit those numbers.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can give a little more detail on the solid margin performance you had in the Global Finishes Group. I know you mentioned the price of mix was improving. What exactly was driving that? And how sustainable could a number like 13% marg
componenttext: I was wondering if you can give a little more detail on the solid margin performance you had in the Global Finishes Group. I know you mentioned the price of mix was improving. What exactly was driving that? And how sustainable could a number like 13% margin be as we get into the second half in that segment?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that when we take a look at the -- at that group, I think that the improvement stems from really 4 focus, driving that product technology I mentioned earlier into the market, improving SG&A, capturing pricing in the -- where the offset currency an
componenttext: I think that when we take a look at the -- at that group, I think that the improvement stems from really 4 focus, driving that product technology I mentioned earlier into the market, improving SG&A, capturing pricing in the -- where the offset currency and then capture reductions in the raw materials that they occur in the United States. So these combination of 4 things, I don't think are going to change. You'll see -- so I'll -- for the longest time, we used to talk about 12%. And I think that this gives us great confidence that we can say 13%. And when some market share gains, I think we can actually beat that number. So I think the game plan has worked very, very well.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, great. And then a question on Latin America. It sounded like you mentioned that you expect to be below breakeven for the rest of the year. But just wondering as we get into the heavier paint season there in Q4, is there a chance that we get nor
componenttext: All right, great. And then a question on Latin America. It sounded like you mentioned that you expect to be below breakeven for the rest of the year. But just wondering as we get into the heavier paint season there in Q4, is there a chance that we get north of breakeven? And also wondering if there were some initial costs in Q2 that help explain a pretty significant sequential weakening in terms of the earnings in Latin America.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The answer to the last question is no. There really was no one-time the thing that I would point out. It's just like it was like the operation as it is. I think we've come closer to breakeven and maybe there's a chance that if we have a little stronger sa
componenttext: The answer to the last question is no. There really was no one-time the thing that I would point out. It's just like it was like the operation as it is. I think we've come closer to breakeven and maybe there's a chance that if we have a little stronger sales, the fourth quarter definitely is closest to breakeven for the remainder of the year. But right now, I would not come out here and say, hey, we're definitely going to make money in the fourth quarter.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions. One was a little accounting and charge clarification and then second on the business. Sean, the income tax benefit, could you explain what that actually is? And is it just simply straight as $0.09, $8 million is coming into taxes?
componenttext: I have 2 questions. One was a little accounting and charge clarification and then second on the business. Sean, the income tax benefit, could you explain what that actually is? And is it just simply straight as $0.09, $8 million is coming into taxes?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And what that is, is when we've expense -- when starting the new rules many, many years ago expensing stock option, our so grant and so forth, you charge the P&L for the Black Scholes amount. So whatever the Black Scholes value on the day of issuance
componenttext: Yes. And what that is, is when we've expense -- when starting the new rules many, many years ago expensing stock option, our so grant and so forth, you charge the P&L for the Black Scholes amount. So whatever the Black Scholes value on the day of issuance, basically, you straight line the, it was a 3-year or a 5-year option vesting period. When the -- then what would occur is if the stock, the differential between when the day of vesting, a differential in -- differential between Black Scholes value and the actual value was actually a -- that difference we used to go to retain earnings. We always took it on our tax return, and that was one of the differentials between book and cash taxes. So this change is a coming change for us has nothing to do and it won't change our cash performance. But instead of having that differential that for us, as you said in the second quarter, $8 million go to retained earnings and now goes directly through the P&L. So that's why it was $0.09 in the second quarter. Year-to-date, it was $0.28. And the reason why I was $0.19 in the first quarter is because of the, in the first quarter, it's when the vesting occurs of our long-term RSOs so that many people are on that. So that's why it hit the first quarter. Second quarter was really driven by stock options that were exercised. So that's what it is. It doesn't have at -- differential. That's why we pointed out. Laid out at it this quarter so we can do it, they coning this way. I think as time goes on, I think January, everyone has to go on. And so I think -- but we took the opportunity to do it now just to get this noise out of our P&L next year.

componenttext: Yes, there's a few things that we're working on, Greg. And quite frankly, we prefer that our customers are talking about that when the timing is right. headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First is on nonres starts. As Bob, I think you said completions have been good this year. So that's obviously helping your business. But starts themselves have been down meaningfully in the first part of this year. Does that mean that there's going to be
componenttext: First is on nonres starts. As Bob, I think you said completions have been good this year. So that's obviously helping your business. But starts themselves have been down meaningfully in the first part of this year. Does that mean that there's going to be a fairly significant headwind next year? And what might you do to sort of get ahead of that?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nils, on average, as we typically point out, the time between starts and completion runs about 20 to 22 months in the nonresidential space, which means that next year, we're probably going to be completing 2015 starts. '15 was a pretty strong year, n
componenttext: Yes, Nils, on average, as we typically point out, the time between starts and completion runs about 20 to 22 months in the nonresidential space, which means that next year, we're probably going to be completing 2015 starts. '15 was a pretty strong year, not as strong as '14. '14 was the strongest year since the recession. '15 was the second strongest. And today, so far year-to-date, we're running down about 9% in square footage of starts. So we will see the nonresidential market trend downward in terms of completions over the next couple of years. As a reminder, the nonres market you're talking about, 1/3 of the new construction piece of the market, which new construction in total less than 20%. So it will be a headwind in outyears, just not a real significant one.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then at your recent Investor Day, you guys highlighted quite a bit of the innovation, particularly Paint Shield. Wondering how that's tracking. And obviously there's -- tying into the nonres starts, there has been quite a bit of strings in hea
componenttext: Got it. And then at your recent Investor Day, you guys highlighted quite a bit of the innovation, particularly Paint Shield. Wondering how that's tracking. And obviously there's -- tying into the nonres starts, there has been quite a bit of strings in health care. So I wonder if you've been able to get in the ground, so to speak.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say with a new technology like this, we as expected in this era, that there'll be a little bit of a ramp-up. We're working with a number of different decision-makers and influencers in this area. Trend-wise, it's going in the right direction and we're
componenttext: I'd say with a new technology like this, we as expected in this era, that there'll be a little bit of a ramp-up. We're working with a number of different decision-makers and influencers in this area. Trend-wise, it's going in the right direction and we're going to continue to focus on it. But the comparisons, as we go forward here, we expect to continue to improve.

componenttextpreview: Great. And then in terms of the Paint Stores, the contribution margin has been pretty large, and I know that's kind of due to the volume [indiscernible] raw materials. As raw materials sort of level out, do you look for that contribution margin started to
componenttext: Great. And then in terms of the Paint Stores, the contribution margin has been pretty large, and I know that's kind of due to the volume [indiscernible] raw materials. As raw materials sort of level out, do you look for that contribution margin started to go back to the traditional 25%, 30% type of flow-through [indiscernible] back half?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the 60%, 70% flow-throughs are nice. But you're right, it's not just that raw materials, we're fully integrated now with that Comex. Those things have really helped us over the last 2, 3 years. So we see as time goes on, it's going to -- we s
componenttext: Yes, I think the 60%, 70% flow-throughs are nice. But you're right, it's not just that raw materials, we're fully integrated now with that Comex. Those things have really helped us over the last 2, 3 years. So we see as time goes on, it's going to -- we still have great flow-through but probably, you're going to see closer to the, maybe a little higher than what we've done in the past. But yes, it will.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the last question. In terms of the acquisition-related cost, how much of that -- where are they big buckets these costs are going into? And how much of them are cash? And are they big enough for your sort of getting ahead of what costs maybe when
componenttext: And then the last question. In terms of the acquisition-related cost, how much of that -- where are they big buckets these costs are going into? And how much of them are cash? And are they big enough for your sort of getting ahead of what costs maybe when the deal finally closes in the first quarter?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In the first quarter, the acquisition cost -- I'm going to just speak to PBT, I won't talk about, unless you want me to. But If you take a look at the big buckets, there were advisory fees there. And then on other big piece of that, and that's the c
componenttext: Sure. In the first quarter, the acquisition cost -- I'm going to just speak to PBT, I won't talk about, unless you want me to. But If you take a look at the big buckets, there were advisory fees there. And then on other big piece of that, and that's the cash out in the third quarter because of the timing and so forth. But that, plus the bridge in term loan fees, that's -- we're amortizing those bridge in term loan fees today. That's cash. Then we have some legal fees that are cash. But the big hit will be Valspar's advisor and legal fees, which will occur at the close. So when we look at that $0.72 that we show in the fourth quarter, it's been finalized to $1.32, the majority of that is going to be a cash hit. That's why a lot of times we look at the cash needed to close this $11.3 billion, we look at it closer to $11.5 billion because we have these $200 million worth of pretax closing cost in total, the majority of which will be paid at that time.

componenttext: Inside our protective and Marine, we're focused on a number of them. Rosemarie, I'd prefer not to highlight those, for obvious reasons. So as we're pursuing these segments, we're -- sometimes, adversity brings out the best. We're finding that we have technologies that will help customers in adjacent segments. We have people that are knowledgeable and that we can pursue better. So we are after them. I'd rather not highlight them right now, but rest assured that we're out there pursuing them.

componenttext: Yes, it is. We did put the -- we did borrow last year in July. And so we've no fully anniversary those bonds that we issued. So we're 100% fixed right now. We're not in any variable interest. That's a very good rate, that $20 million is a very good number.

componenttext: I just had 2. First is, I mean, a little more understanding on the margins. So overall, incremental margins are at around 36% with paint stores performing particularly well. Are we close to the sweet spot in your capacity utilization? And if so, is there much operating leverage remaining as a ramp-up to what your estimate for midcycle paint volumes would be? Or is this going to be more of the headwind going forward where we want to see us much incremental margin for new paint volumes?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that we're getting closer to the sweet spot. I think that there is still some room when it comes to -- looking at that incremental margin. I think that when we are in the low 70s, we had a great deal of room. And so you saw greater impact. Bu
componenttext: Yes, I think that we're getting closer to the sweet spot. I think that there is still some room when it comes to -- looking at that incremental margin. I think that when we are in the low 70s, we had a great deal of room. And so you saw greater impact. But I do think the incremental margins will still be strong. It'll be higher than our ROS today. And I think that's the key for us. We are always trying to make sure that our incremental margin, our incremental flow-through, as we call it, is greater than our current ROS. So I still see that happening. I just don't see that happening at the 60%, 70% incremental margins.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then second question on normalized paint volumes. So I think your new forecast for 7 80 to 110 million gallons is a bit higher than your prior forecast. I think what we discussed maybe a few years ago of normalized volumes around $760 million. I think that's probably closer to what we're at today. And it looks like a large portion of the difference between your previous expectation and your new one is higher midcycle levels for res repaint and DIY. I know you guys discuss having a larger base of home so that would need repainting. But to the extent that the recycling new rest Marcus hasn't changed much, is it that we just expect the cycle to have a much bigger rally in the near term before normalizing the midcycle? Or I guess, what's driving the main difference?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, David, the question you're asking me is why is what we consider normalize growing? And I think you answered the question. It's growing because the base is growing. And if you look at the overall U.S. architectural paint market, more than 80% of aver
componenttext: Well, David, the question you're asking me is why is what we consider normalize growing? And I think you answered the question. It's growing because the base is growing. And if you look at the overall U.S. architectural paint market, more than 80% of average annual volume go stored repaint. It's supplied to structures that already exist. If you look at that 7 40 to 7 60 normalized range, that dates all the way back to the late 1990s. And we've had 3 building cycles since the late 1990s that have put a lot more square footage in place, our population has grown significantly since then. So we think it's reasonable to adjust normalized expectation up based on primarily repaint up volume. The other thing you see is, as the housing market continues to improve and get healthier and that health is often times in reflected in home values, you'll see the frequency of repaint activity increase. So at the peak of this cycle, people are painting more just like they're remodeling more.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Well, no. For normalized, that normalized band would assume housing starts in the range of 1.4 million to 1.5 million. We think that's sustainable given our current rate of household formation.

componenttextpreview: First of all, what we said, and I'm going to give you -- I don't have this in front of me, but I think it will be very close. Bob can tell us on the financial community presentation, that's how the server.com under IR. So we have a schedule and I actually
componenttext: First of all, what we said, and I'm going to give you -- I don't have this in front of me, but I think it will be very close. Bob can tell us on the financial community presentation, that's how the server.com under IR. So we have a schedule and I actually show you that what I think or debt to EBITDA would be although we out to, I believe, 20 20. So -- I'd ask you to do that. But I think what we try to show that is that they day of close our leverage is going to go over 6. If we close -- and based on closing and first quarter 2017, our deft EBITDA will be over 4, approximately 4.25. And so by '19, we'll be at 3. And by 2020, up 1.9, which is under 2. And I think that's the big goal by 2022 to be under 1.9. What we said is, and I'll answer this way because immediately, after that financial to presentation we were asked, does this mean that you're not going to be by any stocks for 2020? And I said no, we're going to by stack when were deft a bit starts to approach 2.5 to 1. So that will give you a little picture of what we're thinking. And then, on the Moody's front, I think we read the same thing from Moody's. Every summer, after the second quarter, we've always had individual meeting with Moody's and Fitch and S&P. We did have a meeting prior to the announcement of the Valspar acquisition, which is some of the -- and I think that we're going to go see all 3 of the rating agencies during this quarter. And we're optimistic that we keep the investment grade. Investment grade is very important to us because in the first quarter of every year, our cash flow is negative because we're building inventory for the season. So we're in the commercial paper. We want to be in the A1 P1. We don't want to have one of them not being investment grade. We take a look at the metrics. And we feel pretty good about the metrics long-term, and so the investment grade is pretty important to us.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you for joining The Sherwin-Williams Company's review of the second quarter results for 2016. With us on today's call are John Morikis, President and CEO; Sean Hennessy, CFO; Al Mistysyn, Senior Vice President, Corporate Controller;
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you for joining The Sherwin-Williams Company's review of the second quarter results for 2016. With us on today's call are John Morikis, President and CEO; Sean Hennessy, CFO; Al Mistysyn, Senior Vice President, Corporate Controller; and Bob Wells, Senior Vice President, Corporate Communications.
This conference call is being webcast simultaneously in listen-only mode by Issuer Direct via the Internet at sherwin.com. An archived replay of this webcast will be available at sherwin.com beginning approximately 2 hours after this conference call concludes and will be available until Wednesday, August 10 at 5:00 p.m. Eastern time.
This conference call will include certain forward-looking statements as defined under U.S. Federal Securities laws with respect to sales, earnings and other matters. Any forward-looking statements speaks only as of the day on which such statement is made, and the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A full declaration regarding forward-looking statements is provided in the company's earnings release transmitted earlier this morning.
[Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Bob Wells.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jesse. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. In the interest of time, we've provided some balance sheet items and other selected financial information on our website, sherwin.com, under Investor Relations, July 21 press release. I'l
componenttext:
Thanks, Jesse. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. In the interest of time, we've provided some balance sheet items and other selected financial information on our website, sherwin.com, under Investor Relations, July 21 press release. 
I'll begin by highlighting overall company performance for the second quarter 2016 compared to the second quarter 2015, then comment on each reportable segment. 
Consolidated net sales increased 2.8% to a record $3.22 billion, driven by higher paint sales volume in our Paint Stores Group. Unfavorable currency translation decreased consolidated net sales 1.5% in the quarter. Consolidated gross profit dollars increased $105.8 million in the quarter to $1.64 billion. 
Our consolidated gross margin increased 200 basis points in the quarter to 50.8% of sales from 48.8% in the second quarter last year. More than half of the gross margin improvement in the quarter resulted from the positive mix effect of Paint Stores Group, our highest gross margin segment, outpacing the growth of the other segments, coupled with increased operating leverage from higher production and distribution volume.
Selling, general and administrative expenses increased $54.7 million over second quarter last year to $1.1 billion. As a percent of sales, SG&A increased to 32.7% in the second quarter this year from 31.9% last year. A relatively small portion of this increase was acquisition-related expenses.
Interest expense increased $28 million compared to second quarter last year to $40.9 million. This increase includes $20.7 million in acquisition-related interest expense, with the balance resulting from a shift to long-term debt from short term that occurred midyear 2015. Consolidated profit before taxes in the quarter increased $31.4 million to $539.2 million due primarily to improved operating results from our Paint Stores Group.
Unfavorable currency translation reduced profit before tax in the quarter by $3.3 million compared to second quarter last year. Our effective tax rate in the second quarter was 32.1%, excluding the impact of the change in accounting standard. For the full year 2016, we expect our effective tax rate will remain in the low 30s excluding the impact of the change in accounting standard. Consolidated net income increased $28.1 million to $378.1 million. Net income, as a percent of sales, was 11.7% compared to 11.2% in the second quarter last year. 
Diluted net income per common share for the quarter increased 7.8% to $3.99 per share from $3.70 per share in 2015. The $3.99 includes $0.09 accretion from the accounting change and $0.16 dilution from acquisition-related expenses.
Looking at our results by operating segment. Sales for our Paint Stores Group in the second quarter '16 increased 6.2% to $2.11 billion from $1.98 billion last year. Comparable store sales, that is sales by stores opened more than 12 calendar months, increased 5.2%. All of the Paint Stores Group sales increase was due to higher organic architectural paint and equipment sales volumes across all end markets. Price mix had a negligible impact on sales in the quarter, and Protective & Marine coating sales were a modest drag on revenue growth.
Regionally in the second quarter, our Southeastern division led all divisions, followed by Midwestern division, Southwestern division, Canada and Eastern division. Sales and volumes were positive in every geographic division. 
Segment profit for the group increased $75.6 million or 17.4% to $509 million in the quarter, as higher architectural paint and equipment sales volumes were partially offset by higher SG&A spending. Segment operating margin increased to 24.1% of sales from 21.8% in the second quarter last year. For our Latin America Coatings Group, second quarter net sales, stated in U.S. dollars, decreased 11.2% to $133.3 million due to unfavorable currency translation and negative volumes that were partially offset by selling price increases. Currency translation rate changes decreased sales in U.S. dollars by 16.4% in the quarter.
Segment profit in U.S. dollars decreased to a loss of $9.6 million in the quarter from a profit of $4 million last year. Segment profit was negatively impacted by higher raw material costs and unfavorable currency translation that were partially offset by selling price increases. Currency translation decreased Latin America segment profit $1.3 million in the quarter. As a percent of net sales, segment operating profit was negative 7.2% in the quarter compared to a profit of 2.7% in the second quarter 2015.
Turning to the Consumer Group. Second quarter sales decreased 2.6% to $477.5 million. As a reminder, in April, we annualized the completion of the load-in of the HGTV HOME by Sherwin-Williams paint program in Lowe's stores, which was completed by May 1 last year. Segment profit for the Consumer Group decreased $6 million to $108.3 million in the quarter from $114.2 million in the second quarter last year due primarily to lower sales and increased SG&A spending, partially offset by improved operating efficiencies.
Segment profit, as a percent of external sales, decreased to 22.7% from 23.3% in the same period last year. For our Global Finishes Group, sales in U.S. dollars decreased 1.3% to $499.2 million in the quarter as unfavorable currency translation was partially offset by positive price mix. Unfavorable currency translation decreased net sales for the segment 2.6% in the quarter.
Second quarter segment profits stated in U.S. dollars increased $8 million or 13.9% to $65.2 million, due primarily to decreasing raw material cost and good cost control, partially offset by unfavorable currency translation, which decreased segment profit $1.5 million in the quarter. As a percent of sales, segment profit increased to 13.1% from 11.3% in the same period last year. 
That concludes my recap of our results for the quarter. So I will now turn the call over to John Morikis, who will make some general comments and highlight our expectations for third quarter and full year. John?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. I think it's fair to say our results for the second quarter were mixed. Architectural paint volumes through our Paint Stores Group held up well in the quarter, resulting in solid revenu
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. I think it's fair to say our results for the second quarter were mixed. Architectural paint volumes through our Paint Stores Group held up well in the quarter, resulting in solid revenue growth and continued strong earnings leverage and flow through. Our Global Finishes Group also did a commendable job of managing both gross margins and SG&A, resulting in a respectable 180 basis point operating margin improvement on modest volume growth.
We continue to see positive demand momentum in some of our industrial coatings businesses, primarily in Europe and the U.S. and currency headwinds in Latin America are starting to ease. Those were the positives in the quarter. 
On the other hand, while we expected difficult comparisons in the HGTV HOME paint program due to heavy stocking orders in the second quarter last year, some of the retail programs we thought would generate growth in the quarter fell short. We are supporting many of these programs with incremental SG&A investment, and we have high return expectations on these investments. 
Finally, while currency comparisons have improved in many Latin American countries, demand trends remain difficult and our outlook for this segment for the full year continues to deteriorate. Our earnings per share results in the quarter include expenses related to the Valspar acquisition as well as a tax benefit related to the adoption of a new accounting standard. 
If you back out these items, diluted net income per common share increased 9.7% on sales growth of less than 3%. As a percent of sales, gross profit increased 200 basis points year-over-year and operating profit and profit before tax both expanded a little more than 50 basis points. Excluding the acquisition expense, our incremental margin on consolidated profit before tax was 36%. SG&A was the only line on the P&L that went the wrong way as a percent of sales, the result of higher SG&A spending by Paint Stores Group, channel investment by Consumer Group and expenses related to the Valspar acquisition.
Paint Stores Group delivered another strong sales performance in the residential segments, which include residential repaint contractors, new residential construction and DIY. Combined, sales to these 3 segments grew by more than 10%. Sales to commercial, health care and property management customers also generated solid year-over-year growth. The outlook for continued growth in these segments over the balance of the year remains positive, supported by very healthy order book trends reported by most of our contractor segments extending into 2017.
During the first half of the year, Paint Stores Group opened 45 new stores and closed 14 redundant locations. This completes our consolidation of redundant store locations acquired from Comex. Our plan for the full year still calls for store openings in the range of 90 to 100 net new locations. Today, our total store count in the U.S., Canada and the Caribbeans stands at 4,117 compared to 4,025 a year ago.
We anticipated a modest sales decline from Consumer Group coming into the second quarter. This, combined with the elevated SG&A investment, tempered our second quarter outlook, which was reflected in our guidance. We remain confident that the great work our Consumer Group teams are doing in strengthening our brand positioning across all retail channels and the investment we are making in many of these channels will pay handsome returns in the years ahead. 
Consumer Group's commercial, industrial and MRO business continued to show good progress on both sales and margin in the quarter. Unfavorable currency translation continues to weigh on sales and profit performance in our Global Finishes Group and Latin America Coatings Group. Both segments reported positive sales in local currency in the quarter and Global Finishes Group volumes were positive, thanks in large part to improving market conditions in North America and Europe.
Volumes sales in most Latin American countries continued to decline with Brazil standing out as the most notable exception. Although Brazil's volume momentum improved in the quarter, margin pressure from raw materials continued to challenge profitability in Brazil and throughout the region. In the first 6 months of 2016, we generated $510 million in net operating cash, an increase of $161 million compared to the first half of 2015, driven by higher 6-month net income and good working capital discipline.
Working capital was a use of cash in the quarter, increasing by about $3.8 million year-over-year. Working capital, as a percent of sales, decreased to 11.6% from 11.8% at the end of the second quarter last year. The capital expenditures in the quarter totaled $62.1 million. Depreciation was $43.8 million and amortization was $6.2 million. In 2016, we anticipate capital expenditures of approximately $240 million, depreciation of $170 million to $180 million and amortization of about $30 million. 
Capital spending will run higher than normal in 2016 as we complete some facility renovation projects. During the quarter, we made no open market purchases of our common stock for treasury. On June 30, we had remaining board authorization to acquire 11.65 million shares. As indicated when we announced the Valspar acquisition, we intend to build cash on our balance sheet over the course of the year to reduce total borrowings required to close the deal, which will eliminate our share repurchase activity in 2016. At the close of the second quarter 2016, our cash balance was $402.7 million compared to $75.1 million on June 30, 2015.
Yesterday, our Board of Directors approved a quarterly dividend of $0.84 per share, up 25% from $0.67 last year. The outlook for Paint Stores Group over the next 6 months remains very positive, and we should see steady improvement from Consumer Group and Global Finishes Group. These positives will be offset to some degree by continued weakness in Latin America. As we've commented over the past few quarters, the gross margin tailwind we have enjoyed in recent years from raw material cost deflation will diminish as we go through the back half of 2016. 
Our outlook for third quarter 2016 is for consolidated net sales to increase low- to mid-single-digits percent compared to last year's third quarter. With sales at that level, we expect diluted net income per common share for the second quarter to be in the range of $4.10 to $4.30 per share compared to last year's record $3.97 per share. 
The full year 2016 earnings per share guidance we provided at the end of the first quarter did not include expenses related to the acquisition of Valspar or the tax benefit from the adoption of the new accounting standard. 
Today, we are revising our guidance for full year consolidated net income per common share to reflect these 2 impacts. For the full year, we expect consolidated net sales to increase over 2015 by a low single-digit percentage. With annual sales at that level, we are revising our expectation for full year diluted net income per common share to be in the range of $11.65 to $11.85 per share compared to $11.16 per share earned in 2015.
Again, I'd like to thank you for joining us this morning. And now we'll be happy to take your questions.

I'd say that our performance in the second quarter, we feel as though inside our largest customer with Lowe's that we're continuing to gain momentum. As far as the performance in the market, I think we're going to let them comment on how their performance rated against the market.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Perfect. And just a quick follow-up. You outlined a few trends in LatAm and indicated you still expect some continued weakness. But can you offer a little more color on what you're seeing here and whether or not you believe you've reached an inflection point in terms of the magnitude of operating losses?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that last year, we earned positive profit in each one of the quarters last year. And for the year, we think that this year is going to be the exact opposite. But I do think when you look at the investments we're making, we think we're doing t
componenttext: Yes, I think that last year, we earned positive profit in each one of the quarters last year. And for the year, we think that this year is going to be the exact opposite. But I do think when you look at the investments we're making, we think we're doing the right long-term. And we think that the markets are troughing. I think that when you look at specifically at Mexico and Brazil, we're closer to the end. What we said last year, we felt that Brazil would not [indiscernible] see an improvement during 2016, maybe mid 2017. I don't think we've seen much difference there with political and so forth. And Mexico, we think Mexico is doing better. We think that's doing fine. But Argentina, Chile, Ecuador, we're still having some headwinds there. And so we do believe that for the year, we're going to lose money in Latin America.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But as we've spoken in the past, we feel this is an opportunity for us. We see rather than just waiting for the market to correct, and we do think that the market will improve. But there is some steps that we can be taking, and we're taking those steps an
componenttext: But as we've spoken in the past, we feel this is an opportunity for us. We see rather than just waiting for the market to correct, and we do think that the market will improve. But there is some steps that we can be taking, and we're taking those steps and ensuring that we've got the right products, the right channels and the right people in those markets. And we're making very good progress and the improvements down there. So as the market does improve, we expect to outperform the market.

componenttext: This is Sean Hennessy. And the 5.2% was fairly close to where we were. We had said that in the first quarter, that was tremendously strong. We're almost double digits in the comp stores. So we did feel that it was going to be lower than that first quarter. But the 5.2% is not materially different than what we had in the guidance.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And regarding the market, Ghansham, I'd say I spent a great deal of my time with our customers and with our people in this segment. And there's a strong sense of bullishness in this area. There's continued growth in the residential repaint area. This is y
componenttext: And regarding the market, Ghansham, I'd say I spent a great deal of my time with our customers and with our people in this segment. And there's a strong sense of bullishness in this area. There's continued growth in the residential repaint area. This is yet another quarter for us with double-digit gains in residential repaint. Our commercial customers are really speaking a very solid book that currently exists as well as a number of bids in the pipeline. So on the architectural side, we're really excited about this market.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just my second question in terms of the, maybe you can share the outlook for raw material cost, including titanium dioxide and inflation more broadly, including labor inflation for the back half of '16 and heading into '17. I guess I'm asking be
componenttext: Okay. And just my second question in terms of the, maybe you can share the outlook for raw material cost, including titanium dioxide and inflation more broadly, including labor inflation for the back half of '16 and heading into '17. I guess I'm asking because the industry has not seen a paint price increase since '13, it seems like the case is increasing for one in '17. Would you sort of agree with that?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ghansham, this is Bob. On the raw material outlook, we still see low mid-single-digit deflation from the full year '16. Although you asked specifically about TiO2, the majors in TiO2, we think, are probably gaining some traction on the second quarter
componenttext: Yes, Ghansham, this is Bob. On the raw material outlook, we still see low mid-single-digit deflation from the full year '16. Although you asked specifically about TiO2, the majors in TiO2, we think, are probably gaining some traction on the second quarter price increase that they announced that is off the December 2015 lows. The implementation at this point, as near as we can tell from an industry standpoint, is probably in the mid single-digit cents per pound. So not a significant increase in percentage terms. They -- as expected, they've been out with a third quarter announcement. We think that it's likely they may get some traction. But how much they get really depends on customer size, on location geographically. So we're likely to see some year-over-year inflation in TiO2 as far as the rest of the basket. The feedstocks for the latex and acrylic monomer market is -- have been very stable. Propylene -- chemical grade propylene has been steady at around $0.31 a pound. So we don't necessarily see inflation in that side of the basket.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the labor side, we're putting our game plans together for 2017. We've done a lot of work on '17. But we don't see -- in their guidance, we still see productivity gains, especially in the stores group. So when you look at that labor expense, and we'
componenttext: And on the labor side, we're putting our game plans together for 2017. We've done a lot of work on '17. But we don't see -- in their guidance, we still see productivity gains, especially in the stores group. So when you look at that labor expense, and we're evaluating 2017 as we go. And as always, before we go -- before we announce to the market what we're going to do with pricing, we'll talk to our customers first. So those plans are being developed right now. And if we do go, after we've talked to the customers, we'll be pretty transparent and let you know.

componenttext: I think that our customers have always done a very good job in managing their working capital. And we're constantly working with them. And so I'd say it's just an ongoing discussion that we have with our customers. We want to help drive their key metrics, [indiscernible] or any another that they have. And so as they are reviewing what it is that's working for them, we want to be a part of that.

componenttext: I think that Latin America, 100% of the raw materials are based on U.S. dollar and are fully affected by the currency changes. In the Global Finishes, we do have a portion of that business that's in the United States and doesn't have that same effect. And I think that's what -- that's really the dramatic difference there.

And again, that was 100% in the administrative segment.

componenttext: But I would say this, Arun, is that all along, as we've been going through this, just as we just talk about Latin America, there are a number of segments within the Protective & Marine opportunities for our teams. componenttext: I think so. Yes. I think, as we move forward, the comps, we're going to lap those comps. And at the same time, some of the good work our teams, what they're putting in place right now, will continue to, I think, positively benefit us going forward.

componenttextpreview: And I think that even though the comps are getting easier, we're basically saying, I think, that we're in a trough now. I don't think we're ready to say that we're going to see major growth in either the Latin America or the Protective & Marine, but I thi
componenttext: And I think that even though the comps are getting easier, we're basically saying, I think, that we're in a trough now. I don't think we're ready to say that we're going to see major growth in either the Latin America or the Protective & Marine, but I think we're in a trough.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just the last question. You had put out earlier that your belief is that you can potentially get to 820 million gallons in the next peak. Is that still your belief? And when do think you can get there in this cycle?
componenttext: And just the last question. You had put out earlier that your belief is that you can potentially get to 820 million gallons in the next peak. Is that still your belief? And when do think you can get there in this cycle?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is, Arun. And we base that belief on the fact that the installed base of square footage that requires maintenance has grown pretty dramatically since the -- since we considered mid-700 million gallons to be normalized. So this peak should be well above
componenttext: It is, Arun. And we base that belief on the fact that the installed base of square footage that requires maintenance has grown pretty dramatically since the -- since we considered mid-700 million gallons to be normalized. So this peak should be well above the last peak just at normal build rates. And we're not back to normal build rates yet. We consider normal to be closer to 1.4, 1.5 million residential starts and a little stronger nonres activity than we're seeing right now. So once we get build rates back there and once the maintenance cycles are -- have returned to kind of normalized repaint activity, we think we're going to see normalized volume in the 780 to 810 million gallons. And very likely that this cycle should peak above that 810 million gallons. Whether that takes 3 years or 5 years to get back to, time will tell. At the rate of recovery in the residential market right now, I think that it's probably going to take at least 3 years to get back there.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question is coming from the line of Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to longer-term, orient a question just trying to understand your gross margin policy up nice the quarter and gross margins have been coming up quite a bit. Obviously, raw material cost has something to do with that. But as you guys look a
componenttext: So I just wanted to longer-term, orient a question just trying to understand your gross margin policy up nice the quarter and gross margins have been coming up quite a bit. Obviously, raw material cost has something to do with that. But as you guys look at kind of like your normalized gross margins, what are your thoughts about that? Can we still see things come up here? And I just wanted to get your thoughts on that.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that the way we run the business, we believe that in the long term, we're going to continue to raise their ROS. I think that the gross margin, we've had great expansion. We've had basically because of 3 things. I mean, really nice gallon grow
componenttext: Yes, I think that the way we run the business, we believe that in the long term, we're going to continue to raise their ROS. I think that the gross margin, we've had great expansion. We've had basically because of 3 things. I mean, really nice gallon growth, especially in the stores group. And integration that is complete now from the Comex North America and raw materials have been a tailwind. But those things have occurred. I think that in all cases, we're always looking at long term. I like your term, really looking in the long term. And again, this year, we're taking a balanced approach to where we're going. We're investing. There's times when the gross margin lead our ROS improvements. And there's times that SG&A -- and back to that gallon growth that we've had in that stores group is because of innovation. I think that we continue to do a lot of innovation, and innovation has helped us in all the different segments. So when you look at where we are going, this year, our midpoint of our range is $12.60. Last year, it was $11.13, a 13% increase. And during -- if you take a look at a challenging global environment and no share buybacks. Our original guidance had approximately $0.25 for the buybacks in there. So we're generating net operating cash at record levels, and we'll continue to make prudent investments in the business. So you're going to see SG&A. Probably this year isn't going to be in the improvement in the ROS. It has to be in gross margin. And we had the tailwind. We clearly said there was going to the tailwind. We had the innovation, and we had stores group going away. But we're pretty confident that those investments will earn solid returns in the future. And that's how we do this balanced approach for the long term that you asked.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's perfect. Appreciate all the color. And just maybe switching gears just a little bit to capacity levels that you guys are seeing right now. And what are these -- where are they? And what will they look like if you successfully close the Valspar acqu
componenttext: That's perfect. Appreciate all the color. And just maybe switching gears just a little bit to capacity levels that you guys are seeing right now. And what are these -- where are they? And what will they look like if you successfully close the Valspar acquisition?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We always have said that we were 88% and 92% as the sweet spot for us. And 2008 and 2009, when the market did go down 25%, 30% in that 1 year, we managed it. We did not take all the capacity out to get down to that level. And that's where the earlier ques
componenttext: We always have said that we were 88% and 92% as the sweet spot for us. And 2008 and 2009, when the market did go down 25%, 30% in that 1 year, we managed it. We did not take all the capacity out to get down to that level. And that's where the earlier question about the 820, we were shooting for that 750, 770. So that capacity, we live with the capacity in the low 70%. We're now much closer to that 88% and 92% and that's why our margins are doing very well. Since then, that North America acquisition of Comex, I think those gallons going into our footprint. But we've held on to a couple of the assets they have, and when we look at the Valspar, we think that they have some great assets to give us for capacity. We think that gives us another leg in the stool that give us the ability to have that capacity utilization go down in the short term. But that gives us the ability to grow without great deal of CapEx.

componenttext: Just to dig in a little bit more on Consumer Group. You mentioned a couple of programs you were running at retail, but didn't get the traction that you were looking for. componenttext: Well, I think what's important here is that there is some investment here and we see as the clear opportunity. We do go into this with our eyes wide open. We know that there are investments made that may not come back in the first quarter that we make those investments, maybe not the second. But if you look at our market share in this segment, there's terrific opportunities. We believe a disciplined approach and an aggressive approach here can help us to grow our market share and manage our margins for our shareholders. So we are moving in this direction very -- with a very disciplined look. We are making the investments, and we think that there are opportunities out there for us to grow.

componenttext: Yes. And as far as the timing, as you mentioned, we're patient. We think it's -- but we don't see it snapping back in the next quarter or so.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question first just on your overall impression in the architectural market. Last year, it was obviously -- I know you don't like to talk about weather, but it was weather depressed and growth was 2% to 3%. Are you seeing the snap back you expected this
componenttext: A question first just on your overall impression in the architectural market. Last year, it was obviously -- I know you don't like to talk about weather, but it was weather depressed and growth was 2% to 3%. Are you seeing the snap back you expected this year? Or is that being moderated again by weather, Bob, what's kind of your outlook for the U.S. architectural market growth this year?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Don, I mean, for starters, we don't think there was much of weather effect in the numbers this year. We think that build rates are holding up very well, but they're not on fire. Residential construction is up about 10% year-over-year in square footag
componenttext: Yes, Don, I mean, for starters, we don't think there was much of weather effect in the numbers this year. We think that build rates are holding up very well, but they're not on fire. Residential construction is up about 10% year-over-year in square footage terms. In the commercial market, starts are down, but completions are up pretty significantly year over year. So we are seeing solid demand growth in the new construction markets. In their repaint markets, while the pro-residential repaint business has been really solid, we -- what's hard to determine at this stage because we just don't have the data is how the DIY channel's held up in the second quarter. So I hesitate to say that there's just not enough data to call market growth in the second quarter yet, but I think that's the truth. The contractor market seems to have grown nicely, but it's hard to tell on the other piece.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

Maybe you can update us on the Valspar synergy outlook to the extent you've been able to talk to your counterparts over there and have meetings about combining the 2 companies. componenttext: Right. I don't think we're going to move the original target. And -- but I think that, as time goes on, we continue to feel very confident that we're going to hit those numbers.

componenttext: I was wondering if you could give a little more detail on the solid margin performance you had in the Global Finishes Group. I know you mentioned the price and mix was improving. What exactly was driving that? And how sustainable could a number like 13% margin be as we get into the second half in that segment?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that when we take a look at the -- at that group, I think that the improvement stems from really 4 focus: driving that product technology I mentioned earlier into the market, improving SG&A, capturing pricing in the -- where they offset currency a
componenttext: I think that when we take a look at the -- at that group, I think that the improvement stems from really 4 focus: driving that product technology I mentioned earlier into the market, improving SG&A, capturing pricing in the -- where they offset currency and then capturing reductions in the raw materials that they occur in the United States. So these combination of 4 things, I don't think are going to change. You'll see the [indiscernible]. For the longest time, we used to talk about 12%. And I think that this gives us great confidence that we can say 13% and win some market share gains. I think we can actually beat that number. So I think the game plan has worked very, very well.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, great. And then a question on Latin America. It sounded like you mentioned that you expect to be below breakeven for the rest of the year. But just wondering as we get into the heavier paint season there in Q4, is there a chance that we get nor
componenttext: All right, great. And then a question on Latin America. It sounded like you mentioned that you expect to be below breakeven for the rest of the year. But just wondering as we get into the heavier paint season there in Q4, is there a chance that we get north of breakeven? And also wondering if there were some unusual costs in Q2 that help explain a pretty significant sequential weakening in terms of the earnings in Latin America.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The answer to the last question is no. There really was no onetime thing that I would point out. I just think it was like the operation as it is. I think we've come closer to breakeven. And maybe there's a chance that if we have a little stronger sales, t
componenttext: The answer to the last question is no. There really was no onetime thing that I would point out. I just think it was like the operation as it is. I think we've come closer to breakeven. And maybe there's a chance that if we have a little stronger sales, the fourth quarter definitely is the closest to breakeven for the remainder of the year. But right now, I would not come out here and say we're definitely going to make money in the fourth quarter.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had 2 questions. One was a little accounting and charge clarification and then second on the business. Sean, the income tax benefit, could you explain what that actually is? And is it just simply as straight as $0.09, $8 million is coming into taxes?
componenttext: I had 2 questions. One was a little accounting and charge clarification and then second on the business. Sean, the income tax benefit, could you explain what that actually is? And is it just simply as straight as $0.09, $8 million is coming into taxes?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And what that is, is when we've expensed -- when starting the new rules many, many years ago expensing stock option, RSO grants and so forth, you charge the P&L for the Black-Scholes amount. So whatever the Black-Scholes value as on the day of issuan
componenttext: Yes. And what that is, is when we've expensed -- when starting the new rules many, many years ago expensing stock option, RSO grants and so forth, you charge the P&L for the Black-Scholes amount. So whatever the Black-Scholes value as on the day of issuance, basically, you straight line it, and if it was a 3-year or a 5-year option vesting period. When the -- then what would occur is if the stock, the differential between when the day of vesting a differential in -- differential between Black-Scholes value and the actual value, was actually a -- that difference will use to go to retained earnings. We always took it on our tax return, and that was one of the differentials between book and cash taxes. So this change -- this accounting change for us has nothing to do with, and it won't change our cash performance. But instead of having that differential that for us, as you've said in the second quarter $8 million, go to retained earnings and now goes directly through the P&L. So that's why it was $0.09 in the second quarter. Year-to-date, it was $0.28. And the reason why it was $0.19 in the first quarter is because of the -- in the first quarter, when the vesting occurs of our long-term RSOs so that many people are on that. So that's why it hit in the first quarter. Second quarter was really driven by stock options that were exercised. So that's what it is. It doesn't have a cash differential. That's why we pointed it out. We adapted it this quarter. So we can do it, the accounting this way. I think as time goes on, I think January, everyone has to go on. And so I think -- but we took the opportunity to do it now just to get this noise out of our P&L next year.

componenttext: Yes, there's a few things that we're working on, Greg. And quite frankly, we prefer that our customers start talking about that when the timing is right. headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First is on nonres starts. As Bob, I think, you said completions have been good this year. So that's obviously helping your business. But starts themselves have been down meaningfully in the first part of this year. Does that mean that there's going to be
componenttext: First is on nonres starts. As Bob, I think, you said completions have been good this year. So that's obviously helping your business. But starts themselves have been down meaningfully in the first part of this year. Does that mean that there's going to be a fairly significant headwind next year? And what might you do to sort of get ahead of that?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nils, on average, as we typically point out, the time between starts and completion runs about 20 to 22 months in the nonresidential space, which means that next year, we're primarily going to be completing 2015 starts. '15 was a pretty strong year,
componenttext: Yes, Nils, on average, as we typically point out, the time between starts and completion runs about 20 to 22 months in the nonresidential space, which means that next year, we're primarily going to be completing 2015 starts. '15 was a pretty strong year, not as strong as '14. '14 was the strongest year since the recession. '15 was the second strongest. And today, so far year-to-date, we're running down about 9% in square footage of starts. So we will see the nonresidential market trend downward in terms of completions over the next couple of years. As a reminder, the nonres market, you're talking about, 1/3 of the new construction piece of the market, which new construction in total is less than 20%. So it will be a headwind in out-year is just not a real significant one.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And then at your recent Investor Day, you guys highlighted quite a bit of the innovation, particularly Paint Shield. Wondering how that's tracking. headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say with a new technology like this, we -- as expected in this era, that there'll be a little bit of a ramp-up. We're working with a number of different decision makers and influencers in this area. Trend-wise, it's going in the right direction, and w
componenttext: I'd say with a new technology like this, we -- as expected in this era, that there'll be a little bit of a ramp-up. We're working with a number of different decision makers and influencers in this area. Trend-wise, it's going in the right direction, and we're going to continue to focus on it. But the comparisons, as we go forward here, we expect to continue to improve.

componenttext: Great. And then in terms of the Paint Stores, the contribution margin's been pretty large, and I know that's kind of [indiscernible] raw materials. componenttext: Yes, I think the 60%, 70% flow-throughs are nice. But you're right, there's not just that raw materials. We're fully integrated now with that Comex, and those things have really helped us over the last 2, 3 years. So we see, as time goes on, it's going to -- we still have great flow-through, but probably, you're going to see it closer to the -- maybe a little higher than what we've done in the past. But yes, it will.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the last question. In terms of the acquisition-related costs, how much of that -- what are the big buckets these costs are going into? And what -- how much of them are cash? And are they big enough where you're sort of getting ahead of what costs
componenttext: And then the last question. In terms of the acquisition-related costs, how much of that -- what are the big buckets these costs are going into? And what -- how much of them are cash? And are they big enough where you're sort of getting ahead of what costs may be when the deal finally closes in the first quarter?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In the first quarter, the acquisition costs -- I'm going to just speak to PBT. I won't talk about unless you want me to. But If you take a look at the big buckets, they were our advisory fees there. And then another big piece of that, [indiscernible
componenttext: Sure. In the first quarter, the acquisition costs -- I'm going to just speak to PBT. I won't talk about unless you want me to. But If you take a look at the big buckets, they were our advisory fees there. And then another big piece of that, [indiscernible], that's the cash out in the third quarter because of the timing and so forth. But that, plus the bridge and term loan fees, that's -- we're amortizing those bridge and term loan fees today. That's cash. Then we have some legal fees that are cash. But the big hit will be Valspar's adviser and legal fees, which will occur at the close. So when we look at that $0.72 that we show in the fourth quarter to finalize to $1.32, the majority of that is going to be a cash hit. That's why a lot of times we look at the cash needed to close this $11.3 billion, we look at it closer to $11.5 billion because we have these $200 million worth of pretax closing costs in total, the majority of which will be paid at that time.

componenttextpreview: I think the majority of which was in consumer but LACG, but we're still investing in stores. I think that the stores' investments have not changed. We think this is a continued driver. So the SG&A increase, as a percent of sales, was not in stores. But we
componenttext: I think the majority of which was in consumer but LACG, but we're still investing in stores. I think that the stores' investments have not changed. We think this is a continued driver. So the SG&A increase, as a percent of sales, was not in stores. But we still are investing in stores as heavy as we ever have been.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So just to tailor the question, maybe the consumer, given that you had heavy investment last year and then you have investment this year that might be related to other programs, do you think this is needed to sustain that flat to low single-digit g
componenttext: Right. So just to tailor the question, maybe the consumer, given that you had heavy investment last year and then you have investment this year that might be related to other programs, do you think this is needed to sustain that flat to low single-digit growth you guys have guided to longer term? Or should we expect the growth rates to be better than that once you get a return on these investments?

componenttextpreview: We're going to be trying to drive that higher, Scott. The investments that we're making here we believe can help us.
componenttext: We're going to be trying to drive that higher, Scott. The investments that we're making here we believe can help us.

componenttext: Inside our Protective & Marine, we're focused on a number of them. Rosemarie, I'd prefer not to highlight those for obvious reasons. So as we're pursuing these segments, we're -- sometimes, adversity brings out the best. We're finding that we have technologies that will help customers in adjacent segments. We have people that are knowledgeable and that we can pursue better. So we are after them. I'd rather not highlight them right now, but rest assured that we're out there pursuing them.

componenttextpreview: I think that we've never broken out segment when -- inside our guidance. But I think what we've really have said for probably 14 quarters in a row, when you look at that guidance number, the stores group again will lead our sales in the third and fourth q
componenttext: I think that we've never broken out segment when -- inside our guidance. But I think what we've really have said for probably 14 quarters in a row, when you look at that guidance number, the stores group again will lead our sales in the third and fourth quarter and for the full year. So I think that the first half of the year is probably a pretty good indication of where you'd see. When you break out your sales in the market, that stores group is going to be #1, and those comp stores are going to be strong.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And another year you're expecting 90 to 110 net new stores, and you've put out some pretty good targets out there on 6,000. Can you just talk about sort of what gives you guys the confidence to say that you're not hitting or you won't hit a saturation poi
componenttext: And another year you're expecting 90 to 110 net new stores, and you've put out some pretty good targets out there on 6,000. Can you just talk about sort of what gives you guys the confidence to say that you're not hitting or you won't hit a saturation point or some diminishing returns with that level of continued growth?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We -- I'd say, we spent a lot of time on this metric. And we're watching to see how the new stores today are creating cash and the metrics versus the metrics we've done over the years. We compare it to the market. We compare it to how that market is in re
componenttext: We -- I'd say, we spent a lot of time on this metric. And we're watching to see how the new stores today are creating cash and the metrics versus the metrics we've done over the years. We compare it to the market. We compare it to how that market is in relative size to stores per household. And the metrics have all been going in the right direction, which would tell you if your incremental stores continue to perform like that, you're probably -- and the markets are performing that you're probably not at a saturation point.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
