componenttextpreview: I'm Matt Skowronski on for Dmitry. Looking at Brazil and Latin America, were there any currency kind of flat year-over-year? So do you guys expect positive FX comps in the second half? Or other currencies kind of going to weigh you down with the peso or t
componenttext: I'm Matt Skowronski on for Dmitry. Looking at Brazil and Latin America, were there any currency kind of flat year-over-year? So do you guys expect positive FX comps in the second half? Or other currencies kind of going to weigh you down with the peso or the Argentina peso?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Don't worry about the Argentine peso. The 4 currencies that drive us, and I'm talking specifically Sherwin, the Brazilian real, which is better than it was in the first quarter but still a headwind in the second quarter, we were still in the BRL 3.
componenttext: Right. Don't worry about the Argentine peso. The 4 currencies that drive us, and I'm talking specifically Sherwin, the Brazilian real, which is better than it was in the first quarter but still a headwind in the second quarter, we were still in the BRL 3.11s. We expect that possibly by the fourth quarter, that's not going to be a headwind. That's going to be a tailwind. The second is Canadian dollar. The Canadian dollar continues to be weak. So we expect that's going to be a headwind for the remainder of the year. The euro, which is relatively flat, and so we think about that [ph], but we have a big presence in the U.K., and with the Ronseal brand, the Leighs Paint brand, the Geocel. And the Great Britain pound is now a headwind, a significant headwind.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining The Sherwin-Williams Company's review of third quarter results for 2016. With us on today's call are John Morikis, President and CEO; Sean Hennessy, CFO; Al Mistysyn, Senior Vice President, Corporate Controller; and Bob
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining The Sherwin-Williams Company's review of third quarter results for 2016. With us on today's call are John Morikis, President and CEO; Sean Hennessy, CFO; Al Mistysyn, Senior Vice President, Corporate Controller; and Bob Wells, Senior Vice President, Corporate Communications.
This conference call is being webcast simultaneously in listen-only mode by Issuer Direct via the Internet at sherwin.com. An archived replay of this webcast will be available at sherwin.com beginning approximately 2 hours after this conference call concludes and will be available until Monday, November 14 at 5:00 p.m. Eastern time.
This conference call will include certain forward-looking statements as defined under U.S. federal securities laws with respect to sales, earnings and other matters. Any forward-looking statements speak only as of the date on which such statement is made, and the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A full declaration regarding forward-looking statements is provided in the company's earnings release transmitted earlier this morning. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now turn the call over to Bob Wells.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jesse. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. In the interest of time, we have provided some balance sheet items and other selected financial information on our website, sherwin.com, under Investor Relations October 25 press release. I
componenttext:
Thanks, Jesse. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. In the interest of time, we have provided some balance sheet items and other selected financial information on our website, sherwin.com, under Investor Relations October 25 press release. I'll begin by highlighting overall company performance for the third quarter 2016 compared to third quarter 2015 then comment on each reportable segment.
Consolidated net sales increased $127.2 million or 4% to $3.28 billion, driven by higher paint sales volume in our Paint Stores Group and the impact of a change in revenue classification related to third-party service revenue and related costs. The change in revenue classification increased sales 2.3% in the quarter. Unfavorable currency translation decreased consolidated net sales by 0.8% in the quarter.
Consolidated gross profit dollars increased $61.7 million or 3.9% in the quarter to $1.64 billion compared to $1.57 billion last year. Consolidated gross margin was 49.9% of sales, flat compared to the third quarter last year.
Selling, general and administrative expenses for the quarter increased $64.5 million or 6.5% to $1.06 billion. As a percent of sales, SG&A increased to 32.3% in the third quarter this year, up 80 basis points from last year. A portion of this increase was acquisition-related expenses.
Interest expense increased $27.1 million compared to third quarter last year to $44.1 million. The vast majority of this increase was acquisition-related interest expense. 
Consolidated profit before taxes in the quarter decreased $15.1 million or down 2.7% to $535.6 million, due primarily to acquisition-related expenses. Unfavorable currency translation reduced profit before tax in the quarter by $4.6 million compared to third quarter last year.
Consolidated net income increased $12.2 million or 3.3% to $386.7 million. Net [indiscernible] 11.8% compared to 11.9% in the third quarter last year. 
Our effective tax rate in the third quarter was 27.8%. A comparable effective tax rate to 2015 would be 30.5%. For full year 2016, we expect our effective tax rate to be in the low 30s, excluding the impact of the accounting change. 
Diluted net income per common share for the quarter increased 2.8% to $4.08 per share from $3.97 per share in 2015. The $4.08 includes $0.09 accretion from the change in accounting standard and $0.24 dilution from acquisition-related expenses. Unfavorable currency translation rate changes decreased earnings per share by $0.03 in the quarter.
Looking at our results by operating segment. Sales for our Paint Stores Group in the third quarter 2016 increased $140.6 million or 6.7% to $2.23 billion from $2.09 billion last year. Comparable store sales, that is, [ph] sales by stores opened more than 12 calendar months excluding the change in revenue classification, increased 2.1%. Paint Stores Group's sales increase was due to higher architectural paint sales volume across most end market segments and the impact of the change in revenue classification. Price mix had a negligible impact on sales in the quarter, and protective and marine coatings sales were a significant drag on revenue growth.
Regionally, in the third quarter, our Canadian division led all divisions, followed by Southeastern division, Southwestern division, Midwest and Eastern division. Sales and volumes were positive in every division. 
Segment profit for the group increased $10.9 million or 2.1% to $518.3 million in the quarter as higher architectural paint and equipment sales volumes were partially offset by higher SG&A spending. Segment operating margin decreased 100 basis points to 23.3% of sales from 24.3% in the third quarter last year.
For our Latin America Coatings Group, third quarter net sales stated in U.S. dollars was $156.6 million, up $618,000, due primarily to higher year-over-year selling prices that were partially offset by unfavorable foreign currency translation and volume declines.
Currency translation rate changes decreased sales in U.S. dollars by $12.8 million or 8.2% in the quarter. Segment profit in the third quarter, stated in U.S. dollars, decreased $1.2 million or 54.6% to $1 million from $2.1 million in the same period last year. The negative impact from higher raw material costs and unfavorable currency translation was only partially offset by increased selling prices. Currency translation decreased segment profit $3.6 million in the quarter compared to the same period last year. As a percent of net sales, segment profit decreased to 60 basis points in the quarter compared to 1.4% in the third quarter 2015.
For our Consumer Group, sales decreased $8.7 million or 2.1% to $412.9 million from $421.6 million last year, primarily due to unfavorable foreign currency translation and declining sales to certain retail accounts, commercial customers and in our European business. Unfavorable currency translation decreased net sales for the segment by $5 million or 1.2%. Segment profit for the Consumer Group increased $3.8 million or 4.3% to $92 million from $88.3 million last year, due to improved operating efficiencies and good SG&A expense control. Segment profit as a percent of external sales increased to 22.3% from 20.9% in the same period last year. 
For our Global Finishes Group, sales in U.S. dollars decreased $5.4 million or 1.1% to $480.7 million in the quarter as unfavorable currency translation was partially offset by positive price mix. Unfavorable currency translation decreased net sales for this segment by $7.1 million or 1.5% in the quarter. Segment profit in U.S. dollars increased $8 million or 14.6% in the quarter to $63.2 million from $55.1 million last year, due primarily to good SG&A expense control. Unfavorable currency translation decreased segment profit $500,000 [ph] in the quarter. As a percent to net external sales, Global Finishes Group segment profit increased to 13.1% from 11.3% in the quarter compared to last year. 
That concludes my recap of our results for the quarter. So I will turn the call over to John Morikis, who will make some general comments and highlight our expectations for fourth quarter and full year. John?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Our results for the third quarter include a number of unusual items that affect our revenues, expenses and tax rate. If you back out the impact of these items, our results on a comparable year
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Our results for the third quarter include a number of unusual items that affect our revenues, expenses and tax rate. If you back out the impact of these items, our results on a comparable year-over-year basis showed modest improvement.
Consolidated sales increased 1.7% to $3.2 billion. Consolidated gross margin was 50.9%, an increase of 100 basis points compared to the third quarter last year. Operating profit improved 1.9% to $591.8 million. Profit before tax grew 3.9% to $572.4 million, a 30 basis point increase as a percent of sales. Net income increased 6.2% to $397.9 million, and earnings per share increased 6.5% to $4.23 per share.
These results are consistent with the GAAP guidance ranges we provided for both revenue and earnings, but they fell short of what we envisioned at the start of the quarter. Revenue growth at the lower end of our low to mid-single-digit range was disappointing. And the ongoing investments we are making in new stores, sales territories, retail merchandising, advertising, training and store service weighed heavily on earnings, particularly in light of the slow revenue growth.
Our sales trend by quarter so far this year is similar to last year with growth decelerating each quarter as we go through the year. At this point, it is unclear whether the midyear slowdown in sales over the past 2 years is a result of labor constraints in the construction trades or an indication that the housing cycle is slowing, which is contrary to what most of the data would suggest, or something else entirely. Whatever the reason for the slowdown, our response is the same: We will continue to make prudent investments in the things that drive our long-term growth and profitability.
Architectural paint sales to our Paint Stores Group, once again significantly outpaced revenue growth for the segment as a whole. High single-digit growth in the new residential and residential repaint contractor business was partially offset by a modest but unexpected year-over-year decline in DIY sales. Sales to commercial and health care customers also generated solid year-over-year growth while the property management segment showed modest gains.
The outlook for continued growth in residential markets over the balance of the year and into 2017 remains positive, supported by very healthy order book trends reported by most of our contractor customers.
On the other hand, the revenue headwind from our protective and marine business in Paint Stores worsened sequentially in the third quarter. During the first 9 months of the year, Paint Stores Group opened 69 new stores and closed 14 redundant locations, completing our consolidation of redundant store locations acquired from Comex. Our plan for the year still calls [ph] for the store openings in a range of 90 to 100 net new locations. Today, our store count in the U.S., Canada and the Caribbean stands at 4,141 compared to 4,048 a year ago. 
Finally, the upward inflection in input costs and operating expenses that we have seen in the recent months, including raw materials, wages and benefits, rent expense and more, warrant a price increase by our Paint Stores Group. Effective December 1, 2016, our Paint Stores Group will be implementing a price increase in the 4% to 5% range across most product lines. 
We also anticipated a stronger sales performance from our Consumer Group coming into the third quarter. We saw widespread weakness across our commercial, industrial and MRO customers. Our Ronseal brand business in Europe also had a soft quarter. Despite the weaker-than-expected sales results, the Consumer Group continued to show good progress on margins in the quarter.
Our Global Finishes Group did a commendable job of managing both gross margin and SG&A in the quarter, resulting in a 180 basis point operating margin improvement on modest sale declines. We continue to see positive demand momentum in some of our industrial coatings businesses, primarily in Europe and in Asia.
Finally, our Latin America Coatings Group reported positive revenue growth in the quarter for the first time in 12 quarters. Despite this improvement in revenue and volume momentum, margin pressure from raw materials and higher SG&A spending continued to challenge our profitability throughout the region.
Third quarter was a strong quarter for cash generation. Net operating cash in the first 9 months was $966.5 million, up about $64 million over last year, with third quarter accounting for about $456 million of the total. We're on pace again this year to generate net operating cash at a rate above 10% of net sales. We are at 10.7% year-to-date despite higher working capital.
9-month working capital ticked up slightly to 11.5% of sales from 11.1% last year. Free cash flow, which is net operating cash less CapEx and dividends, was $560 million compared to $557 million last year. Our capital expenditures year-to-date totaled $173.1 million. Depreciation was $128.3 million, and amortization was $20.2 million.
In 2016, we anticipate capital expenditures of approximately $240 million, depreciation of $170 million to $180 million and amortization of about $30 million. Capital spending will run higher than normal in 2016 as we complete some facility renovation projects.
During the quarter, we made no open market purchases of our common stock for treasury. On September 30, we had remaining board authorization to acquire 11.65 million shares. As indicated when we announced the Valspar acquisition, we intend to build cash on our balance sheet over the course of the year to reduce total borrowings required to close the deal, which will eliminate our share repurchase activity in 2016. As a result, our cash balance at the close of the third quarter 2016 was $702.6 million compared to $91 million on September 30, 2015.
Last week, our Board of Directors approved a quarterly dividend of $0.84 per share, up 25% from $0.67 last year. The outlook for Paint Stores Group over the balance of the year remains positive, and we expect to see steady improvements from Consumer Group and Global Finishes Group. These positives will be offset, to some degree, by continued weakness in Latin America.
Over the balance of the year, the input cost tailwinds are likely to turn to headwinds, and the slower pace of sales growth is unlikely to fully offset our investment in new stores, territories and retail programs already in place. For the quarter, we anticipate our core consolidated net sales will increase a low single-digit percentage compared to last year's fourth quarter.
At this anticipated sales level, we estimate diluted net income per common share in the fourth quarter to be in the range of $1.45 to $1.55 per share. Fourth quarter 2016 earnings per share include costs related to the anticipated acquisition of Valspar totaling $0.71 per share and an increase in EPS of approximately $0.03 per share related to the decrease in the income tax provision. Excluding these items, fourth quarter EPS will be in the range of $2.13 to $2.23 per share compared to $2.12 per share earned in the fourth quarter 2015.
For the full year 2016, we expect core consolidated net sales to increase by a low single-digit percentage compared to full year 2015. With annual sales at that level, we are updating our guidance for full year 2016 diluted net income per common share to be in the range of $11.30 to $11.40 per share.
Full year 2016 earnings per share includes costs related to the anticipated acquisition of Valspar totaling approximately $1.35 per share and an increase in EPS of approximately $0.40 per share related to the decrease in the income tax provision. Excluding these items, full year EPS will be in the range of $12.25 to $12.35 per share, a 10% increase at the midpoint of the range over the $11.16 per share earned in 2015.
Before we open the call for questions, I'd like to comment briefly on the other press release we issued this morning. Last week, our Board of Directors elected Al Mistysyn to serve as our next Chief Financial Officer, a position held for the past 15 years by Sean Hennessy. This change will take effect January 1, 2017.
I'd like to close my comments with a few words about my great friend, Sean Hennessy. My relationship with Sean spans our 30 years together at Sherwin-Williams. He's always been an excellent adviser, contributor, and importantly, friend. We traveled around the world together on many occasions, and Sean has regularly impressed me in so many ways. So it's no surprise that Sean has once again impressed me with his selfless decision to do what he believes to be right for his family. Sean's decision to step down from the day-to-day responsibilities of CFO in order to provide more time and flexibility to address family priorities is yet another example of the quality individual we've all grown to respect. We appreciate his willingness to stay on as Head of M&A Activities [ph] to provide support for the Valspar integration planning process and to ensure a smooth transition of CFO responsibilities.
This past year, I've spent more time with Sean than any other executive on my team, traveling with many of you to immerse myself in this important aspect of my job and to gain as much information as I could from Sean knowing this time was coming. While it's never a good time for a high-performing executive like Sean to leave such an important role, the timing of his decision sets us up well for the year ahead. 
Al Mistysyn's promotion to CFO is the natural conclusion of a long, careful and thoughtful development plan to prepare him for this position. Al has been Sean's right-hand man and the architect of many of our financial programs and successes. Al is my choice for this important position. He is a proven, seasoned executive. And I'm truly excited to have him on my side as we move forward. We've assembled a full Valspar integration team that has been hard at it [ph] for several months now, with Al actively involved on a daily basis. We're also in the process of building our operating plans and budgets for next year with each of our segment teams. And having Al at my side for these important meetings is crucial to his fast start.
With that, I'd like to thank you for joining us this morning. And now we'll be happy to take your questions.

componenttext: Yes. So initially, I would maybe answer it this way. We did see high single-digit growth in our new residential and our residential repaint business. We saw solid year-over-year increases in our commercial and our health care businesses and modest gains in our property management. As I mentioned just a moment ago, we did see a modest decline in DIY, and our P&M worsened sequentially. So our outlook obviously remains very positive. We see the fundamentals of the business very solid and have great confidence in the investments that we're making, that we're going to continue to be able to grow market share. We talked -- actually, Bob just covered geographically about the growth, with Canada leading the market, and talked about the different geographies. So I think we captured that in the comments just a moment ago.

componenttext: So I guess, going back to same-store sales for PSG just kind of being irradical [ph] with the past few quarters, you're obviously bullish on the outlook. I guess, John, what are customers in particular sharing with you in terms of why growth has been so choppy quarter by quarter?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, your point is a good one. The confidence that we have, we believe, is built on the fundamentals of the market, and we continue to believe that investing in this business is going to be a key part of our success. The contractors that we've spoken to
componenttext: Well, your point is a good one. The confidence that we have, we believe, is built on the fundamentals of the market, and we continue to believe that investing in this business is going to be a key part of our success. The contractors that we've spoken to continue to believe that there are plenty of opportunities ahead. I mentioned the residential business that we saw growing a nearly double-digit increase in residential repaint, over 9%. And speaking to these customers about the constraints that they feel as a result of the labor has had an impact on their business. So we're confident in this model that we have. We're continuing to invest in it. We believe that the investment in our stores reps and products are going to continue to allow us to continue to drive that operating margin. We're going to have a good operating margin improvement this year. We expect to have a good operating margin improvement next year, and we think that the fundamentals of the market support to the contractor base that we're focused on.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ghansham, this is Bob. Let me throw in that based on our volumes by quarter, it appears to us that the third quarter is the busiest quarter for contractors. So if there is labor constraints in the market, it would most likely show up in the third quarter,
componenttext: Ghansham, this is Bob. Let me throw in that based on our volumes by quarter, it appears to us that the third quarter is the busiest quarter for contractors. So if there is labor constraints in the market, it would most likely show up in the third quarter, or it would show up more in the third quarter than even in the second.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll take the first piece on the bottom of the P&M. We do feel as though that we're nearing bottom. This has been a tough road here with the oil and gas predominantly under a lot of pressure. We have -- as I've mentioned in previous calls, we're [ph]
componenttext: Yes. I'll take the first piece on the bottom of the P&M. We do feel as though that we're nearing bottom. This has been a tough road here with the oil and gas predominantly under a lot of pressure. We have -- as I've mentioned in previous calls, we're [ph] to pivot our efforts into accelerating in other segments, where we've been focused on for many years, but we expect to be able to accelerate our sales in those areas. The fact is, is [ph] that the oil and gas is a big part of our business. It's been an area that we've been focused on for many years, and we've had significant success, and it's had an impact on our business as it's slowing down. [ph] But we're continuing to grow in areas within oil and gas as well as some of these other areas within protective and marine.

componenttext: Yes. Bob, a question on the overall market. I mean, we've seen lower growth from other companies who have reported in the architectural space as well. So just wondering, snapback [ph] that we're all expecting this year because -- [ph] easy weather comps from last year. Did that not materialize? Or were there some volumes that weren't brought forward [ph] in the very strong first quarter you had? Just wondering what comment you'd have on the overall market growth.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Don, in John's prepared remarks, he talked about the sales trends or the sales trajectory by quarter being similar this year to last year. And with think that's a reflection of the market overall. We're seeing that year-over-year growth tends to slow
componenttext: Yes. Don, in John's prepared remarks, he talked about the sales trends or the sales trajectory by quarter being similar this year to last year. And with think that's a reflection of the market overall. We're seeing that year-over-year growth tends to slow as we go from even second to third quarter sequentially. And we're not sure if that's a function of market capacity or -- it doesn't feel to us like it's a change in demand trend. Our customers are still reporting very strong order book volume. And so it doesn't feel like third quarter jobs were pulled forward into first and second. It just feels like we're seeing some constraints in the rate at which contractors can get on those jobs.

componenttextpreview: The overall tone from our customers remains very positive on the architectural side.
componenttext: The overall tone from our customers remains very positive on the architectural side.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the raw material side, Don, it -- we think it's likely the raw materials will swing from a low single-digit tailwind in the third quarter to a low single-digit headwind in the fourth quarter, but we've kind of been guiding to that all along. We've
componenttext: Yes. On the raw material side, Don, it -- we think it's likely the raw materials will swing from a low single-digit tailwind in the third quarter to a low single-digit headwind in the fourth quarter, but we've kind of been guiding to that all along. We've said that the benefit from raw materials will diminish as we go through the year. The headwind, if there is one, in the fourth quarter will be primarily driven by modest inflation in TiO2. We think the TiO2 producers got some traction on both their second quarter and third quarter price increases during the year, so -- or during the second and third quarters. So we haven't put together an outlook for 2017 yet. But fourth quarter '16, it's going to be flat to -- raw materials are going to be flat to up low single digits.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Arun Viswanathan with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Arun Viswanathan with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats, Sean, [indiscernible] Just -- I guess, I wanted to follow up on the growth question. Over the last several years, we've seen Paint Stores Group kind of grow 1.5x to 2x the market. This quarter, it looks like the 2% growth is kind of in line with
componenttext: Congrats, Sean, [indiscernible] Just -- I guess, I wanted to follow up on the growth question. Over the last several years, we've seen Paint Stores Group kind of grow 1.5x to 2x the market. This quarter, it looks like the 2% growth is kind of in line with the market. Is that a fair assessment? And is there anything that changed that led to this kind of performance? And then also, in Consumer, it looks like the 2% decline is kind of a bit below. You discussed a modest decline in DIY. Maybe you can just help us understand what drove that.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a bit early to tell if there's an issue with market. I don't think we have enough data right now to know how our growth [ph] in the market compared to our competitors. Our third quarter last year showed the same sequential softness, as Bob me
componenttext: I think it's a bit early to tell if there's an issue with market. I don't think we have enough data right now to know how our growth [ph] in the market compared to our competitors. Our third quarter last year showed the same sequential softness, as Bob mentioned, before rebounding in the fourth quarter and the first quarter. And as I mentioned, we believe that the growth that we saw in the architectural side in residential repaint and new residential, very high, strong performance, the solid year in commercial and health care that I mentioned as well as the modest gains in property management. We still feel as though we're growing share. The -- and most importantly, I would say, would be the fundamentals. The position that we have in the marketplace with the contractor continuing to outpace the market and our positioning there and our continued investment there is what gives us the most confidence. These stores that we're adding, the reps that we're adding, the new products that we're adding as well as our core locations, we believe, will allow us to continue to grow share.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: [ph] And when [ph] you're asking about the Consumer Group, again, our Consumer Group this quarter was negatively affected by the European businesses as well as some of the commercial, industrial and MRO that are also embedded in there. So if you look at the North American architectural business, we were pleased with those results.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you back out the European business, our North American business was positive.
componenttext: Yes. If you back out the European business, our North American business was positive.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just as a quick follow-up on the price and raw material side. Usually, you take pricing, I guess, in the beginning of the year. Is there a reason you kind of pulled that forward? You discussed the low single-digit headwind.
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just as a quick follow-up on the price and raw material side. Usually, you take pricing, I guess, in the beginning of the year. Is there a reason you kind of pulled that forward? You discussed the low single-digit headwind. But presumably, if you're announcing it December 1, you won't see that in Q4. So is it safe to assume that, that will start flowing through in Q1? Or what's the cadence on realizing that pricing?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it speaks to what we have spoken about frequently, which is when we know we typically go. And the fact is, is that the last price increases you know that we took was in the first quarter of 2014. Many of our operating expense categories have
componenttext: Well, I think it speaks to what we have spoken about frequently, which is when we know we typically go. And the fact is, is that the last price increases you know that we took was in the first quarter of 2014. Many of our operating expense categories have risen since then: our wage and benefits; our store rent. And presumably, as Bob just mentioned, we're going to see some raw material increases. And so we knew it was time for a price increase, and we decided to go ahead and move on it.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Within Paint Stores Group, obviously, the results were below your expectations, and you outlined the different subsegments of it. But it wasn't clear to me which one of those came in below your expectations. You talked about high single-digit residential; doesn't seem like it would be that. [ph] So was it DIY? Was it the health care or Protective & Marine? What went wrong?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think obviously, our DIY with a modest decline was clearly below our expectation. For Protective & Marine, we still have high expectations for this team. We recognize that a big percentage of the business is growing in this oil and gas. But we are
componenttext: Well, I think obviously, our DIY with a modest decline was clearly below our expectation. For Protective & Marine, we still have high expectations for this team. We recognize that a big percentage of the business is growing in this oil and gas. But we are focused on a number of these other segments, and we're -- we have been involved in these other areas. And our expectations for all our teams are to continue to improve. So I would tell you that even our residential repaint up nearly double digits, our expectations are that we want to grow faster. So clearly, some of those underperformed to a little greater [ph] degree in the DIY and P&M or Protective and Marine that I mentioned. But it's safe to say that our expectations are we want to grow faster in every one of those segments.

componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up. Internally, as you guys assess the weather impact on any given quarter, do you have any particular means by which you do that? I mean, I think about a hurricane going up the Gulf Coast [indiscernible] -- I mean, sorry, at the East Coast in September, then we had another one in October for the fourth quarter. So how do you guys think about assessing the impact of lost painting days or even Fourth of July [ph] move today during this quarter from a Saturday to a Monday? So what is in the impact of that type of stuff? And is worth speaking about in advance to the extent that we know about it?

componenttextpreview: We don't like to talk about it. [indiscernible] -- I mean, our discussion internally, as you mentioned, is that we've got shareholders with high expectations, and we've got to find a way over the hill. And yes, we had closed stores in the areas that were
componenttext: We don't like to talk about it. [indiscernible] -- I mean, our discussion internally, as you mentioned, is that we've got shareholders with high expectations, and we've got to find a way over the hill. And yes, we had closed stores in the areas that were affected, but that -- we're not waiting on that. We have a determined effort on this side of the call to continue to drive and improve. And it's, quite frankly, something that we don't want to point to. We know it was there, but we have high expectations of ourselves.

componenttext: Duffy, this is Sean. I think it really goes back to just the lumpiness, the question that we [ph] asked earlier. componenttextpreview: But I didn't -- industry now coming up on 32 years and every day of my experience has been competitive. We work hard in what we do to add value to our customers. And as I mentioned, a piece of this, we expect will be raw materials. The other components in
componenttext: But I didn't -- industry now coming up on 32 years and every day of my experience has been competitive. We work hard in what we do to add value to our customers. And as I mentioned, a piece of this, we expect will be raw materials. The other components in that we have invested in to be able to supply our customers with a greater value our key drivers for our ability to put a price increase in. And we don't think that likely. We know it, to your point, and we know its competitive. We've got to be able to them straight our value to our customers. And so the combination of our products and our services have to make our customers more money at what they do or we don't deserve the business. And we understand how competitive businesses are out there. So we're investing in the right things to better position ourselves, to better help our customers.

componenttext: Got it, makes sense. Now let me ask him, if I could. Bob Wells, I think you talked about low single-digit raws inflation. John you mentioned you 4% to 5% seeking price in your store's business. How should we think about the gross margin path into 2017?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that 2017, when you look at it, we are very focused on operating margins as I know, they've been with us for many, many years. And I think over the last 3 years, plus the gross margin that's been driving those margins, I think that we all know tha
componenttext: I think that 2017, when you look at it, we are very focused on operating margins as I know, they've been with us for many, many years. And I think over the last 3 years, plus the gross margin that's been driving those margins, I think that we all know that the gross margin is not going to be as robust when it comes year-over-year. I don't -- I think that we're going to continue to do things for efficiencies in the land warehouse. The price increase, to make sure that the gross margin is somewhat positive or -- but it's not going to be the driver it's been for the last 3 years. But that operating margins are going to be also helped by the work that we're going to do in the SG&A.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, every year is different, as you know, Bob and we set out a plan in January 1. And by January 2, it changes depending on what's happening in the market. And one thing that will be true, to Sean's point, is a focus on this operating margin improvement.
componenttext: Yes, every year is different, as you know, Bob and we set out a plan in January 1. And by January 2, it changes depending on what's happening in the market. And one thing that will be true, to Sean's point, is a focus on this operating margin improvement. And so the efforts that will be taking will get us in there. We'll figure out only to do that. It may, stomach and, not be the margins in the past. It may be greater leverage on the SG&A while driving sales. But our commitment is the improvement in operating margins going forward.

componenttextpreview: I don't know if it costs more than we ever have and our ability to recruit on campus has been traffic. We hired, as you know, John, having traveled with us, between 1,200 and 1,400 management trainings a year. The performance of our company and the band h
componenttext: I don't know if it costs more than we ever have and our ability to recruit on campus has been traffic. We hired, as you know, John, having traveled with us, between 1,200 and 1,400 management trainings a year. The performance of our company and the band has allowed us to recruit the highest caliber trainees. And I'd say that, that just continuous but with a more time I spent with our trainee class, the more I'm impressed with our ability to recruit such high caliber people. So we've got confidence there. We've been able to negotiate good rents and leases with our track record. And we're becoming more and more choice in these markets because of our ability to ensure that the financial strength of the company and what we bring to the market. So gradually in a very good place right now in our focus continues to be on accelerating beeper for of those new stores.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: I recognize Europe is not an enormous region for you. But to the extent that you are exposing their, I was wondering if you can comment on trends that you're seeing by product line and also on an individual country basis, if you're seeing anything material there. Sounds like it hit consumer a bit. I'm wondering if you think that its macro or broad-based in nature or more idiosyncratic.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think when you look at the business we have in Europe, I think we are not broad-based at all. I think that we don't have any architectural business in Europe. So we ran out of probably a good barometer of what's happening there. On the industrial side,
componenttext: I think when you look at the business we have in Europe, I think we are not broad-based at all. I think that we don't have any architectural business in Europe. So we ran out of probably a good barometer of what's happening there. On the industrial side, we're probably have the in the industrial wood, but that's in the Global Finishes Group. That's actually been strong, stable, I'd say, I'd use the word stable. So I think to try to get some type of barometer in Europe, we're not of very good indicator of that.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And a second question, if I may, possibly for Bob. I think you mentioned your commercial business was up. I was wondering if we could speak to nonres more broadly on your third quarter experience and near-term outlook.
componenttext: Fair enough. And a second question, if I may, possibly for Bob. I think you mentioned your commercial business was up. I was wondering if we could speak to nonres more broadly on your third quarter experience and near-term outlook.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kevin. As a reminder, there's a pretty long lag between a nonresidential start on average and when that project is painted. So we are benefiting from fairly strong start activity 18 months to 2 years ago. And as a result, the commercial business is h
componenttext: Yes, Kevin. As a reminder, there's a pretty long lag between a nonresidential start on average and when that project is painted. So we are benefiting from fairly strong start activity 18 months to 2 years ago. And as a result, the commercial business is holding up quite well. It's not a strong as the residential segment. John indicated the residential businesses are up in the high single digits. It's not that strong but it's really solid year-over-year growth. The dark line around that silver cloud is that starts this year are actually down year-over-year. So we're seeing some weakness in new projects started that if that persist was going to impact our commercial business a couple of years out. But for the time being, it's good.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Was wondering if you could talk a little bit about Latin America. It what was nice to see you back about breakeven. And you've added about 25 stores this year. So could you talk a little bit about the strategy going forward, what the outlook might be? Sho
componenttext: Was wondering if you could talk a little bit about Latin America. It what was nice to see you back about breakeven. And you've added about 25 stores this year. So could you talk a little bit about the strategy going forward, what the outlook might be? Should we expect to remain above breakeven? Or could some of those investments start to weigh on the performance on the bottom line?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So our approach in Latin America is really market specific, not even country-specific. We understand that there are locations in the market throughout the Latin American region where a direct store model might be best and there might be others so tha
componenttext: Yes. So our approach in Latin America is really market specific, not even country-specific. We understand that there are locations in the market throughout the Latin American region where a direct store model might be best and there might be others so that are best utilized through home centers or through dealers. And our team down there is working very hard to upgrade our position in the marketplace. And by doing what we believe to be the heavy lifting now, while the market is maybe choppy and might be an understatement. But while taking the steps now that will be better able to participate at a greater rate once the market does improve. We do feel as though that it's hit a trough. It's too early to tell if its improvement in the market is sustainable there. The choppiness in sales and profit will likely to continue over the next few quarters. But we really do believe that the steps that we're taking right now are going to better position us by other employee base of that we have down there, better product line, more consistent products and a much more efficient path to the customer than what we've had in the past. So our expectations of what we're doing down there are clearly to outperform the market as we move forward.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would add that looking -- going forward, of course, you'd expect it will be closer to breakeven.
componenttext: And I would add that looking -- going forward, of course, you'd expect it will be closer to breakeven.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: All right. Then you've also talked about some of the SG&A expense control. I was wondering if you could talk at all about your marketing and advertising expenses and how those have trended during the year? At this point, are we running meaningfully above or below what we might think of as normal advertising expenses?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think we're meaningfully above or below. I think we're right around the same pace as we've been in the past. We're trying to be smart and efficient with what we're doing with media. But I wouldn't say that we've jumped or cut anything in a mea
componenttext: No, I don't think we're meaningfully above or below. I think we're right around the same pace as we've been in the past. We're trying to be smart and efficient with what we're doing with media. But I wouldn't say that we've jumped or cut anything in a meaningful way.

componenttext: Well, my point was that we certainly saw slowdown in the third quarter, Scott. And our feeling continues to be that the fundamental still support the market in a very positive way. And I know you heard Bob talk about those in a number of occasions. But if you just look at household formations, new home sales, single-family start permits, resales, the underserved entry into the new residential by builders, the fundamentals continue to be there. And we, in fact, the contractors are going to be the benefactor of many of these opportunities and our position with that contractors is something that we're continuing to improve in.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And by the way, Scott, maybe it wasn't worded as well as it could have been. But John's opening remarks basically said if it's slowdown in the housing cycle, contrary to what all the data would suggest. So it was kind of qualifying it by saying we're not
componenttext: And by the way, Scott, maybe it wasn't worded as well as it could have been. But John's opening remarks basically said if it's slowdown in the housing cycle, contrary to what all the data would suggest. So it was kind of qualifying it by saying we're not seeing it in the data, but if it is, we're still going to invest in the things that drive our growth.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate you guys clarifying that. And just kind of to reiterate, is this, I guess, more uncertainty to the cadence of how the business is growing? Have any impact on to how you are thinking about incremental investment back into the business an
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate you guys clarifying that. And just kind of to reiterate, is this, I guess, more uncertainty to the cadence of how the business is growing? Have any impact on to how you are thinking about incremental investment back into the business and/or the synergy guidance for Valspar?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I believe that our investments will continue as you've seen. This is a year that's going to have record sales, record profit, record operating margin. We're going to continue to invest in those drivers that we believe will allow us to drive that operating
componenttext: I believe that our investments will continue as you've seen. This is a year that's going to have record sales, record profit, record operating margin. We're going to continue to invest in those drivers that we believe will allow us to drive that operating margin further, and that's going to be in new stores, new reps, new products. And we believe that the contractor's positioned, as I said, very well in the market and our positions, we're going to be working very hard to improve that. And we've got confidence in that model. We've got confidence in our ability to execute.

componenttext: Yes, I think that in the past, we've said been 75% effective when you take a look at the increase. So 4.5% to 5 -- 4% to 5%, you're using 4.5% x 7%, you're talking just over 3%. I think we that we've constantly said that we're working to try to get that quicker. I think that you'll see some effect in December, but it'll be muted. And I think that the first quarter, you'll see hopefully, somewhere net 50% effectiveness. And then from then on, I think you'll see it 75%.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering from your perspective, business, you have this dichotomy between the pro- market contractor market and do-it-yourself. If you guys think back over the years, the company, I mean, you've ever seen this kind of divergence in the 2? And
componenttext: I was just wondering from your perspective, business, you have this dichotomy between the pro- market contractor market and do-it-yourself. If you guys think back over the years, the company, I mean, you've ever seen this kind of divergence in the 2? And what do you think is causing it? It seems like consumer, for some reason, is it weaker? We've seen that costs coming I'm just rang to understand from your perspective what do you think kind of going on? Have you ever seen this before? So anything you can shed, and a lie?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott, this is Bob. We've talked for a long time about this long-term secular trend away from DIY toward the contractor. And we saw that kind of step back in the direction of DIY and during the 2008, 2009 cycle. And since that time, we think that the
componenttext: Yes, Scott, this is Bob. We've talked for a long time about this long-term secular trend away from DIY toward the contractor. And we saw that kind of step back in the direction of DIY and during the 2008, 2009 cycle. And since that time, we think that there's been a pretty strong migration back toward the pro. What we've observed in past cycles is that when we see a period of rapid home value appreciation, in many cases, it will accelerate the move back to the pro. People are more inclined to hire a professional live there are feeling more positive about the equity that they have in their home. So the last 3 years pretty rapid home value appreciation that we've seen, may have accelerated this migration away from DIY and toward the pro. That's the best we've got. There's no empirical data as to why that's happening.

componenttext: So there's obviously, been like those probably households are probably do-it-yourself versus do it for me. Still a lot of buzz that millennials are finally, kicking into the year. But what you're saying to me maybe a good event I wondering if you have any thoughts on that piece as well?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we centrally agree that millennials will be a stronger driver in the housing market going forward. I mean, there's forecast of between 13.5 million and 17 million a new first-time homebuyers coming into the market in the next 5 years, which is reall
componenttext: Well, we centrally agree that millennials will be a stronger driver in the housing market going forward. I mean, there's forecast of between 13.5 million and 17 million a new first-time homebuyers coming into the market in the next 5 years, which is really exciting to us. And all due respect for the younger generations, we disagree with the notion that millennials our strong DIY years. They have not shown to be -- mainly the levels that their parents were. Baby boomers were far more DIY involved than their offspring. And it's Italy has a lot to do with schedules nowadays being very tight and lack of free time. But we don't necessarily see the millennials coming into the home buying market as driving DIY the way -- the baby boomers did generation ago.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's perfect. It argues with your business model, too. So that's good news for the long-term.
componenttext: That's perfect. It argues with your business model, too. So that's good news for the long-term.

componenttextpreview: You noted that keeping strong control on your SG&A cost is going to help your operating income line going forward. And of course, that was represented in most in the segments, but you also did note some headwind in the Paint Stores Group. So I'm curious w
componenttext: You noted that keeping strong control on your SG&A cost is going to help your operating income line going forward. And of course, that was represented in most in the segments, but you also did note some headwind in the Paint Stores Group. So I'm curious where will the incremental discipline come on the SG&A? Is it going to be in the Paint Stores Group? And if so, how is that going to affect your investment there? And if it's not in the Paint Stores Group, where would it be because it seems that Europe the disciplined across the board.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's going to be across the board. And I think if you look at our opportunities going forward, the ability to leverage SG&A in every organization and that is. I mentioned earlier about the Global Finishes Group taking a look at a number of the are
componenttext: Yes, so it's going to be across the board. And I think if you look at our opportunities going forward, the ability to leverage SG&A in every organization and that is. I mentioned earlier about the Global Finishes Group taking a look at a number of the areas in the back-office to become more efficient. We have those opportunities throughout the organization. What we're committed to, though, are those areas that are customer facing and continue to invest in this model. We just talked with the previous question about the long-term model and why it fits and why we believe in it. So we're going to continue to see us invest in new stores territories, new products, the things that allow us to different sheet ourselves from our competition. And you should expect us to continue to be animals on expenses with discussion last week about our budgeting process. And I mentioned, Al coming on Board and yes the same discipline that we that with Sean in the past. And we're going into our operating plan process. We're starting to ground zero. and were ripping all the expense out that we can that doesn't affect sales. And so we're -- we want to be that disciplined about what it is we're doing. We don't want point to past success and justify future expense. We want to be invested or those things are going to drive our business. And we're committed to do in that -- in the model so that will drive the operating margin of that we've talked about.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And just as a follow-up. You note the weakness in oil and gas and the protective and Marine. But there are a fair number of chemical projects coming up in the Gulf Coast. So is it just at the size of oil and gas is so high that offsets whatev
componenttext: Fair enough. And just as a follow-up. You note the weakness in oil and gas and the protective and Marine. But there are a fair number of chemical projects coming up in the Gulf Coast. So is it just at the size of oil and gas is so high that offsets whatever is going on in chemical in that part of your business? Or do you just not have the type of mix that you log or exposure to the chemical industry for your protective business?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a little bit of both. We've had success in oil and gas in areas that are not investing right now. And we're still growing market share in some of those areas. Even with the decline, we're still fighting and growing, we believe, share a very cha
componenttext: Well, it's a little bit of both. We've had success in oil and gas in areas that are not investing right now. And we're still growing market share in some of those areas. Even with the decline, we're still fighting and growing, we believe, share a very challenging market. But to your point, that's the point that I tried to make earlier, there are still areas for us -- there are opportunities in the space. You mentioned the chemical area where there are -- our assets coming online but we are fighting for a 1 of those projects. We know that the infrastructure is an area that eventually is going to have to Bay Area of focus for our country and countries around the world. And we are furthering our penetration in those areas. So what I don't want to give is the impression that we're just sitting here waiting for the oil and gas market to fix itself. We're out there fighting in existing markets, in adjacent markets and in new markets. And we believe that there's considerable amount of opportunity for us there, and we're determined to capture it.

componenttext: Just one on same-store sales and repaint for professionals. So just the home sales, looks like they were basically flat or down year-on-year for the third quarter of '15. But you guys saw high single-digits in Professionals segment there. Do you think that -- I guess, where do you attribute this to? Is it a stronger business model? I know that we obviously saw weakness in DIY. But I'm trying to get a sense of White the professional segment was so strong.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've had a team that's been focused on that segment for many years. And it goes back to the comment that I made earlier about our commitment to providing the products and the services, locations, the people that will help us differentiate us from o
componenttext: Well, we've had a team that's been focused on that segment for many years. And it goes back to the comment that I made earlier about our commitment to providing the products and the services, locations, the people that will help us differentiate us from our competition. And we're blessed with a good competition out there. So we're not satisfied. We're not complacent. We're not sitting here feeling as thought we've got it all figured out. We're trying to get better every day. And with our direct model, which is unique in the ability to partner with our customers and understanding what their needs are and sometimes sending flying need the didn't even know exist has allowed us, we believe, to grow faster than the market. And we're committed to doing the things that can help differentiate us from our competition by allowing our customers to be more successful in what they're trying to do.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, while you're right that existing home turnover does drive residential repaint activity, remodel activity in total year-to-date is up pretty substantially. It's up more than -- it's up almost 6% in spending year-on-year. So in the absence of a l
componenttext: And David, while you're right that existing home turnover does drive residential repaint activity, remodel activity in total year-to-date is up pretty substantially. It's up more than -- it's up almost 6% in spending year-on-year. So in the absence of a lot of growth in existing home turnover, we've seen growth in remodeling activity.

componenttext: And one last thing I would add is the point that Bob made earlier, which is the shift to more and more contractor base. I think we have technology there's a shift going on to the contractor. And we happen to be positioned very low for that contractor. But I also believe that that's helping that as well.

componenttextpreview: Chuck, we use third-party contractors. They do a variety of things for our customers. These previously immaterial amounts -- we used to net them in SG&A. We determine that the billings for the customer should have been grossed up in sales with the payment
componenttext: Chuck, we use third-party contractors. They do a variety of things for our customers. These previously immaterial amounts -- we used to net them in SG&A. We determine that the billings for the customer should have been grossed up in sales with the payment to the contractors, including the cost of goods sold for net immaterial impact and gross profit played thus reduce our gross margin and it does decrease our operating margin. And what we talked about is we did it prospectively in the third quarter. So we only booked it for the third quarter. Will do that in the fourth quarter, it will have a similar small impact and then in the first and second quarters of '17. So 2017 full year won't have any impact.
