componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Eric Bosshard with Cleveland Research Company.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions for you. First of all, Bob or Sean or Al, if you could review what we should be thinking about in terms of price, understanding the increase becomes effective December 1, which, I think, is a little different language than you've had in the
componenttext: Two questions for you. First of all, Bob or Sean or Al, if you could review what we should be thinking about in terms of price, understanding the increase becomes effective December 1, which, I think, is a little different language than you've had in the past. Curious what we should be assuming in terms of the time to implement and the amount of that, that should be expected to be realized.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that we've, in the past, have said that we've been 75% effective when you take a look at the increase. So 4.5% to 5% -- 4% to 5%, you're talking use at 4.5% x 75%, you're talking just over 3%. I think we that we have constantly said that we'r
componenttext: Yes. I think that we've, in the past, have said that we've been 75% effective when you take a look at the increase. So 4.5% to 5% -- 4% to 5%, you're talking use at 4.5% x 75%, you're talking just over 3%. I think we that we have constantly said that we're working to try to get that quicker. I think that -- I think you'll see some effect in December, but it'll be muted. And I think that the first quarter, you'll see, hopefully, somewhere net 50% effectiveness. And then from then on, I think you'll see, it at 75%.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then secondly, would just love a little perspective. And I think the statement was made that the store comp would be 5% ex Protective & Marine. And I'm curious, within that or if you want to speak to the expectation of the archit
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then secondly, would just love a little perspective. And I think the statement was made that the store comp would be 5% ex Protective & Marine. And I'm curious, within that or if you want to speak to the expectation of the architectural business, how that compares to the prior couple of quarters and what the expectation should be of that moving forward.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that the architectural -- I mean, if you look at the quarters, there's no doubt the first quarter was the strongest quarter architecturally. Second was the second strongest, and then the third. And -- but I do believe when you take a look at
componenttext: Yes. I think that the architectural -- I mean, if you look at the quarters, there's no doubt the first quarter was the strongest quarter architecturally. Second was the second strongest, and then the third. And -- but I do believe when you take a look at it, some of these -- the third quarter was probably weighed down because of that DIY component that we talked about. But -- so I think -- again, I think John's comments about the strength of the market and why we continue to invest and feel good about what kind of results we can produce in this Paint Stores Group are still driven by those thoughts on the architectural side.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excluding DIY, are you capable of looking through the numbers you're sharing with us, excluding DIY? It sounds like the resi repaint was up high single digits versus perhaps low double digits. Was -- other than DIY, it seems like the other pieces of archi
componenttext: Excluding DIY, are you capable of looking through the numbers you're sharing with us, excluding DIY? It sounds like the resi repaint was up high single digits versus perhaps low double digits. Was -- other than DIY, it seems like the other pieces of architecture slowed a bit in 3Q relative to its 2Q growth. Is that accurate?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any thoughts on the driver to that?
componenttext: And any thoughts on the driver to that?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will tell you, this is -- I think that labor, we're seeing things such as labor constraints some of these results of that we're having in some of these quarters.
componenttext: I will tell you, this is -- I think that labor, we're seeing things such as labor constraints some of these results of that we're having in some of these quarters.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Eric, it's not uncommon at all to hear contractors talk about their ability to do more work if they had more qualified labor.
componenttext: Yes. Eric, it's not uncommon at all to hear contractors talk about their ability to do more work if they had more qualified labor.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from the line of Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: The next question is coming from the line of Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I was just wondering, from your perspective, obviously, we have this dichotomy between the pro market -- contractor market, and do-it-yourself. If you guys think back over the years in the company, I mean, have you ever seen this kind of divergence in
componenttext: So I was just wondering, from your perspective, obviously, we have this dichotomy between the pro market -- contractor market, and do-it-yourself. If you guys think back over the years in the company, I mean, have you ever seen this kind of divergence in the two? And in your opinion, what do you think is causing it? I mean, It seems like the consumer, for some reason, is a little weaker. I mean, we've seen that across a lot of different sectors. And I'm just trying to understand, from your perspective, what you think is kind of going on? Have you ever seen this before? So anything you can shed light...

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Scott, this is Bob. We've talked for a long time about this long-term secular trend away from DIY toward the contractor. And we saw that kind of step back in the direction of DIY during the 2008-2009 cycle. And since that time, we think that there's
componenttext: Yes. Scott, this is Bob. We've talked for a long time about this long-term secular trend away from DIY toward the contractor. And we saw that kind of step back in the direction of DIY during the 2008-2009 cycle. And since that time, we think that there's been a pretty strong migration back toward the pro. What we've observed in past cycles is that when we see a period of rapid home value appreciation, in many cases, it will accelerate the move back to the pro. People are more inclined to hire a professional when they're feeling more positive about the equity that they have in their home. So the last 3 years, pretty rapid home value appreciation that we've seen, may have accelerated this migration away from DIY and toward the pro. That's the best we've got. There's no empirical data as to why that's happening.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I do a follow-up quick, Bob? Is that all right?
componenttext: Can I do a follow-up quick, Bob? Is that all right?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you bet.
componenttext: Yes, you bet.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there's obviously been a lot of thoughts regarding millennials, younger households, who are probably more do-it-yourselfers, do-it-for-me. There's been a lot of buzz that millennials are finally kicking it in the year. But what you're saying to me
componenttext: Yes. So there's obviously been a lot of thoughts regarding millennials, younger households, who are probably more do-it-yourselfers, do-it-for-me. There's been a lot of buzz that millennials are finally kicking it in the year. But what you're saying to me maybe argues against that, and I wondered if you have any thoughts on that piece as well.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we certainly agree that millennials will be a stronger driver in the housing market going forward. I mean, there is forecast of between 13.5 million and 17 million new first-time homebuyers coming into the market in the next 5 years, which is really
componenttext: Well, we certainly agree that millennials will be a stronger driver in the housing market going forward. I mean, there is forecast of between 13.5 million and 17 million new first-time homebuyers coming into the market in the next 5 years, which is really exciting to us. In all due respect for the younger generations, we disagree with the notion that millennials are strong DIY-ers. They have not shown to be at nearly the levels that their parents were. Baby boomers were far more DIY-involved than their offspring. And it certainly has a lot to do with schedules nowadays being very tight and lack of free time. But we don't necessarily see the millennials coming into the homebuying market as driving DIY the way the baby boomers did a generation ago.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's perfect because it argues for your business model, too. So that's good news for the long term.
componenttext: That's perfect because it argues for your business model, too. So that's good news for the long term.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from line of Nils Wallin with CLSA.
componenttext: The next question is coming from line of Nils Wallin with CLSA.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You noted that keeping strong control on your SG&A cost is going to help your operating income line going forward. And of course, that was represented in most of the segments, but you also did note some headwind in the Paint Stores Group. So I'm curious w
componenttext: You noted that keeping strong control on your SG&A cost is going to help your operating income line going forward. And of course, that was represented in most of the segments, but you also did note some headwind in the Paint Stores Group. So I'm curious where will the incremental discipline come on the SG&A? Is it going to be in the Paint Stores Group? And if so, how will that affect your investment there? And if it's not in the Paint Stores Group, where would it be? Because it seems you're pretty disciplined across the board.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's going to be across the board. And I think as you look at our opportunities going forward, the ability to leverage SG&A in every organization that existed. I mentioned earlier about the Global Finishes Group taking a look at a number of the ar
componenttext: Yes. So it's going to be across the board. And I think as you look at our opportunities going forward, the ability to leverage SG&A in every organization that existed. I mentioned earlier about the Global Finishes Group taking a look at a number of the areas in the back office to become more efficient. We have those opportunities throughout the organization. What we're committed to, though, are those areas that are customer facing and continue to invest in this model. We just talked with the previous question about the long-term model and why it fits and why we believe in it. So you're going to continue to see us invest in new stores territories, new products, the things that allow us to differentiate ourselves from our competition. And you should expect us to continue to be animals on expenses. We had a discussion last week about our budgeting process. And I mentioned, Al coming on board, and so the same discipline that we've with Sean in the past. We're going into our operating plan process. We're starting at ground zero, and we're ripping every expense out that we can that doesn't affect sales. And so we're -- we want to be that disciplined about what it is we're doing. We don't want to point to past success and justify future expense. We want to be invested in those things are going to drive our business. And we're committed to doing that in the models that will drive the operating margin that we've talked about.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And just as a follow-up. You note the weakness in oil and gas on the Protective & Marine. But there are a fair number of chemical projects coming up in the Gulf Coast. So is it just that the size of oil and gas is so high that it offsets what
componenttext: Fair enough. And just as a follow-up. You note the weakness in oil and gas on the Protective & Marine. But there are a fair number of chemical projects coming up in the Gulf Coast. So is it just that the size of oil and gas is so high that it offsets whatever is going on in the chemical in that part of your business? Or do you just not have the type of mix that you want or exposure to the chemical industry for your protective business?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a little bit of both. We've had success in oil and gas in areas that are not investing right now. And we're still growing market share in some of those areas. Even with the decline, we're still fighting and growing, we believe, share in a very
componenttext: Well, it's a little bit of both. We've had success in oil and gas in areas that are not investing right now. And we're still growing market share in some of those areas. Even with the decline, we're still fighting and growing, we believe, share in a very challenging market. But to your point, and that's the point that I tried to make earlier, there are still areas for us -- there are opportunities in this space. You mentioned the chemical area where there are assets coming online. We're fighting for every one of those projects. We know that the infrastructure is an area that eventually is going to have to be an area of focus for our country and countries around the world. And we're furthering our penetration in those areas. So what I don't want to give is the impression that we're just sitting here, waiting for the oil and gas market to fix itself. We're out there fighting in existing markets, in adjacent markets and in new markets. And we believe that there is considerable amount of opportunity for us there, and we're determined to capture it.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from line of Christopher Perrella with Bloomberg.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from line of Christopher Perrella with Bloomberg.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The antitrust regulatory environment. You've been doing deals for a while now. Have you noticed a change this year as you've gone through the Valspar deal?
componenttext: The antitrust regulatory environment. You've been doing deals for a while now. Have you noticed a change this year as you've gone through the Valspar deal?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think they're doing their job. They're asking questions that are appropriate, and we're trying to be as responsive as we can. I think going into this, we knew the deal and the facts, and we feel confident that the facts will carry the day. But we've
componenttext: No. I think they're doing their job. They're asking questions that are appropriate, and we're trying to be as responsive as we can. I think going into this, we knew the deal and the facts, and we feel confident that the facts will carry the day. But we've got a government agency that is empowered to look at these things and challenge. And they're doing just that. And we're trying to be as responsive as we can.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then a quick question. Inventory was up. Are you carrying more volume of inventory due to the slowdown here? And on the back of that, do you typically run promotions in through October at your paint stores?
componenttext: All right. And then a quick question. Inventory was up. Are you carrying more volume of inventory due to the slowdown here? And on the back of that, do you typically run promotions in through October at your paint stores?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll address the inventory. And our working capital was up slightly in the -- through September. The way we look at it, as a reminder, we target 10% of sales. Our working capital last year came in at 8.6%. We expect this year to come in around 10%. So I d
componenttext: I'll address the inventory. And our working capital was up slightly in the -- through September. The way we look at it, as a reminder, we target 10% of sales. Our working capital last year came in at 8.6%. We expect this year to come in around 10%. So I don't believe we're carrying more inventory than we should be.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do occasionally run a promotion in October.
componenttext: And we do occasionally run a promotion in October.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of David Wang with Morningstar.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of David Wang with Morningstar.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had one on same-store sales and resi repaint for professionals. So just the home sales, looks like they were basically flat or down year-on-year when you think of the third quarter of '15. But you guys saw high single digits in the professional segme
componenttext: Just had one on same-store sales and resi repaint for professionals. So just the home sales, looks like they were basically flat or down year-on-year when you think of the third quarter of '15. But you guys saw high single digits in the professional segment there. Do you think that's -- I guess, what would you attribute this to? Is it a stronger business model? I know that we obviously saw weakness in DIY, but I'm trying to get a sense of why the professional segment was so strong.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've had a team that's been focused on that segment for many years. And it goes back to the comment that I made earlier about our commitment to providing the products and services, locations, the people that will help us differentiate us from our c
componenttext: Well, we've had a team that's been focused on that segment for many years. And it goes back to the comment that I made earlier about our commitment to providing the products and services, locations, the people that will help us differentiate us from our competition. And we're blessed with good competition out there. So we're not satisfied. We're not complacent. We're not sitting here, feeling as though we've got it all figured out. We're trying to get better every day. And with our direct model, which is unique, and the ability to really partner with our customers in understanding what their needs are, and sometimes satisfying needs that they don't even know exist, has allowed us, we believe, to grow a little faster than the market. And we're committed to doing the things that can help differentiate us from our competition by allowing our customers to be more successful in what they're trying to do.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, David, while you're right that existing home turnover does drive residential repaint activity, remodeling activity in total year-to-date is up pretty substantially. It's up more than -- it's up almost 6% in spending year-on-year. So in the absence of
componenttext: And, David, while you're right that existing home turnover does drive residential repaint activity, remodeling activity in total year-to-date is up pretty substantially. It's up more than -- it's up almost 6% in spending year-on-year. So in the absence of a lot of growth in existing home turnover, we've seen growth in remodeling activity.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one last thing I would add is the point is the point that Bob made earlier, which is the shift to more and more contractor-based. I think we have to acknowledge that there's a shift going on to the contractor. And we happen to be positioned very well
componenttext: And one last thing I would add is the point is the point that Bob made earlier, which is the shift to more and more contractor-based. I think we have to acknowledge that there's a shift going on to the contractor. And we happen to be positioned very well for that contractor. But I also believe that's helping us as well.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: We've talked to the contractors who have mentioned this labor shortage, John. And I think it's even impact to how aggressive they want to be on bidding at this point. Does that bode well for projects going into next year once the paint season gets under way? We're coming into some tougher weather now seasonally. So what are your thoughts on that?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it does, Chuck. I think it's -- and that's the point that I made. I know I keep beating the same drum, but it's what gives us confidence about the model in 2017 and our ability to continue to drive operating margins going forward. You're exactly r
componenttext: I think it does, Chuck. I think it's -- and that's the point that I made. I know I keep beating the same drum, but it's what gives us confidence about the model in 2017 and our ability to continue to drive operating margins going forward. You're exactly right.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if you're looking at the Consumer Group, and, Sean or Al, you might want to address this one, the margins were up, lower sales, does some of that reflect what went on last year with the load into Lowe's and introductory promotional spending?
componenttext: Okay. And if you're looking at the Consumer Group, and, Sean or Al, you might want to address this one, the margins were up, lower sales, does some of that reflect what went on last year with the load into Lowe's and introductory promotional spending?

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think the spending has been pretty consistent and it -- like we talked about in the second quarter, it was maybe different programs. But with the -- around the other edges of SG&A, they did a nice job of controlling their cost, and we talked about t
componenttext: No, I think the spending has been pretty consistent and it -- like we talked about in the second quarter, it was maybe different programs. But with the -- around the other edges of SG&A, they did a nice job of controlling their cost, and we talked about the mix in that business that helped. So I think that's what's driving the margin.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know this is the end of the call. I got cut off somehow for a bit. And I think I joined just this you were explaining that reclassification. Now is the good time to just quickly explain that, it would be great. Otherwise, I'll catch you off-line.
componenttext: I know this is the end of the call. I got cut off somehow for a bit. And I think I joined just this you were explaining that reclassification. Now is the good time to just quickly explain that, it would be great. Otherwise, I'll catch you off-line.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chuck, we use third-party contractors. They do a variety of things for our customers. These previously immaterial amounts, we used to net them in SG&A. We determine that the billings for the customer should have been grossed up in sales with the payments
componenttext: Chuck, we use third-party contractors. They do a variety of things for our customers. These previously immaterial amounts, we used to net them in SG&A. We determine that the billings for the customer should have been grossed up in sales with the payments to the contractors included in cost of goods sold. And for net immaterial impact on gross profit, it does reduce our gross margin and it does decrease our operating margin. And what we talked about is we did it prospectively in the third quarter. So we only booked it for the third quarter. Will do that in the fourth quarter. That will have a similar small impact and then in the first and second quarters of '17. So 2017 full year won't have any impact.

headline: The Sherwin-Williams Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
